description:
An amazing dining experience at Wako! The $135 omakase is an incredible deal with the amount of sushi you get -- you're in good hands! The sweet shrimp with uni is not on the omakase menu but I definitely recommend ordering it as an extra ($14). 
You'll get a mixture of sushi and traditional hot plates throughout the course.

The second time I went the kin medai and katsuo really stood out. The fish really melts in your mouth!
author: Ayumi W.

description:
Perfection. Simply unreal! A close girlfriend of mine decided to make a rezzo here for our girlfriend's birthday. Out of this omakase geographic monopoly of NorCal, I've relieved I chose this destination. 

The ambiance was intimate and our service was informative with each selection and unrushed at a later reservation time. I wish we were able to snag seats at the bar so we could make conversation with the chefs, but we had good seating nonetheless. The deluxe omakase was nothing short of fresh and just ethereal.. I've never been so FULL from omakase and I can say with confidence, I felt like we were spoiled by each taste that came out! It was all timed perfectly with palate cleansers here and there. Everything was absolutely toothsome and I'm here for this establishment striving off their quality.
author: Vivian T.

description:
Here for a weekend date with a reso made one month in advance - remember to request a seat at the bar on opentable! 

Cozy, unpretentious ambiance. Service was excellent. 

Fresh fish for the nigiri, good kaiseki dishes (bf thought they were excellent but I didn't like the mackerel in one of them as much).  There are a lot of pieces included in the prices, but their sizes are on the smaller end for omakase pieces. Slightly disappointed with the uni piece - a pity that the flavor didn't stand out as much in the hand roll.

TLDR: tho nothing particularly stood out to me, still a great cozy omakase place with good value!
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Picture a symphony playing in perfect harmony -- an array of violins, cellos, trombones, and saxophones together, combining for a mellifluous experience. This is the essence of Wako, where the cordial head chef, with photogenic pieces of nigiri as his instruments, is a near-flawless conductor.

Diners may opt for the 10 piece nigiri omakase or the slightly elevated 15 piece set. But either way, each bite is delicately crafted and well, the pictures speak for themselves. Sitting at the bar is an experience in itself. The attention to detail is both mesmerizing, and salivating, to watch. And by sitting bar-side, you also receive the more senior of the two serving chefs, so I highly recommend doing so.

Slightly lackluster for a meal of this stature ($135 if you opt for the premium option) are the appetizers and transitional dishes. The dishes, which consist of pumpkin tofu, cooked mackerel, and dashi soup may be plated phenomenally but are forgettable backdrops. So unless you are accustomed to a luxurious lifestyle or are simply a sushi connoisseur, justifying the price tag will be necessarily difficult, if not impossible.
author: Anderson H.

description:
Outstanding omakase at an excellent price point.  Thank you to Geoff G. for this personal recommendation!  His Foodie IQ is off the charts, and he is able to articulate his experiences in eloquently written and entertaining reviews.  Yelp is fortunate to have him as a 6-year consecutive Elite contributor!!

Every single course from our 9 course ($135.00) Chef Tasting Menu was excellent, both in taste and presentation.   The other omakase option is a 7 course for $95.00. Most impressively presented was the first course (see pic.), which was the perfect preamble that whet our appetites for the 8 other courses to follow.  All of which did not disappoint.  The only item I didn't care as much for was the fish miso soup, which I found overly salted with over done bits of fish.  If I were given a re-do, I would opt for the vegetable miso instead.  

The pieces of nigiri were my favorite.  Every bite so perfectly fresh.  I especially enjoyed the fatty, melt in your mouth Blue fin tuna belly with caviar, the Hokkaido scallop, and the live sweet shrimp, which we ordered as an additional item.  Additional nigiri is available for order.  You may opt for a nigiri that wasn't included in your omakase, or perhaps you  want more of a specific nigiri that you loved, that's an option as well.  Note that the prices on the nigiri are per piece. 

Another highlight for me was the deep fried small fish.  It was described by the server as a sweet fresh water fish.  The bits of the whole fish was fried, in addition to the bones, including the tail (see pic.).   I commented to my friend that I could literally indulge in a small bowl of just the fried bones and tail, the way I do potato chips.  Incredible!

What a pleasure to experience a true authentic Japanese restaurant, amidst the omnipresence of Chinese and Korean owned ones throughout the Bay Area.  This was evident in the high level of care and attention given to the high quality food, presentation, and service, which was well executed from start to finish.  It was so authentic that it was a little difficult at times to understand some of the servers with accentuated Japanese accents, but I'll make that exchange any day.

Having been on an "omakase crawl" with a friend for quite a few months now, I've had a chance to experience a wide variety of spots, including Hashiri, Kusakabe, Omakase, and Wakuriya, just to name a few.  Wako ranks right up there.  Perhaps a very very close second to Kusakabe, which comes with a little more upscale setting, but also with a little higher price point.  

The 4.5 stars out of 5 based on 440 reviews on Yelp don't lie.  That's no small feat, and definitely well deserved.  Definitely looking forward to return visits sooner rather than later.
author: Lori N.

description: What an amazing experience! Each piece better than the last. My BF and I came here to celebrate a life event, and walked away happier and fuller. We both opted for the omakase #2 ($135/person). The A5 wagyu with truffle is not on the menu but I highly recommend it if you want an umami explosion for your tastebuds! Furthermore there was impeccable attention to detail and the service was outstanding. While the waitress was serving us our last dessert dish, she overheard me talking about how everyone was congratulating me on my new job. She paused half way and said, "Congratulations?! For what?!" And then promptly took away our dishes, only to come back with our desserts on a festive plate with confetti, a candle, and a small "Congratulations" card on it! Again, just an amazing experience!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Wako has been on my to-try list for years! I finally had the chance to stop by a couple weeks ago. The service here is on point! We chatted about rose and without asking our server, a waitress heard us and automatically brought us a wine list.

We got the smaller pre-fixe but were very happily full by the end of the meal. Previous reviews mentioned a stronger use of wasabi and I did feel that is true. While it didn't bother me all too much, if you're not a fan you may want to be careful. It's well balanced but definitely on the higher end of the "balanced spectrum." and definitely stronger than japan, but that might be because a lot of the fish did have to endure an 11 hour flight from Asia. 

Overall a lovely experience in an intimate setting. We made reservations via opentable and were not seated at the sushi bar, so if that's important to you make sure to call the restaurant ahead of time or mention it when you make the reservation.
author: Annie Z.

description:
I came expecting a Michelin experience, and I got a Michelin experience.

Wako does get pretty pricey, but I'd say I got about what I paid for.  We opted for the $135 tasting, and I'm pretty sure those extra pieces of nigiri were worth it.  Especially at the end when they started serving us the crab and ikura and uni.  I was also very pleasantly surprised that the last piece served to us wasn't toro (that was the penultimate piece), but anago.  I've never had a more fluffy, delicious piece of eel before!  The other nigiri were well done and there were a few interesting pieces.  Appetizer sampler plate was whimsical and beautifully presented.

Our servers were super gracious, and did a great job of keeping a straight face even when they dropped in on the increasingly inappropriate conversations that unfolded throughout the night.  The four of us were celebrating a birthday, and before they placed the desserts they showered my friend's space on the table with birthday confetti.  I've never had a restaurant do that before, and she was delighted.

Tips and Tricks
-Yolo, $135 omakase!
-Tell them if you're celebrating a special event
-I recommend the shima aji and anago if they aren't served to you in your tasting
author: Jessica L.

description:
I came to Wako with my family for my dad's birthday and it was fantastic. Since I booked this for a Saturday night, I made sure to get a reservation exactly one month out when reservations opened up online. Even then, I was only able to snag the last slot (8:30pm) for my group of four.

We got the $135 omakase (the more expensive omakase option) which left us feeling more than stuffed. It consisted of several sushi courses interspersed with cooked dishes. Highlights included:
- Appetizer set that consisted of many little dishes such as a shooter, tomato + cream cheese skewer, tamago, and sesame ball
- Tuna sushi topped with caviar and gold flakes
- Crab and ikura over rice
- Tamago that was so fluffy and sweet that it tasted almost like pound cake

All of the food was amazing and beautifully plated. Best part was they threw some birthday confetti with our dessert since it was my dad's birthday!
author: Michelle L.

description:
An amazing sushi restaurant, and def worthy of its Michelin one star. My friend and I wanted to celebrate our birthdays together, and chose Wako as our celebration restaurant. We made reservations on a weekday, and when we came in got seated immediately. There wasn't too many people so it was nice to enjoy the food, see the chefs at work, and have good convos. My friend and I sat at the sushi bar, so we were able to see the real deal, and have our sushi made by the owner himself!! The owner is super sweet, explains all the dishes he presents, and is an amazing chef!

We first started with an appetizer, which was absolutely beautiful. Then we got 5 Sushi pieces, an interim dish, and then another 5 sushi pieces. We decided not to get the extra 5 pieces as we were already feeling pretty full. We added on an extra piece of uni though .. so delicious. Literally melts in your mouth. And the night ended with an aged miso soup, and some yummy dessert. The Sushi dishes that were the most delicious we're definitely the toro and uni! 

We also ordered a sake per recommendation of the owner, and it was so smooth and delicious as well. I need to look up its name :P

The service was fantastic. The servers were quick to always serve us, clear our tables, and make sure our drinks were filled. This is an amazing place and I hope they get their second Michelin Star soon!
author: Jackie C.

description:
I rarely write reviews (despite being a glutton and eating out all the time) but I need to give a shoutout to Ryan.

I had to cancel a reservation at Wako two whole years ago (!) and he honored what I paid for the fee then as credit towards dinner tonight. I know they made an exception, and it was above-and-beyond fantastic service even compared to 3-Michelin restaurants. I've only felt a similar care for customers at Atelier Crenn.

Wako masters the elegant simplicity of Japanese omakase. I'm still in awe thinking about how the knife work rippled on the porcelain-colored octopus (not to mention the delicate sweetness of flavor) and the stunning ruby of the mackerel, overlaid with a sweet and salty clear layer that reminded me of the umami of seaweed. As my dinner mate remarked, it was a beautiful balance of kaiseki and sushi too, with alternating cooked and raw dishes.

My own preferences lean towards creative and fusion in chef-prepared dishes but I will say that this is one meal that will stay in my memory just because of how accommodating Ryan and other staff were and the pure visual beauty of the sashimi. There's modern art to be made.
author: A. L.

description:
Amazing! 

I've been twice now and it's been a savory experience every time. 

Fresh fish, purist flavors, fantastic rice. 

Tomo san has served me both times and it was a stellar meal. He's talkative, informative and very talented. He explained each piece of fish even giving an origin.   

Lovely staff but not intimidating and delicious omakase! Always opt for the sushi bar for optimal experience. 

Favorites: 
Barracuda 
Mackerel
Uni from Hokkaido 
Ocean Sea perch
author: Mone J.

description: Love this place! We went for my birthday this year and had to make a reservation one month ahead! I love their cozy setting, food were super fresh with gorgeous presentation. It was a great experience and left us extremely satisfied.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
We have sampled a few high-end sushi/Japanese restaurants.
Our experience at Wako was good, but it was not off the chart when placed next to their competitors. The price also plays a big part. The four of us sat at a table (not at the counter), our waitress, I presumed she was Japanese, tried to explain the dishes. We have two Japanese speakers at our table including myself. The four of us could not understand what our waitress was saying. And That's every time she stopped by with a new dish...
author: Blueberry P.

description:
I remember going to Wako before they got a Michelin star...They deserve it! Very nice people.

I was here late on a Saturday night and got the 7 course meal. Small intimate setting...very good sashimi...rest of the meal was good ...very friendly staff. Was not blown away but good experience overall.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Wow. 

I said this, "wow" emphatically and repeatedly throughout the meal we just enjoyed at this remarkable Michelin Starred Sushi restaurant. I was so impressed both by the amazing parade of light, yet flavorful courses, paired perfectly with a sake combination and flawless, completely understated yet essential service. (For example, my husband habitually drops his napkin from lap to ground, tonight his napkin was replaced without his notice in a beautiful folded arrangement after his had dropped, also without his notice.) 

We were lucky enough to enjoy the premium Omakase menu paired with the sake pairing, and every course was a delight. I was particularly thrilled to taste the barracuda, (dense yet light and meaty and flavorful) and the Hokkaido uni! The chef made what I termed "uni-shiso," which was a perfect example of this chef's menu- there was genius WHIMSY in each bite, combining citrus or shiso or savories, or earthy umami flavors with the fish to create unique and palate-dancingly delicious bites of fresh fishy fantasy.

Or, TLDR- eat here. It's stunning and a FUN, friendly high-end Sushi experience.
author: Sarah H.

description:
A few friends I know tend to live their lives on a sushi rush, literally going to as many sushi restaurants in SF and trying their omakase offerings. Wako came up one day and I jumped on the opportunity to try this place out. 

For those of you who live under a rock, omakase is literally a meal consisting of a variety of dishes selected by the chef. During the experience, you have the opportunity to order different items at the end but the actual experience is all selected by the chef, so be prepared to eat anything and everything! 

Wako is one of those small joints that only offer omakase. There's a sushi bar and a handful of tables so reservations are almost required. There are 2 omakase offerings, a $95/person and a $135/person. The difference is an extra 5 pcs nigiri set and a dashi soup for the higher priced set. 

I loved how the sushi chef and staff was so thorough with what item you were eating and from what region in Japan the fish came from. The dishes were well thought out and intricately created. Flavors were bold and full of life, sushi was super fresh. What an experience! 

In one of our courses, my friend noticed a little hair in the dish. Bringing that to the attention of the staff, they showed extreme empathy and gave us a bottle of sake on the house. That was super sweet of them and really appreciated. Overall, I had a fantastic time there and can't wait to return. Thanks for the amazing service and food, Wako!
author: Rockne H.

description:
I have a soft spot in my heart for Wako because it was my first Michelin-starred restaurant and my first omakase menu when I moved to the Bay Area three years ago. I loved everything they served at that time, including my first monkfish liver and an extraordinary chawanmushi (also my first) topped with uni. As a result, I was afraid to go back for fear that things wouldn't be as good as I remembered them and I would be horribly disappointed. Thankfully, I was wrong, and when I went back at the end of June it was just as good.

Ambiance and Service: It's a small, warm space, with lots of wood. Welcoming and relaxing rather than intimidating. We were a few minutes early for our reservation, but were greeted and seated immediately. I prefer table seating because I don't like making conversation or reacting to food in front of the person who prepared it (just in case something isn't great). There's also a bar for those who prefer to watch the chef at work. 

The staff is friendly, deft, and efficient, working as a team to quietly tend to things before you even notice you need something. There was even a designated server whose job appeared to be just keeping an eye on things and swooping in to replace dropped napkins, etc. Again, all without being overly precious or intimidating the way upscale dining can be. My partner secretly told them it was my birthday, but they didn't make an embarrassing scene, which I hate. Instead, they simply wished me a happy birthday by name when placing the dessert, and threw a small handful of birthday confetti. I appreciated the reserve. 

Food: We ordered the #2 tasting ($135 per person) and added on the wagyu beef with summer truffle. Once again, everything from start to finish was delicious, artfully presented, and interesting/varied. I won't go over each course in detail (see pictures), but in terms of the sushi, I particularly enjoyed the chance to try barracuda, which was a first for me, and, predictably, found the red nose amberjack, uni, blue fin tuna belly with caviar, and the add-on wagyu beef with summer truffle particularly enjoyable, although all the sushi were high quality fish, well prepared and presented. The chef dabs each piece with the perfect complement amount of wasabi and soy as well.  

I also want to take a moment to mention the warm dish, which was a Japanese sweet fish with fig and pickled Japanese ginger. I was somewhat nervous when it arrived at the table because it included the fish tail and skeleton, fried. I've had a similar warm dish at Kusakabe and found it wasn't enjoyable eating the tail fin, etc. (it was dry and the flavor was also underwhelming). This fried tail was crunchy and flavorful, the fish meat bundles were juicy and warm, and the fig was an unexpected and delicious accompaniment. The pickled ginger was also an elevated version of a palate cleanser to the dish. 

Overall, Wako continues to offer a pleasurable, memorable, and superior dining experience for a surprisingly good price, especially in comparison to other SF omakase spots.
author: Katherine A.

description:
Easily, I mean easily the best meal I've ever had. This was my second Michelin star restaurant after the famous Sardine restaurant in Tokyo. Not even sure how to write this review... because everything was just so darn good. We went with the second Omakase option and by the end of the meal, I was so full.

Let me just try to list my favorites here - The Firefly squid in the appetizer kinda set the expectations for what the rest of the meal was going to be like. Boy has squid ever tasted this good. Each and every single nigiri I had was out of this world - the red snapper, the striped jack, the barracuda, were all absolutely amazing. The chef also hit it out of the park with the Anago sushi. The A5 Kobe beef tasted as good as I had always dreamed it would. 

Before I move on to my most favorite part of this meal, let me talk about the one puzzling part of my experience here - he order in which the nigiri was served. The chef didn't serve us all in the same order. He always kept serving us in different orders. It did affect my experience a little bit. 

Now with that out of the way, let me talk about the delightful Shirago. It tasted kinda like goat brain if you've ever had the pleasure, but only it was much much better. It was so good I had to order it again a la carte. It was then I realized what Shirago actually is - cod milt; yeah, look it up :( But never the less, it tasted like an umami cloud.

If I only made more money, would do this at least once every month. Again, very hard to put in words how delightful this whole experience was. 

Me :3 Wako.
author: Ganesh K.

description: This is a highly recommended sushi kaiseki restaurant. head Chef Tomoharu nakamura sushi is the ultimate, sushi rice and ingredients are perfectly blended, and Japanese soup is very delicious. I like it here, highly recommended!
author: 会懿

description:
I had read a lot of great things about Wako, so I took a gamble and booked my boyfriend's birthday dinner here without having tried it myself. I'm so glad I did!

We went with the eleven course meal (warning: with so many things in each course, it feels like much more than eleven courses), and I loved everything we had--from the "uni taco" to the wagyu nigiri (probably the tastiest bite of beef I've ever had). Each dish was made with such astounding attention to detail, and all of the fish we had was incredibly fresh. 

I'd love to come back, but next time I'll probably try the nine course instead of the eleven since I left feeling just a little overstuffed. :)

Be sure to request a seat at the bar--the experience at the tables just didn't feel quite as special.
author: Kelly R.

description:
I love omakase and Wako definitely won't let you down! It's easy to make reservations on their website or OpenTable!  If you request to sit at the bar, you'll have to call them to let them know & they call you a few days before to confirm it. 

Parking- Plan to come early because parking is difficult. After circling around many times, the waitress told us to try parking on 8th street between Clement and Geary, which is only a few blocks away. We were able to find parking there! 

They have a 9-course and 11-course omakase. We got the 11-course ($130) because we thought the extra items would be worth it! What I like about this place is that they give you the a la carte menu in the beginning so that you can follow along and see exactly what you're getting. 

They give 4 nigiri at a time and separate that with other items! I loved all their nigiri and I was so surprised that they included blue fin tuna belly, Wagyu beef, and uni! Most places I go to, they don't include all of them and if you want it, you have to pay for it separately. Their toro just MELTED in my mouth, even their chu-toro (medium fatty tuna)!! The wagyu beef was not bad, it was a little too torched for my taste, but it was still good! 

The a la carte menu is different every day, and if yours has a negitoro hand roll, I recommend getting it!! Instead of the toro being finely chopped up like other places, the toro was actually in pretty thick cuts. For $7 that was a steal! I definitely will order more of that next time! 

Overall, very friendly and helpful staff. I like the ambiance- they play music, which makes it easier to talk with your party. I definitely recommend making your reservation at the sushi bar because I noticed that a different chef makes the omakase for the tables. They change the menu roughly every other month, and I'll definitely be back!
author: Letty H.

description:
My bf made the rookie mistake of booking a table vs the bar. First mistake. Always sit at the bar for omakase! 

But although we weren't getting the same bar experience, the food tasted really good! Staff were very attentive without being annoying, and overall it was an enjoyable experience.

As for the nigiri, here you get very little rice to fish proportions. While I like this in rolls, and the fish was definitely the feature, we were both hungry a few hours later... And when you're paying roughly $150/person, buying another dinner isn't what I want to do.

While the nigiri was well presented, and their flavors paired well, the cooked fish dish was overcooked and dry - very disappointing. 

Overall, is it better than some of the other high end omakase spots in the city? I don't think so, but glad I was able to give them a try.
author: Mandi W.

description:
You get to choose between an Omakase menu of 9 courses for $92 or 11 courses for $130. We chose the 11 course which comes with a starter, appetizer, 4 pieces of nigiri sushi, owan (soup), a grilled dish, 4 more pieces of nigiri, a deep fried dish, 4 final pieces of nigiri, wite or red miso soup, and a house made dessert. 

We didn't get to sit the bar where all the action is so that definitely took away from the entire experience. We usually like to interact with the chef and learn more about the chef's background and apprenticeship but didn't get to do that this time. I'm not sure if we have to make the request during reservations to be seated at the bar because sitting at the regular tables makes it feel like you're eating at any old sushi spot.

The fish is very fresh, we were served a good selection during our dining experience here. I liked that they threw in some hot foods (fried/grilled) dishes in between for variety.

The restaurant is small and intimate, a very good spot for date night. Make sure you get bar seating for the full experience!
author: Janny S.

description:
Very good food!

Let me preface by saying I am very picky about Japanese food / edomae sushi, and walked in with skepticism.  This place really exceeded expectations and 100% deserves its Michelin Star for interesting, creative, authentic, gorgeously delicate food.

We went with the pricier omakase which included an extra hot soup and 5 more nigiris than the cheaper omakase.

Above all the overarching taste of the meal was light, delicate, nuanced, but very balanced umami.  For me personally it turned out to be the perfect palate.

The standout dishes for me were:
1) Appetizers combo which were a super interesting mix of flavors/textures, each perfectly executed.  The most delightful piece was the cream cheese with tomato (which doesn't really taste like what it sounds).
2) bluefin tuna nigiri marinated in jalapeño soy sauce.  Surprising taste but it works soooo well.  Very creative.

Also very good:
3) sakura mochi with tiny ground chicken bits in clear dashi soup.  I've had similar dishes at other restaurants but this was fluffier and just better done.
4) horse hair crab with crab miso nigiri, served in a little bowl.  Very crabby and fresh.
5) green tea gelatin dessert was so delicately made it looks like it was made under a microscope.  Very light taste but not simple, a bunch of different things going on in the dish.
6) seafood egg cake was perfect balance of savory and sweet.
7) wagyu beef nigiri, with spicy daikon topping.
8) another nigiri piece (I forget the fish) that tasted like it had light ume (plum) sauce.
9) simmered yellowtail - pleasantly lightly sweet.

The only piece I liked slightly less was the sea eel, which I felt could have used just a little more sauce/flavoring or slightly less eel so it doesn't taste bland.  Also was not a huge fan of their sushi ginger, which seemed a bit too sweet / reminiscent of cheap sushi ginger to me, compared to what other high end sushi restaurants serve.

On a stand-alone basis there are sushi restaurants that serve better fish or showcase better knife work (even though these guys are also quite good!) - but their kitchen dishes are amazing, and I love that they take risks - and delight - with unconventional things like jalapeño shoyu.

5/5 highly recommend.
author: Sallie D.

description:
We spend our one-year dating dinner at Wako. 

The environment are quiet and decent. Love it. Personally I like the restaurant with brighter light, then at least I can see the food clearly hahaha. A bit hard to find parking. 

Sushi are def good and dishes are creative! Toro/Uni can never go wrong~ 

I feel like the experience would be better if we had the bar table. We came in 8:30, pretty much the last customer to served, the food came in one after one (too fast), which makes me wonder if It's pre-made. You know most of omakase nigiri will only make it when the customer ready to eat next in order to keep the best temperature. And we had 4 pics topping with green onion and ginger (favor duplication)...
author: Wong T.

description:
Everything is in the details

From the ambiance to the bathroom is crafted to be an intimate experience. The food was delicious and tasted so fresh. Crafted and presented beautifully. It was expensive, but that was expected. 

I went for my anniversary, reserved to sit at the bar. Made reservations for a Tues night approx 6 days before. Great experience. The staff are helpful as it was our first time. It was so fun watching them make the sushi. Would definitely go back if I felt like having the whole experience again. 

TIPS: Ask to sit at the bar
author: Taylor W.

description:
When was the last time you went to a restaurant and it made you rethink  everything you ate in your entire life? Wako's 9-course omakase does not excel at everything but that didn't matter when it came to the nigiri. The nigiri was so incredible, blasting your senses with so much flavor and life that nothing else in the world mattered except you, the rice, and the fish. Seriously. 

Wild red snapper from Nagasaki - This had to have been laced with Hogwarts floo powder because I felt like I was being taken on a culinary adventure through the Japanese landscapes in 5 seconds. How does a piece of fish make me feel like this? 

White squid with sea urchin - Fantastic blast of flavor from the urchin complimented by the blandness of the squid. Best uni I had since Jean George's.

Flounder - Great. 

Seared Scallop from Hokkaido - The best scallop I've had my entire life. I envisioned a bunch of scallops relaxing by the seashores when I ate this. Am I really saying all of this in a Yelp review? 

Mackarel - The juiciest mackarel I have ever had. My dad (aka lover of all mackarels) needs to eat this once in his life. 

Sea urchin from Hokkaido - Tasted like a fresh breeze from the sea. How is that even possible? It's yellow. 

Dietary preferences - Very accommodating. My dessert was a lychee shaved ice that was light, crisp, and refreshing. 

Birthday - Celebrated it at the chef's counter. Chef Tomoharu Nakamura prepared all of our nigiri in front of us and was the friendliest host I've ever interacted with. Thank you for welcoming me and making me feel special on this occasion. 

Most Michelin restaurants are worth one try and then on to the next. Not this one. We will most certainly be back for more.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night and really enjoyed the great food and the exceptional service (they were also very accommodating in moving my reservations when my friend cancelled).  I picked the higher of the two omakase menus ($135) and really enjoyed it.  The courses were:

(1). Starter was herring roe and ikura (love this combo)
(2). Hassun plate was good and the oyster was outstanding
(3). Hokkaido Halibut and snapper
(4). Scallop, Striped Jack and White squid with uni 
(5). Dashi soup with mushroom
(6). Barracuda and Amber Jack
(7).  Japanese soy marinated blue fin tuna, mackerel with kelp, bonito
(8).  Warm dish (grilled yellowtail)
(9).  Horse hair crab with crab miso (probably my favorite of the night)
(10).  Hokkaido uni
(11).  Blue fin tuna with caviar
(12).  Anago
(13).  Wagyu
(14).  Gizzard shad (extra piece)
(15).  Amaebi with uni (extra piece - this is really good)
(16).  Amaebi head
(17).  Egg
(18).  Red miso
(19).  Green tea and red bean mousse 

My one critique of this place is that the nigiri is on the same side.  I've been to other Omakase places with really stand-out (and large) pieces (the shiroyaki at Kusakabe or A5 wagyu at Akiko's) but Wako provides an amazing variety of fresh fish and flavors.  I did not leave hungry.  I think it's very deserving of a Michelin star and worth the trip to the Richmond.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Definitely enjoyed our omakase and sake pairing but unfortunately felt like nothing really stood out. Maybe I tend to enjoy the omakase restaurants where they play with flavors a bit more. 

We opted for the 135 pp omakase and they hand you a menu with the nigiris available for the night but Chef Tomo chooses which 15 to give you and sadly not all the ones we wanted were chosen (and at the end were too full and weren't up to spending more money to get the ones we wanted to try).
author: Laura D.

description:
4.75/5
Came by with my friend on a Tuesday night. We were able to get a spot pretty easily since it was a weekday (called in about 1.5 wks ahead of time). The restaurant itself is very small (sushi bar + ~4 small tables). Service was nice but not on the same caliber as other Michelin restaurants I've been to where I feel like I'm waited on hand and foot (not that that's a bad thing, if anything I felt a bit more relaxed). They were very kind, explained each item well, and made sure our food came at the perfect pace.

Our meal included the following:
1) Firefly squid: The miso brought a nice zing. Crisp blanched asparagus went well w/ creamy insides of the squid. (3.5/5)
2) Various small apps: Gorgeous presentation. (4/5)
Items included:
-Seaweed w/ strawberry vinagrette: tartness of the strawberry went really well w/ seaweed's oceany taste and slimy texture was fun)
-Sesame tofu w/ wasabi (tofu had almost mochi like stickiness w/ deep bitter taste from sesame
-Cream cheese/shiso/tomato: Japanese cream cheese so it had a nice sweetness
-Wagyu croquette w/ red miso: Croquette ok but sauce was great.
-Deep fried sea eel/shiso/uni butter: Uni & eel's flavors came out but needed a bit more salt
-Sweet egg

Various nigiri courses. Loved their combos. Very unique compared to other spots I've been to. Quality fish, rice could've been a bit more flavorful. Pieces on the small side but w/ everything I was at a light fullness so I'm happy. (4.5/5-5/5)
3) Red snapper w/ cherry blossom, lemon, rock salt: Fruity flowery flavors paired well w/ the tender snapper
4) Halibut w/ spicy daikon: The oil on top was delicious but fish a bit chewy
5) Ink squid w/ uni: 2 types of creaminess came through w/ the taste of those dried squid snacks + an extra kick
6) Striped Jack w/ ginger: Fish had almost a scallop-like texture
7) Seared scallop: Bitterness from the char went well w/ sweet sauce

8) Sakura mochi w/ braised chicken, bamboo shoots, & sansho leaf: Chicken a bit dry but mochi was delicious & not pounded completely so still had some grain texture. (3.5/5)

9) Red nose amberjack w/ yuzu: Also had scallop-like texture but less oily than the striped jack
10) Barracuda w/ ginger: Fishy taste but w/ texture of light whitefish
11) Bonito w/ chives, daikon pulp, garlic chip: Super light piece w/ garlic flavors enveloping it. Loved it
12) Mackerel w/ sea kelp: Had rounded sweet taste and brine from kelp cuts through the fishiness
13) Cold Cherry Smoked salmon: Smoke brought out salmon's natural sweetness.

14) Steamed mackerel w/ snaps peas, clams, spinach: Most average dish. Fish was mostly tender. Broth was good but nothing special (3/5)

15) Horse hair crab w/ crab miso & ikura: Crab envelopes all your senses thanks to the crab butter. Very compact and smooth texture
16) Hokkaido Uni "taco": Everything was sweet, even the seaweed.
17) Bluefin w/ caviar & gold: Almost like melted butter. Very few tendons so it was extra smooth
18) Sea eel w/ sansho: Leaner saltier flavors. Slightly gritty
19) Wagyu: Extra peppery (which I love) but still has a chew. Imagine the best burger you've ever had condensed into one tiny bite. Amazing
20) Seafood egg: Like cross between egg and and cake. Salt & sweetness both very prominent.
21) Cherry blossom tiramisu: 1 of 2 dessert options. Wasn't a huge fan of the hard candy on top. A bit too sweet for me but interesting (3/5)
22) Panna Cotta: 2nd dessert option of the night. Good but standard (3.5/5)
23) Housemade Chocolate: A nice little extra for the end of the meal.

Overall my friend and I both really loved our meal. Everything was tasty, intricate, and unique. Price was also better than Omakase and overall taste was better too. Would definitely come back.
author: Vivian C.

description: Returned here 2.5 years later, and the sushi here has SIGNIFICANTLY improved from before. Perfect rice with just the right amount of vinergary acidity, well prepared fish, and a great attention to detail. They're very welcoming and I really enjoyed my meal here.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Came here for my birthday a few days ago and I'm absolutely in love :)

I'm not an expert in sushi but have tried quiet a bit of places for omakase. What really distinguished this place from other omakase places for me is really the combination of the freshness of the fish and the sauce pairing. I really loved their in house plum sauce which went with some of the nigiri pieces I had and it was absolutely amazing.

I was so full at the end of the night but was still craving the food the next day. Their Sake selection have some pretty good choices and are not marked up double or triple the price. The overall experience I had here on my birthday was just outstanding. 

Let the photos talk ;)
author: Sunny C.

description:
Wako, my sincerest apologies for hating on you for the last three years. But seriously, when I last came here in 2014, I didn't feel like the menu tasting, ambiance, and/or food quality was at the level of a Michelin Star restaurant (or the hype!). 

Fortunately, my BFF forces me to be more open-minded, and at the recommendation of 3 other friends, I FINALLY decided to give Wako another try tonight. And man, have you guys grown! 

First of all, we sat at the bar in front of the head chef. I had bad flashbacks of the awkward dinner here three yrs ago, but it was quickly dispelled with the humorous and attentive head chef. We quickly went over dietary restrictions and preferences. He noticed the BFF was left-handed and made the necessary serving adjustments (served her nigiri facing the other way), and checked in on us throughout the course of our tasting.

There's 2 tiers (9 course for $90ish and 11 course for $120ish). We went with the 9 course, but ended up adding in two more pieces of nigiri...which equated to the same price as the 11 course anyways. The servers were extremely knowledgeable about each item being presented. You'd think this would be the case at every restaurant, but it's not true. Plus, they quickly refilled our teas throughout the night, never allowing it to get past lukewarm. 

Wako, you've won me back over. Michelin Star well deserved. Tax and tip included, came out to $150pp. 5 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
One of the best Japanese sushi places in San Francisco. The omakase is not cheap but a good value for money that couples a good mix of prepared food and sushi.

There is also a good sake list w good bottles that run the spectrum of prices. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Ian C.

description:
A meal for two people at this restaurant cost us about $300. We chose tasting menu number two and it was well worth it.

Make sure to ask to be seated at the bar. Your sushi will be made by the head chef and you will have an opportunity to interact with the chefs. 

Service is fairly quickly and staff are very friendly.
author: Tony F.

description:
We went here with my wife's cousin and bf.  

We all got the omakase but I thought it was good but not great.

I think that some of the sushi we got wasn't as impressive as we would've thought.

Same for the creativity, it was nothing special for the price point that we paid.

I would say that it's worth checking out but not sure  I would do it again.
author: Will C.

description:
Honestly this last dining experience with Wako was such a disappointment!  I used to love love love Wako when it first opened and have recommended it to so many friends.   

The restaurant has drastically increased its price, almost doubled!  which is not a major concern to us if the quality and service meet expectation.  Perhaps this is the reason the restaurant was not full(used to be always full).  Unfortunately other than most of the nigiri, The hot dishes and desserts have became nothing but blanded taste.  Sooooo disappointing as I have always looked forward to their creative hot dishes and the pannocotta dessert.  This time the hot dishes were extremely fishy, nothing special.  The pannocotta was nothing but a few pieces of fruits topped with lime shavings...barely any mouse on bottom. 

Service, the tallest Chinese waitress was just too tired of her job.  She has been with the restaurant since it begun.  Not once she made us feel welcome.  This time was even worse.  She brought our dessert and said:"someone's birthday?" We said "yes". She then quickly sprinkled some birthday sparkles, said "happy birthday" then walked away like wind.  I am not exaggerating, who thing was about 2 seconds!!! OMG!!!! If it was sooo much of an obligation for you to say a heartless congrats...please don't do it to ruined our mood!!!  

One nice thing worth mention was there's a Japanese waitress, we think she is new, and has always carried a very sweet smile each time she came to our table. Which was pleasant.

Value....totally not worth it like it used to be. $360 without any drinks for 2 with this type of service, and not so wow food, not worth it!
author: Kelly L.

description: I dont eat a lot of Omakase Japanese but so far I think this is the best one I had. The rice tasted so good. We sat on the counter watching chefs action. Chefs and staffs there are very friendly. Overall my experience there is awesome!
author: Lori T.

description:
I came here to celebrate my anniversary with the boy. I had been scouring lists after lists trying to find something quiet, intimate but high quality food when I stumbled upon Wako. 

The interior is pretty small and the decor is nature/minimal. We opted for the grand omakase which I feel like was a greater "value" for the food we received. If we had gone with the regular menu, we would have probably ordered extra or the same amount of money as a grand omakase. I prefer my sashimi on the buttery side so I preferred the later half of the menu. I never knew sweet shrimp or sea eel could taste this good. Out of the entire menu, we ordered an extra order of sea eel. It's $12/piece but it was worth it. The A5 wagyu beef didn't even taste like beef. Just pure goodness. 

Service from the server could have been a little better but having the chef in front of us was a nice treat. I would definitely recommend this restaurant for special occasions. 

For the Toto toilet lovers, they have one in the bathroom!
author: Lily Z.

description:
Yes. Of all the Michelin omakases I've ever had, Wako is my favorite. I've been here a few times for omakase and just dinner. The atmosphere is intimate, clean and pretty. The service is ninja like in the sense that they attend to your needs quickly and quietly. The fish is fresh (obviously) but my favorite part is how different it is every time I go. It's like real omakase where the chef actually just gives you the best that's available. That means in-season and they need to recreate and season pieces according to what is the best available. Each nigiri is creatively prepared and then they mix in a few kaiseki courses for a nice balance. 

I sometimes feel kaiseki courses are included to fill stomach space or skimp on quality but not here. The kaiseki courses are just as interesting and deliciously made with quality and rare ingredients. The price ($95 or $135 pp) especially for a Michelin in sf, is very reasonable and probably adds to why I love it so much. Wako is my personal heaven and I recommend all my fellow sushi aficionados go!
author: Naomi K.

description:
Such an exquisite experience! The restaurant is small with pleasing decor, attentive staff, and even a humidifier in the bathroom.

The menu is omakase style and you can choose between the 9 course meal ($92) or the 11 course ($130). You can choose to order more nigiri later. Each course was intriguing, delicious, and plated extremely well. Their uni, blue fin tuna belly, and salmon were some of my favorites.

For a cute touch, they put a candle in my dessert and threw 'happy birthday' confetti onto the table.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Simply amazing.

Fresh, tasty, clean, simple, attentive... So many adjectives I would like to use for this restaurant, but just keep this one in mind:phenomenal.

You get two options: 2 omakase-style menus - a 9 course meal or an 11 course meal. They basically boast the same items, it just depends on how hungry you are, and how much you're willing to spend. Every single courses were wonderful. From the simple nigiri to a really a complex and interesting tofu/fish dish - you will just be amazed by the variety of food you'll be trying, by its quality, and by its perfect presentation. I personally really enjoyed every single of them. But my favorite of all was the Blue Fin Tuna Belly. Damn, that dish tasted like butter! So freaking good. 

Service was really immaculate and friendly.  Really enjoyed how the chef described every dishes! The entire staff is doing an amazing job there. Also, the bathroom has one of these typical Japanese toilet with the cleansing jet (bidet?) and a seat warmer. There's also a cool humidifier in there! 

A reservation is recommended, even necessary? Definitely a place to check out.
author: Alex L.

description:
Small restaurant so very attentive staff and chefs are very nice and kind. They are very friendly so don't be afraid to have a conversation with them. They're all super knowledgeable about the sushi and dishes they are serving. 

Wako is a omakase type style restaurant, they have a set menu and you can chose between the cheaper one or the more expensive one, either way they are both high priced so you should go for the higher priced one just to get more bang for your buck.  ($130)

All of their plated dishes were designed beautifully and made it harder to eat but they were very delicious. I recommend you try to reserve early and get bar seating because you can see the chefs make your pieces carefully. The sushi here was fresh but I feel like they added a bit too much wasabi in it for my liking. The taste of the wasabi was overpowering the fish. The highlight of the meal has got to be the dishes with uni, toro and the wagyu. 

Overall I think I would prefer to go to Kusakabe. Their grand omakase is $150 but I felt so much more satisfied there after the meal and the rice tasted more buttery without the overpowering wasabi. I also like the darker setting at Kusakabe as well, it gives it a better ambiance.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I took my bf here for his birthday and made sure to get bar seating and the 11 piece tasting. He loved it-I've never seen him happier.

The food, quality, and service were excellent. Each piece was served with an explanation and we were at the edge of our seats each time. Each bite was heavenly. 

Although it is expensive, I'd definitely recommend this restaurant for the omakase lover in your life.

They even provided a special dessert with a candle at the end to celebrate his birthday. 

On a final note, make sure to use the restroom. They have the authentic Japanese toilets that I'm afraid to use correctly, haha.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Girl date = $92 9-course omakase

Wako has been on the to-try list for longer than I can remember. 1-Michelin star Japanese restaurant just a few miles away? Yes, sign me up.

However, if you only have time and money for a single 1-Michelin star Japanese restaurant, then please head over to Wakuriya. That was much more impressive experience. Wako is a bit more traditional.

Anyway, my favorite course here was the second, the appetizer platter with 6 different items: oyster with caviar, sesame tofu (OMG OMG OMG so good!!!), eggplant with mini anchovies, tartare, cream cheese thing (another fantastic bite), and croquette. Everything on this plate was great.

Even though I saw it on the menu, I still felt surprised by the amount of nigiri sushi (8 pieces) and sashimi (separate course) there was. Basically half of the meal was sushi or sashimi and these pieces just tasted average to me. During the sushi course, they hand out menus for you to add additional pieces if you are still hungry. Looking at the menu made me realize how overpriced each piece of sushi was, even when considering how much of the $92 price tag each piece of sushi made up. It was not a pleasant feeling.

I did like the steamed egg custard dish as well. The meal ended with two dessert choices: chocolate mousse or lychee peach. It turned out that both were similar in texture and served in little bowls. They served as a good finale.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Here u can see .
Good quality and good service 
Very comfortable environment 
And ... nice staff 
Thanks for your service and 
Amazing food 
Not need reservation 
Just go. For it.
author: Mr.Gong X.

description:
At some point in your life you find yourself staring at a piece of sushi with a sizeable lump of caviar and gold leaf on top of it, and you think "haha GOSH this is pretty over the top" or "what sushi could possibly deserve to be this extra." And so you take the obligatory photo of it, just to document the extravagance of it all, and about ten seconds later you're SO GLAD YOU DID because it's now the only tangible reminder you have of the rapidly fading memory of the best sushi you've ever had.

I mean, that was my deal, anyway. It feels preeeetty great to walk away from a meal knowing that you tasted every damn dollar that you paid for it, and this was one of them. I cannot even pretend to be a sushi connoisseur by any stretch of the imagination - this was just mind-blowingly good food, presented beautifully, and paired with some pretty killer sake. I found myself immediately patting myself down looking for even the thinnest excuse to come back, and I spent a week being That Annoying Friend who wouldn't shut up about the insanely good gold sushi she had. If you have the opportunity, absolutely treat yourself. Start to finish, just perfect.
author: Claire H.

description: Every bite was a beautiful piece of art and very delicious.  I recommend having the sake pairing with the omakase to complement the amazing dining experience. I loved how the environment wasn't too formal like other Japanese restaurants. A great place for a birthday dinner.
author: Misch R.

description:
Tl;dr Fantastic omakase course with fresh fish, delicious flavors, and a great progression.

We got the $95 course, which came with a starter, appetizer, 10 nigiri, warm dish, miso soup, and dessert. Every course was expertly made, and complemented each other very well.

We really enjoyed the selection of small dishes in the appetizer, especially the oyster, the ankimo crostini, and the marinated cheese with cherry tomato. 

Every piece of nigiri was perfectly seasoned, and the texture and flavors were so spot on, we just had to order 4 more each a la carte!

Service and ambience were also very good, our experience made for the perfect early Valentine's dinner. Wako is now the top of our list of favorite sushi spots!
author: Jeff C.

description:
Was so excited but it wasn't the omakase I expected to be. Way more plated dishes than sushi/nigiri. Which I haven't experience before in the states and in Japan. The chef was great though, he is from Japan and very knowledgeable. The staff was good and the restaurant is clean. I'm sad that not one piece blew my mind. Don't get me wrong, it was good and fresh but wasn't $130 good. 

My friend took me here for my birthday and we did pick the $130 omakase. I was super excited but left a little disappointed. Maybe my expectation were too high because it is a Michelin Star restaurant? I was when it came down to the last few pieces, such as the waygu and toro it would be amazing but it wasn't, and didn't melt in my mouth. The beef was pretty chewy. Overall experience was okay but not my favorite.
author: Sandy B.

description:
95% DELICIOUS. Came here for my bday and went with the $120 per person omakase option plus sake pairing. The nigiri potions of the meal were my favorite, especially the pike mackerel (seasonal), sea eel, seared scallops, and toro. The cooked food was tasty with very clean traditional flavors. 

Some reviewers mentioned that they use a lot of shiso and yuzu-- I thought this was true, but I really enjoyed the flavors and didn't think they were overpowering.

The only thing I was REALLY disappointed by was the sea urchin, which I almost gagged on bc it was SO funky. I usually love sea urchin and this was the first time I've ever felt such a strong negative reaction. It was so memorably bad that I have to take off one star. :(  My SO, who also loves sea urchin (and yes yes he is a good lover) had the same negative response.
author: Jean L.

description:
Wako is in my top three favorite omakase spots in san francisco. Every nigiri piece has its own unique combination of flavors where the sauces arent overpowering. 

The chef was very adept and informative on all the dishes he prepared from us. This is actually one of the few places I see that you can get firefly squid (one of the best spot for it too). Usually when you think of squid, you think of a chewy texture but the firefly squid was tender. I was amazed because it had a pop of flavors that oozed out once i bit into it. The uni here was vibrant in color and had a deep creamy flavor. 

Service was also impeccable. Whenever I got up, the staff would always fold up my napkin. Everyone was friendly and i have to say, Wako is definitely worth its price point.
author: Timothy C.

description: Amazing dinner tonight at Wako! We were celebrating a special occasion and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves here, where we were served a delicious omakase by the owner, Chef Tomo, with a very inventive, flavorful focus. The setting was simple, intimate, and warm. The highlights of our nigiri / sushi courses were the soft and fluffy eel, fatty tuna (with caviar and gold leaf!), uni "taco", and seared scallop. I'm looking forward to coming back!
author: Carmela A.

description: Delicious! Sushi was among the best I've had and service was attentive and unpretentious. Left stuffed but wishing I could fit more in my tummy.
author: Peace M.

description:
Another Omakase added to the books. My bf and I have been obsessed with eating at Omakase places for special occasions and this is where he chose to take me for my birthday this year. We chose the larger omakase option because why the heck not?! I was full after the first 3 courses but devoured each piece after that and even order another piece off the ala carte! 

I loved everything, but my favorites would have to be the Salmon Toro with caviar, A5 Waygu and the Stripe Jack.

Sitting at the bar is a must, so I highly suggest making that a request when booking your reservation. It's such a different experience sitting at the bar vs the tables.
author: Lena V.

description:
Oh dear god...this place! Heaven in each bite...celebrated my friends birthday here, and omg was this the best decision we ever made in our lives! Everything about Wako is outstanding. Once in a lifetime experience, I can't wait to go back perhaps before the end of the year..maybe for my own birthday this time lol
My friend loved it, I highly recommend Wako. The decor, the service, ambiance...felt so soothing and relaxing. And of course there was the food...oh Just the quality of the fish and the presentation, the way they timed each course. Just outstanding.
author: Patricia H.

description:
Everything about this place is truly amazing. When they say traditional Japanese cuisine, they mean it. The last time I tasted sushi this good and authentic was back in Japan. This place is pricey, but that's what you get for quality. My date and I got the 9 course omakase for $92 and we had room to spare when we were finished (but that's what the drive thru is for right?). From a fish stand point, Wako is more about the sushi experience (the rice to fish ratio, the combination of flavors, the order in which the food is served). So if you came here for good, real sushi, you came to the right place.

Service here is top notch. Attentive, knowledgeable and calm, they really payed attention to our table and the pace we ate. We also ordered hot sake and the presentation was beautiful (not to mention practical since it actually kept our sake warm). The ambiance is also very charming and contemporary, but space here is SMALL. There was only seating at the bar and a couple tables available (which can't accommodate more that a dozen people or so) in the entire restaurant. Talk about exclusive. Important note: get reservations! Parking here is also a troublesome issue. You're only chance is street parking (you'll eventually find something, even if it's three block away)

Food wise, the 9 course omakase included everything from multiple appetizers, grilled dishes, nigiris, soup and desserts. Every fish that they served included where the origin of fish came from (ie. Spain, Japan, ect). My personal favorite was the Uni but if you're not a sea urchin fan, pass it along because this has all that seafood-y goodness. My date's favorite part of the night was the Wagyu beef (which my vegetarian self had to hand over to him). Pace yourself, because you're not just enjoying your meal, but you're enjoying the experience. I thoroughly loved it here, and while I can't dine like this every night, it was for sure a treat.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Had a combo Valentines & Chinese New Year dinner here, and it definitely rose to the occasion.

The appetizer plate was very interesting (and certainly good!) in that you had to eat them in a particular order to harness the most taste. The soup and hot entrees were great as well.

But the star of the show was definitely the sushi made by Chef Tomo-San. He takes great care in making your sushi and some of them will literally melt in your mouth. Exquisite.

Overall a great experience (bar seating was a plus), and definitely recommended!
author: Yuqing N.

description:
I've tried a couple Japanese restaurants that have omakase dining, and Wako is by far the best quality for what you pay. It deviates from traditional omakase dining in the sense that you have other non-sushi options that go with your courses. For example, I loved that the baked salmon with roe. Each dish was also creative in its own way, and left your taste buds raging and wondering what it would taste next.

I sat at the bar, and talked a little bit with the sushi chef. He was very friendly and explained each course in detail (e.g. the type of fish, where the fish was from, etc)

One of my favorite Michelin star restaurants I've been too. This place is on the rise, and I have expect it to continue to become more popular
author: Avery B.

description:
My first time trying Omakase and Wako did not disappoint at all!

First and foremost, their service was A++! Everyone was so sweet and attentive. We came here to try the 9 course Omakase and honestly did not know what to expect. What we had throughout the entire night WOW-ed us and we are not holding our Omakase standards very high. 

Let's see if I can remember everything/course we had (sorry, this will most likely not be in order):
- starters
- appetizer (six mini items)
- 2 nigiris (tuna, and 1 other fish)
- steamed egg
- 4 nigiris (scallops, white squid, and 2 other fish)
- steamed dish
- 4 nigiris (wagyu beef, sea urchin, mackerel, 1 other fish)
- Miso soup (go with the red one because the white one, you can get at any other Japanese restaurant) 
- 2 Desserts

They placed a candle on my friends dessert because it was her birthday. It was such a wonderful experience!
author: Eva O.

description:
I guess I will not come back to this place anymore, I have been to so many Japanese restaurant and as usual I like to seat at the sushi bar to enjoy the nigiri processing.  For so many sushi bars I have been to, when the chef wants to sneeze most of the chef will step down the sushi bar or covering their mouth, turn around then wash their hand before touching the fish again, but except for wako.  The sushi chef stand still at the same spot with left hand holding a piece of sashimi and right hand holding a knife just blended down and sneezed.  Continue with the sushi making after the sneezed........???!   Omg, can't believe I saw this happening at a Michelin stars restaurant, really have no comment for that.....!

On the fish, it's fresh, but wako is the only omakase I have been to with 95% of the nigiri are either cover with seasonings / different kind of sauces.  Every bite of the sushi that I have were full of taste, but mostly taste the seasonings or sauces not a bit of the fish itself.  I wonder if I can only taste the seasonings or sauces what's the purpose to spent this money for omakase?
author: Cora L.

description:
My friend took me here for my birthday and I loved it! Small intimate place.

We ordered the 11 course meal and I was definitely super full after (of course I didn't come here starving though) I thought the price was decent as well.

Everyone from the waiters/waitress and chefs were all really polite and attentive. Water always filled, didn't really wait long for each course. Sitting at the bar was really fun. We got to see what the chef was making for us and he was really passionate about the food.

All the fish was AMAZING. Tasted so fresh and buttery. I tried a lot of things I've never had before and liked every single one. There is a good mixture of cooked foods as well as the nigri. They have a menu in front of you so that you can reference it (and order more if you wanted after the meal) but of course they explain what everything is to you.

I would definitely come back again! Definitely a happy customer.
author: Allison S.

description:
What a lovely dining experience. While I have had TONS of sushi in my life, ranging from cheap-ish to expensive and reservation required, this was actually my first foray into a full on Omakase. Many people have detailed what goes into the meal so I won't delve into all of the details but here are some highlights and notes. 

The service is immaculate. Very attentive yet perfectly paced, they pay close attention to how slow or fast you're eating and bring the dishes at a good speed. My date and I went with the 9 course and I really enjoyed every component. We ordered a hot sake and it came in the coolest case that kept it warm and felt fancy. 

All of the fish was insanely fresh. It had the cleanest most pure taste imaginable and sometimes was very surprising. The tuna felt richer and more fatty than I'm used to and the salmon was leaner and tougher than I expected. It flipped some of my assumptions based on where the fish was caught and how it was treated. Without a doubt one of the best bites was the seared scallop - so succulent and beautiful. 

I was a bit disappointed that the nearly $100 fixed meal didn't include the Waygu beef nigiri but we had try it and each got a piece at $12 a pop. Not something I would do all the time but worth it for a celebration. 

The most underwhelming part of the meal were the deserts, both of which I thought were just okay. To be fair that's not why I'm there at all and there's always ice cream at home. Bonus fun fact: the bathroom is insanely cool. Heated toilet seat and nice design really helped elevate this small unpretentious restaurant to a great level.
author: Sean S.

description: Loved it, everything about this omakase experience. However, I always compare every experience with Sasaki, and this is a close second!
author: Kim I.

description:
An early V-Day dinner at Wako Japanese Restaurant was an entirely lovely surprise. I grew up hanging out in the Sunset, and am more familiar with the local pizzeria & ice cream shop, not a Michelin-starred omakase joint.

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Reservations are, in fact, required. It's always funny and sad seeing a young couple walking in for a casual dinner and finding out that seats aren't left open
~ A sake pairing is offered with your omakase for $80+, which not a soul was doing the night we went
+ Omakase comes as a 9-course ($92) or 11-course ($130) menu, depending on how hungry you are. We opted for the luxurious 11-course menu, and were completely blown away
+ The sake menu is diverse and full of quality options. I highly recommend ordering a full bottle, then after dinner making your way to the bookstore down the street to do some damage!
~ Parking can be tricky in this area, so come early to be safe

PRO TIP:
- Don't be that guy who brings a DSLR, sits at the sushi bar with his date, and tries to document every single piece (or attempts to Snapchat it all, moment by moment). Learn to live in the moment a little bit.
author: Claire S.

description:
4.5/5 stars. Mostly -0.5 for a service issue that shouldn't have happened at a Michelin-stared restaurant, but the entire meal was wonderfully crafted and worth it for the price. I went for my dad's birthday, and we all chose the $92/9-course Omakase. I would definitely recommend this restaurant over Kusakabe in the Financial District.

[Food]
The nigiri used in the 9-course omakase was pretty standard, but I felt full at the end. I actually enjoyed the Mushimono (steamed egg) the most. Given that I normally hate steamed egg, I was surprised how I fell in love this dish. It was fluffy and didn't taste like egg at all. We also ended up ordering the Wagyu and Uni nigiri pieces as add-ons at the end, and both of these off the a-la-carte menu were fresh and flavorful. 

[Service / Decor]
The restaurant is small, with limited bar seating and tables. There was only one four person table. My only issue with my meal started at the beginning. The 4-person table ahead of me ended up sitting at the table for way longer and ran into my 8:30pm reservation (that I had made 3 weeks in advance). Given it was already so late, I wished the server had spoken up and asked the party sitting there to leave. We ended up waiting another 20 minutes before being seated. If you can, try to get a bar seat! The sushi chef is amazingly skilled and it would be fun to see him craft the pieces right in front of you. The servers explained every piece and dish that was brought out. My dad ordered the sake pairing with the omakase, and our server expertly explained each sake and its relationship to the course we were eating. 

If you can snag a reservation, I highly recommend coming to Wako to experience the sushi.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Wake delivered a very welcoming and great experience for my friends and I. We came here for a Birthday celebration and once the chef/staffs found out it was my besties Birthday, they made extra sure to make her experience 100+1%. 

Wake is a very small, cuddly place where you get to enjoy top notch Authentic Japanese Omakase. The Chefs were very friendly and ensure we were enjoying our food.

My most favorite is the fatty tuna with caviar topped with GOLD FLAKES!  The fatty tuna melts in your mouth. NO SOY SAUCE NEEDED. it will ruin the sweetness and flavor!
author: Cyndi L.

description:
For having maintained Michelin status for the past couple of years, Wako was slightly disappointing; maybe I expected more. I didn't really plan on trying Wako but it was the only restaurant in SF that still had open reservations 3 weeks prior. 

Non Nigiri Dishes were delicious!

I've had better Nigiri in Socal what really stands out is the non nigiri dishes. They had an Steam Egg dished that had a gelatin soup on top with wonder surprises inside. 

Unique dishes like Baby Sea Eel (They sometimes explain it as Baby Seal so you'll be like WTF?)

Their black cod was also delicious. I can see where Wako received the 1-star however its the same reason why they did not receive 2 stars. 

Side Note: Service and servers were on point; although I wish they smiled more. They were also really attractive lol. 

I chose the 95 dollar option and the couple next to use chose the 135. There wasn't much of a difference.
author: Anh L.

description:
I went to Wako last night eager to check another SF Michelin star restaurant off my list. I enjoyed that Wako's omakase meal was more than just pieces of nigiri but was more like a multi-course kaiseki meal that included things like small bites and soup. There was definitely a good variety of interesting dishes served. 

If I'm being completely honest though, a lot of what I was served wasn't exactly my cup of tea. Don't get me wrong though. It was all done well! But I'm pretty sure there's no way any chef will ever be able to prepare cod milt in a way that will make me crave it. (Cod milt is fancy code word for cod sperm. Yes, you read that right. Sperm. What.) I'm also personally not a fan of baby eels swimming in egg yolk, abalone, monkfish liver, or firefly squids. Again, this is all personal preference. I'm sure everything was done well. I'm just kind of picky sometimes. :/

The service was great though! It basically felt like there was a 1:1 ratio of diner:staff which was definitely noticeable. My napkin slipped off my lap three times (every time an accident!) and each time it was replaced quickly and with a smile. 

Would I recommend Wako? Yep. It's a unique and interesting meal. Would I go back? Mmm... probably not. I like to try new things but this meal was a bit too adventurous and there are still too many other fancy omakase restaurants in SF that I need to try!
author: Charles L.

description:
This was our first time at a Japanese Michelin and it exceeded my expectations and then some. I could probably write an entire book on the flavors of each item we tried tonight, but I'll try to keep it short. 

We went with the 9-course omakase, which came with 16 different items, including a variety of appetizers, grilled dish, six types of nigiri, miso soup, and two types of desserts. You have the option to add on nigiri or a few kitchen items after the sashimi round, so we added on grilled calamari and the wagyu beef nigiri. 

Every single item was unique and satisfying in its own way. My standout nigiri were the six-hour smoked Scottish salmon, torched scallop, and Wagyu beef. The uni with salmon roe was delectable and the warm egg custard was perfect. I liked everything in their own way and I wish I could eat like that every night! 

The service was on point as expected. We were sat at the sushi bar, which made for a tight space for servers to bring and take away plates but also allowed for an amazing experience, being able to watch the sushi chefs in action. Everyone was polite and patient, describing every ingredient on each plate, much like our past experiences at other Michelin restaurants. 

I am so glad we got to experience Wako fresh off their first Michelin star. If you're looking for a way to start off your Michelin journey at a reasonable price (compared to others), Wako is by far the best choice.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Delicious, I loved it.
I was amazed by that Japanese food could be so mellow and full-flavored, divine would be the word to describe their food!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
You know...maybe a year or two ago, this would've been one of, if not, the best spot for sushi in SF.  There have just been so many gosh darn gems opening up that places like wako kinda get lost in the madness.  This place was honored one Michelin star and I believe it is Michelin star worthy.  4.5 stars for me though.  

We sat at the bar...which is a must if you come here.  You get to interact with the sushi chef and see your nigiri made first hand.  The guy we had was extremely knowledgeable, friendly, and very tactful with his skills.

So you have a choice between the 9 or 11 course omakase.  I say go all out and get the 11 although it is around $40 more.  But hey, if you're here, you might as well try everything you can.  You get more traditional items here ranging from nigiri to grilled items to soup.  

The fish is fresh.  Most of it comes straight from Japan.  So why fall short of 5 stars?  I just thought the way they prepared their nigiri fell slightly short to other places that I have tried.  The wow factor wasn't as strong as some of the other spots in the city.  

Otherwise, it was a fantastic experience and a must try if you're on the hunt to try some of the city's best.
author: Jen W.

description:
Traditional & intimate. 

We had the 11 course ($130/person) omakase. We made a reservation for two a month ahead. Traditional is the first word that comes to mind - there was no music and all the focus was on serving quality fish with top-notch service. We sat at the sushi bar where watching the chef prepare our nigiri added so much to our appreciation for the craftsmanship of what we ate.

We visited Kusakabe earlier this year but knew this would be a slightly different experience. Their philosophies are different despite both being omakase-focused. I would imagine Wako to be the traditional omakase that you find in Japan. Kusakabe is a bit more experimental and uses slightly less traditional ingredients for their nigiri. 

My favorite nigiri piece was the squid with uni, lime zest, and freshly grated wasabi! Aside from nigiri, the omakase also included tempuras, miso soup (white or red), and beautifully-plated appetizers.
author: Jenn H.

description: We got the $135 Omakase. Honestly it didn't really wow me too much. The sushi wasn't moist enough and there wasn't sauce on some of the sushi which made them taste bland and dry (I am sure that is not how it was served if it was from another fancy Omakase place). I expect more and it did disappoint me quite a bit given the yelp review is very high.
author: Rebegi G.

description:
I had been searching for a great omakase restaurant for my anniversary. And I took chefs feed's advice. So glad I did.

I made reservations here, about 3weeks in advance of my anniversary. It was easy to make an online reservation. I specified online that I wanted a bar seat. They called to confirm my reservation and they already gave me the bar seats. GREAT. This is a really small place, its very intimate, focus is definitely on the food. 

Saying "fresh" for every piece of sushi we had here doesn't do it any justice. Of course it's friggin fresh. Lol. Every piece of fish had a very distinct flavor, some fish I never even heard of. But every bite triggered an MMMMMM reaction from me. Everything that was served was so damn good. My favorites though was definitely the uni, the toro, the Wagyu, the sashimi. Delicious, delicious, delicious. Also, paired with a bottle of Sake, it was all a wonderful meal.
author: josephine v.

description: Constantly solid 5 star sushi every time I'm there; very fresh fish, great attentive service, and I don't have to wait in line! The hand wraps are always big and stuffed full of fish or lobster (depending on what I order). They sure don't skimp on the portions!
author: Mei W.

description:
Amazing sushi! We went for the upgraded omakase for $130 and it is worth every penny. Might as well go all out when you'll be spending anyway, right?

Reservations are pretty easy to get on OpenTable. But, be sure to commit or else you get charged $92/pp and if you're late they give up your table. 

Our server was very knowledgeable, especially while going over the sake tastings. At the end of the meal, I was very full and satisfied! 

I'll definitely be back :)
author: Janet H.

description:
As of the moment of this review, the best sushi meal and experience I've ever had. This may change, but this one Michelin star restaurant is my current champion. (Disclaimer: I haven't eaten a lot of nice sushi so take it for what it's worth)

The restaurant is quaint, featuring a few tables and a small sushi bar. The storefront is unassuming so you may pass it by. You will require a reservation. And as of Nov 2016, they strictly serve their omakase menu. 

Food: 
We opted for their 9-course option at $92 and added their house hot sake for $21 in lieu of the $80 sake pairing. The price is quite reasonable compared to other spots. Every course was better than the previous. A seaweed bite, various appetizer bites, sashimi, two sushi courses, grilled mackerel, egg, soup, and dessert. I love how they provided a tiny finger towel to clean your fingers so that you can use your fingers to eat the sushi, the way it's intended to be eaten. The absolutely best part was their lychee champagne dessert. It is literally the best thing I've ever eaten. This is not to take away from the rest of the meal, the sushi was top notch. That dessert was just something special. 

Service: 
Cannot get any better. The waitresses were so sweet and attentive. Each course was described in detail and dropped and picked up so timely. 

Detail:
We enjoy the small stuff that don't really matter to most. The chopsticks were double sided and smooth to the touch. Very nice. The hot sake comes in a container type thing that keeps it hot. They give a lot of ginger to cleanse the palette. 

We would 100% return to this place. It was such an incredible experience. We really felt bad for not thanking the sushi chefs. They are masters.
author: Dan P.

description:
This place is phenomenal from service to quality. Let's start with service, they had about 4 wait staff for a room that seats about 25-30 people. The staff is very attentive, polite and knowledgeable (especially about sake). It's a small room that is comfortable with a friendly vibe (both diners and staff), however it was not too loud, simply enjoyable. There were two sushi chef and lead chef is Tomo. He was approachable and very accommodating. 

Despite the amazing staff and food, we have another reason why we will return. As soon as we sat at the bar and began our first course, we had an emergency with our dogs. At that moment, the staff gave us privacy and few minutes to sort out our situation. My husband had to leave the restaurant for close to an hour and they still kept our spot at the bar. They also stayed late once the restaurant closed until we completed our meal since we had a late start. They did not rush us. This type of service added to our entire dining experience. We were able to fully enjoy the meal knowing that our dog situation was taken care of. 

They offer only two omakase: 9 course or 11 course and the option of sake pairing. We choose the 11 course with sake pairing.
