The restaurant was small with maybe four or five tables and a bar. It filled up quickly. For two, we decided to order the $100 omakase nigiri set. In addition to the set, there were several extra items from the chef sprinkled in with our meal. At first, I thought the pace of the meal was rather quick, with dishes coming soon after we finished the small plate/box appetizer and first 3 piece nigiri plate. I was worried I'd be hungry after! But the pace slowed down significantly after the first two. We ended up finishing our meal after two hours and felt full and satisfied.

Blue fin tuna belly with caviar and edible gold, uni with salmon roe, anago, and wagyu were some of my favorites. Really delicious and beautiful food presentation! Compared to Kusakabe and Sushi Yoshizumi, I would say Wako had the most comfortable, laid-back atmosphere. Service was also excellent. Definitely deserving of their Michelin-star, and a great place to go for birthdays or a special occasion.
author: Christina G.

description:
Recommendation of the day: Go with the 11 course for $130. It was worth every single dollar!

Pros:
- Our waitress was super friendly and clearly articulate every single course to us. She also made a great recommendation to pair her favorite sake with our courses. 
- Presentation of each course was nice. #takeitforthegram
- My favorite was blue fin tuna with caviar and gold on top!
-It was my first time trying uni from Hokkaido and it was creamy and taste pretty fresh. 
- Wagyu beef nigiri was tender!

Cons:
I can't think of any right now.

P.S. The 11 courses option was really filling but if you want more then you can order a coupe pieces of their nigiri. 

Also, you'll need to make a reservation at least 45 days ahead to find a good time during the weekend/holidays.

I have tried Wako, Omasake and Warikuya within one week apart of each other and Wako is definitely my first pick then it'll be Warikuya.
author: Linda L.

description:
I was super impressed by Wako. After having tried multiple high-end sushi restaurants in SF such as Kusakabe, ju-ni, Akiko, and more, I think Wako is almost as good as it gets in the city, barring my gold standard: Kusakabe.

I would highly recommend you try their two omakase options: $100 for 12 nigiri pieces, or $82 for a mix of hot and cold dishes, sashimi, and edomae-style nigiri. 

The space is beautiful, woodsy, and fairly small, so reservations are highly recommended. I sat at the sushi counter for a team dinner and absolutely loved all of the dishes, with my favorites being the otoro, umi masu, and the seasonal flying squid sushi. 

The presentation is artful and beautiful, and Tomo really knows his fish and rice. As he says, the rice is at least 60% more important than fish, and I couldn't agree more!
author: Kate M.

description: A bit over rated ... was so excited to try this place!!! A friend of my recommended it so didn't mind trying new places but food was kind of bland n disappointed!!!
author: Nancy W.

description:
Wako is my new fave sushi joint in the city.  I love the hipsterrific woodsy walls and the nice zenny modern lines.  Beautiful ambience.  Friendly service.  It's a small space but not claustrophobic.  

The omakase is pretty fabulous.  The nigiri has a fresh selection of fish.  The tempura is light, not drenched in oil.  The grilled oysters were tastey.  It was my first time trying a red miso.  It's super flavorful.  Highly recommend the omakase.  

The yogurt parfait dessert wasn't memorable, but the house made truffle is pretty darn amazing.  I absolutely wanted more than just one.
author: Kris H.

description:
Buh! Buh! Buh!
I been eating to teeell you,
I've got this hanger that wooon't subside!
I eat at you and I! Faaantasize!
I'll dine tonight!
Now I've! Got you ooon my plates,
Wiiith theeese,
Omaaakaseee!
One bite of you & I can't run away! I've got,
Omaaakaseee!
I taste the magic between you & III!

(*_*) 2nd Omakase $50? (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=BrGH1aH9Rjfl3GDhWNi41A)
(^_^) 1st Omakase $60? (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=OOYCTSyB2KbSsyhSBamUFg)
(^_^) Iced Oolong $3 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=ghy26UvH0vPhkBR9TGj8iQ)
(-_^) Raw Squid $4 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FCYvP693E7RBDSWuYoWtXQ)
(-_^) Chocolate Bite $0 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=T493YObXm5b21Cx4pAoodQ)
(-_-) Raw Oysters $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=NCfKqPTt8kb_tM3atFZbDQ)
(-_-) Natto Handroll $7 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=b5NffZPZOlywdD5eiykM6w)

I need you to eeeaaat!
This dindin was meant to be!
:: supersick saxophone solo ::

The Sealife Wakoatic With Flave Soyssouce was even more melt-in-my-mouth than other simba-it's-to-die-for omakases I've had. Gettit.
author: Dan B.

description: Probably one of the best sushi experiences we've ever had. Pricey, but worth it for a special occasion.
author: Brianna S.

description:
No joke here.
This is the real deal.  After tailgating Cherylyn N's (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg) tour of Japanese, specifically omakase,  meals, she named this as a must try destination.  With an upcoming birthday for my pescatarian friend, I made an early weeknight dinner reservation in early December.  A tad late due to the horrendous City traffic from downtown, we were seated at the rear table near the kitchen.  The dining room, comprising of around six tables, was 2/3rd full while the sushi bar was fully occupied.  The menu is pretty simple with an extensive selection of sushi, sashimi, and small plate choices.  There are three omakase menus: a nigiri sushi and sashimi exclusive one, nigiri only, and a seven course mix of these with cooked and raw small plates; we chose the latter.  
Being exhausted from the hectic journey here, I wasn't fully focused on itemizing our courses, given the wide variety of fish in various sashimi and nigiri form. 
Here is a summary of the various offerings in our meal:

The two specials on the menu were the striped jack (sashimi) and the golden eye snapper. 
Yellow tail baked apple and scallop bites were delicious as well as the fish cake tempura, as a different take.  The nigiri offerings included salmon, scallop, and yellow tail as one course and saba, king crab, and otoro as another course.  
Wanting to explore a bit more, I added yellowtail dumplings as a supplement.
We were offered the option of red or white miso soup (I had the red).  
The dessert was not memorable except that it was topped with a chestnut.

The restaurant is not very large and the tables are pretty close together so hope you aren't shy about sharing conversations.  I tried to add the abalone as another supplement, but they had another party waiting for our table so will save it for next time.
The consensus from my other Yelp friends who've reviewed this place is a rousing five stars (4.5 by Cherylynn, but rounded up).
Just don't walk in here expecting a budget dinner or, as Ken K. dubs, "jive ass rolls" (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA) or bento boxes.  Prepared to be transported to Japan.  Sorry, still have yet to go, but, from what I've read....
author: Mike C.

description:
Phenomenal. Period. Needless to say, the sushi was fresh and delicious.  But I think the service at the sushi bar was what just put the cherry on top.  Our chef was very friendly. He mastered the "have enough banter with customer while making sushi to make them feel welcomed but not enough to over power/hinder customers' experience" - if you catch what I mean.   Our server was astute, agile, and personable.  And together, they really made the customers feel comfortable. According to our chef, anago (salt water eel) is Wako's specialty and was most definitely my personal favorite at Wako.  My husband loved the otoro (fatty tuna) and wagyu beef as well.  

The aesthetic of the restaurant is minimal and clean - quintessentially Japanese.  The wood provides a warmth, while the steel and concrete/tile keeps the place feeling understated and allows you to focus on the food.  The floral arrangements were beautiful and also provided subtle, colorful accents to the interior. 

Definitely will be back when in SF~
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Me and my wife went here for our anniversary. Before I get into the sushi I want to talk about something more than sushi. Which is what I believe this place to be. They made it personable. To have such an amazing selection of fish is one thing but to elevate it through service is elevating them completely beyond any other restaurant. Thank you for making mine and my wife's night of celebration more wonderful. 

Now the fish:
Yes!!! Everything was crafted to perfection. I enjoyed hearing about each cut and it's preparation as we ate it. Savoring each bit and missing it once devoured. My faves would have to be the scallop, the Alaska salmon, the blue find tuna (bam!!! This one mind blowing worth it), and the Wagu!!!!! OMG! I can't wait til we come back, and we will.
author: Attic F.

description: We opted for the $92 for 9 course with an additional nigri at the end. Food came out fresh, fast and steady. I changed my mind after we were a few courses in and wanted to do the 11 course instead but it wasn't possible due to a few items on the 9 not available on the 11, so don't change your mind midway. Positive experience overall.
author: Trammi N.

description: Almost one to one service and attention. Michelin star fresh. Atmosphere 4.5 out of 5.0
author: Ryan K.

description: Came here for my husband's birthday, totally worth the 5 star rating. We got the 11 course omakase ($130), each dish has so much thoughts put into it that you just want to eat every detial of them. Everything tastes good. Also really liked their house hot sake, very rich flavor. Excellent service, they even brought out small desert with candle when they found out that I was my husband's birthday. Recommend for special occasions.
author: Tia T.

description:
RIDICULOUS! Not the food but the parking! I guess it comes with the territory! Parking on Clement can be insane especially during peak dinner hours. Be prepared to circle the block multiple times as even an illegal space was hard to come by!

Décor is typically Japanese with judicious usage of modern plank-wood on the walls, wooden furnishings and a pretty sushi bar. The vibe was chic and contemporary and more importantly, giving the restaurant a clean look.

As we wanted to try a good cross section of the menu, we opted for a table.

SUSHI:  Wako is high-end. I savored each piece of fish in one mouthful with slow, deliberate bites, as there would be no reruns. Breathe in the pristine freshness, relish how each piece was delicately seasoned and sauced by the chef and notice the textural difference between each fish. Close your eyes if you must lest you might be distracted! Ala Carte nigiri prices are steep. The menu prices are priced per piece, not a pair and you can spend a pretty penny in a hurry! 

Here's a low down of today's nigiri specials and every fish was divine!

1. Hirame (Halibut $6) : a very popular white fish with light and delicate flavor.
2. Shima Aji (Striped Jack $6) : delicious, like a cross between kanpachi (amber jack) and hamachi.
3. Kamasu (Japanese Baracuda $6) : like hirame, it was soft, juicy and light.
4. Kinmedai (Golden Eye Snapper $8) : its texture was not too soft or too crunchy, with a slight sweetness and not fishy.
5. Akamutsu (Rosy Sea Bass $8) : a rare find, not to be missed! A white fish that tasted like toro! (fatty tuna).

The kitchen entrees were equally glorious with some minor hiccups. Even the soy on the table was doctored for better taste. Presentation was the essence.

1. King Crab and Baby Scallop Tempura ($12), light batter and the King Crab were beyond delicious! One piece was given the "isobe" treatment using roasted seaweed (nori) for added flavor. (5/5)
2. Kaisen Chawanmushi ($9 Savory Egg Custard) made with jidori eggs (from specially raised chickens but who cares?). I appreciated the uber smoothness of the custard and the snow crab. But a dollop of uni? Didn't blend so well to my liking with egg custard! (4/5)
3. Blue Fin Tuna cheek on Hotplate (14) was just so so as I preferred my tuna raw. But this was just me! (3/5)
4. Grilled Ink Squid Legs ($8) was nicely salted and crunchy (4/5)
5. Simmered Golden Eye Snapper Head (9) was a delicacy although your cat would love it too! I would have preferred it to be served warmer (temp-wise) and was too sweet  for my liking. (2/5)
6. Grilled Sanma (pike mackerel) with Matsutake mushroom was definitely a work of art! The fish was completely deboned and the mushroom and sweet ginger complemented the umami flavors. Well done! (5/5)

This is the place to come if you are a purist seeking out authenticity and traditionality. I can see careful attention was given to every detail. The server was young, very pleasant although not quite as professional as I would have expected at a high-end place like this. All in all, we had an enjoyable evening!

Gochisosama deshita! (Thank you for the meal!)
author: Geoff G.

description:
Great service, but for the amount I was paying in terms of food, it's unfortunate that the food did not live up to the hype.

What we ordered for two: 
- house made tofu with sea urchin
- fried giant clams
- egg topped with sea urchin
- monkfish liver
- tuna cheek steak
- 5 piece nigiri
- house made green tea mochi

The tofu with sea urchin was okay in a sense that you can tell that it's house made. Very silky and there was a hint of sesame taste to it.  The giant clams were not very giant. I would not recommend it. The egg topped with sea urchin was mediocre at best. The monkfish liver also had an almost bland taste to it, even though the texture tasted like it was meant to be more creamy. I was a fan of the tuna cheek steak however! It was a very interesting dish. You can really taste both the tuna and steak to every bite. I don't remember which nigiris we got, but I know that each piece was either $9 or $10. For that amount of money for ONE piece, it was not worth it in my opinion.  I also enjoyed the green tea mochi as a dessert.
author: Janel L.

description:
3.75 STARS, but I know my next visit will be more up my alley.

I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time and am a devout omakase orderer, so I went with the 7 course (per a fellow yelper's tip and my friend wanting to try it).

Fun Fact: The 7 course omakase requires 2 people to order it. 

This place is an interior designer's heaven, super stylish with a very simplistic approach. The placemats and coasters were cool and unique, they gave the heavy wood design a nice touch of style and class.

To be honest, the non-nigiri courses were a bit mediocre. The first course was tasty though, it included some sort of seaweed or kelp and a tiny little seasonal fish that were quite tasty. The red miso is ok, it's nothing special, but it was nice to try something different. There was a red snapper with okra, brussel sprouts, and lotus root that was delicious. All the nigiri pieces were on point, the ones that stood out for me were the Hokkaido Scallop, Maguro, and Spanish Aji.

The customer service was stellar and Tomo, the owner, was very nice and welcoming. They're nearing their 1 year anniversary of being open on Clement. I'll definitely be back, because I really want to try their Nigiri Omakase,

To Be Continued...
author: Aaron C.

description: I love this place. Everything was delicious. I got the 11 course but I definitely had to order the crab with crab miso and also amaebi with uni on top. The amaebi head was also one of the best I've ever had.
author: Ricky W.

description:
What a great sushi place! I took my mom hear to experience her first omakase style dinner. We both got the 7 course omakase and we were stuffed by the end of our meal. 

All the small dishes that came before our nigiri were great. Loved the deep fried sweet fish stuffed with mushroom. I wasn't really impressed with the sashimi dish though. 

Some of my favorite nigiri of the night were: 
Toro
Ika
Scallop
Barracuda

Service was good. The servers were attentive and always came to refill our tea cups. One thing they didn't do though was tell the sushi chef of our dislikes. Our server asked us what we didn't want/like, yet she didn't tell the sushi chef and we got what we didn't want.
author: Chris K.

description:
I like weird food. Marinated raw octopus, fish collar, one-off things you don't see in other places. Especially uni. I am convinced my soul mate is out there. That one person who loves uni as much as I do, is my true soul mate, separated by time and space, he and I will never meet but if we did, in this life time, sparks would fly and we'd congregate at this restaurant and toast for the love affair of a life time. That is how I think about good food and its effect on people. Made a reservation to arrive at this nice little restaurant. The chef/owner Tomo was very friendly, he shared with us his go to dishes and his life in America. In addition, he wrote down the restaurant I must visit on my upcoming trip to Tokyo.

My favorite fish was Japanese barracuda and red snapper. Quite intriguing fish.

Modern aesthetics for a restaurant that is in the Inner Richmond district but that's where I go now for Japanese food.

By the time we finished the restaurant was filled with people.

I like fresh fish. I like small dishes. I like to think as I get to Japan, I'd visit Tomo's buddy who just opened his own shop. 

Having recently been to restaurants that were strict, it's nice to meet a friendly chef who happens to be super talented too. When I am in the mood, I enjoy socialize with the chef. That evening I was in the mood, and I was indeed entertained. Will be back for more raw sea food, and sit at the counter again.
author: Victoria E.

description: This is the 3rd Omakase restaurant I have tried in San Francisco.  Wako is good but not my #1 favorite.  The variety of fish and dishes is excellent and the presentation is very nice.  My biggest complaint is the size of the sushi.  The courses are truly bite-sized.  The servers are professional and make you feel at home.
author: T W.

description: Wako has the best sushi I've ever had in my life so far. They have really taken care of their rice and fish. Each nigiri has its own personality and it melt in your mouth as soon as you bite it. I'm usually not a fan of octopus, but the one they have doesn't have a slight of fishy smell. It was the best sushi experience I've ever had and not sure if I'll be able to eat sushi anywhere else.
author: Jing W.

description:
Came here for my mother's birthday with reservations on a weekday. The spot is pretty small, but service is great! Authentic, friendly and knowledgable servers which made our experience good. We all had the omakase and I had the Chef Omakase which is slightly more expensive than the regular omakase. However not all the fish tasted fresh, but there were many other dishes that were tasty.

The regular Omakase:
- appetizer with 4 cute mini dishes: one of my favorites of the night
- amberjack & red snapper sashimi: fresh and got me excited for the rest of the meal.
- fried fish ake and veggies with lotus veggies fried: also yum!
- baked yellowtail apple bottom and egg: unique dish and very rich in flavor
- halibut, salmon, stripe jack, and scallop nigiri: everything on this dish was good, but nothing unique in flavor.
- Tuna belly & bluefin tuna: yum
- crab and salmon roe nigiri: decent
- soups were a little too salty - both kinds
- sweet egg cake: very sweet but too full at this point to finish

The chefs Omakase:
- Barracuda, golden eye snapper, red snapper, stripe jack, giant clam: everything was decent, some had the fishy taste which I wasn't a fan of, but the snappers were my favorite on this nigiri dish
- abalone, yellowtail, gizzard, and uni nigiri: my favorite was the yellowtail and uni on this dish. Usually I'm not a fan of uni, but it was super fresh that I didn't taste the fishy/oceany taste!
- Otoro from Spain: Otoro is always super soft and melt-in-your-mouth :D
- Anago: cooked fish was tasty - mom loved it
- A5 Wagyu: Delicious as well!

They provided my mom a panna cotta dessert for her birthday which they did it pretty cute because they came with a few confetti pieces that dropped all over the dessert before placing the dessert in front of my mom. It was indeed tasty and we all ended our meals with a piece of chocolate.

The meal went from super tasty to decent which it should have kept up the tastiness, but the fish probably wasn't too good that day. It was around $355 including tax & tips for 3.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Wako was such an amazing choice for a special birthday dinner for my mister. :) I came here at the end of last September and this place has ruined other sushi bars for me ever since. Happy to say that I was able to try this before Wako got the Michelin Star ;)

I made reservations about a month in advance so that I could assure bar seating - a MUST when you are here! Not sure how much you typically would have to book in advance. Omakase is required when you sit in the bar, but what else could you possibly want? We ordered the seven course Omakase and enjoyed every bit of it. My favorites had to be the uni and the blue fin tuna belly. We loved it so much we asked for seconds on our favorite dishes! We also ordered some chawanmushi on the side - so good!

The experience here is so intimate and personal that we definitely felt spoiled. Our sushi chef walked us through each course, each piece carefully crafted. At the end of our meal we were given an extra dessert and our waitress threw some confetti on our table. 

Highly highly recommended :) so worth it
author: Tracy Joy K.

description: Unfortunately I was pretty disappointed with Wako. I booked very far in advance and was really excited. For the price it was probably one of the worse omakase I have had. It is not a normal full sushi omakase and instead they bring out small and unique plates. It was all good but nothing blew my mind. The nigiri pieces were tiny and for smaller $92 omakase option, it did not come with premium wagyu, or toro pieces. Total for four came out to almost $700 and then we went across the street to buy a pizza afterwards. Service was excellent but tiny portions and was expecting a better experience for the price.
author: David D.

description: Great service and well balanced with Nigiri, Appetizers, and Hot Dishes
author: Peter W.

description: Michelin Star? Come on, the waitresses didn't even know what they were serving me in the omakase and this place hasn't even been here long enough to set such a precedence. It's funny, I had mixed feelings when I read they got the coveted star, and then I read that Nobu, whose opinion I am usually aligned with, gave them a 2-star-- he knows his stuff, especially when it comes to Japanese. With Ino Sushi gone, and the original chefs at Maruya gone too, the SF sushi scene is going down the drains being replaced with expensive mediocracy. I'd say save your $$$$ and instead go to Japan where it's 120 yen to the dollar right now, 40% off from 2 years back, and try the real deal!
author: Brian J.

description:
their mediocre appetizers are so disappointed. The server even wouldn't let us dine in at first because of my little baby. Their worried about my baby might interfere other guest. But finally they agreed we dined with baby. There is no baby rules on their website after all. 
My baby always keeps quiet when staying in restaurant.The another reason I give Wako three star is their sushi. Some sushi which can reflect a high quality Michelin Restaurant, like Otoro Unagi, etc. didn't impress me a lot. They seemed lack freshness.
author: Haixing L.

description:
Overall, the quality of fish they served was good. 

I do not like certain fish such as eel. I asked them to switch it out and they insisted that the eel from the ocean is different and served it to me anyway. Same with squid. I wish I did not have to try it. It just reminded me how much I do not enjoy eel and squid.  

The grilled fish was overcooked. I barely ate the dish. The staff asked me if anything was wrong with the fish. When I told them the fish was overcooked, they said "I'm sorry" and walked off to the kitchen.  

Overall, because of the service and lack of flexibility, I can only give this restaurant a 3 star review.
author: Bronx P.

description:
Thank you Wako for a wonderful, top-notch dining experience!  My first visit will definitely not be my last.  Looking forward to retuning sooner than later.  I've really fallen in love this place!  I usually stay away from Clement St. bc parking is such a hassle.  For Wako, I will make the trek across town and deal with it.  It's worth it!   

The other half and I arrived at 6pm on Saturday evening, having made a reservation.  The waitress immediately lead us to the sushi bar where we met Atsushi-san and Tomo-san.  The sushi bar seats 10, making it a very intimate experience.  Throughout the service, the patrons at the sushi bar talked and toasted with Atsushi-san and Tomo-san.  They were so personable and made us laugh with their lighthearted conversations.  They introduced themselves to everyone and asked us our names.  It was a joy to watch them as masters of their craft of preparing authentic sushi by showcasing knife skills and displaying culinary creativity.  We even got to practice speaking a little bit of Japanese with Atsushi-san.      

Wako is a small space with a pleasant, modern-sheik ambiance to admire.  The wood sided and tiled walls are simple and classy.  You can appreciate the thought that was put into designing the interior.  Besides the sushi bar seating, there are small tables available as well.  

The service is impeccable.  Besides having Tomo-san and Atsushi-san taking care of all the sushi bar patrons, all of the waitresses are incredibly attentive, professional and friendly as well.  Whenever a cooked course came out of the kitchen, the waitress would go into detail on what she was serving us and teach us how to eat them.  I really appreciated the extra effort.  Our plates were removed promptly.  Our glasses were constantly being refilled even if they were still half filled.     

The other half and I wanted to try an array of what Wako had to offer, so we both ordered the 7 course omakase ($68 pp).  It included 3 small plates, 4 pcs sashimi, 1  bincho-grill, 3 tempura, 7 pcs nigiri, miso soup and dessert.  I won't go into detail about everything that we ate, but I will confirm that everything was exceptional!  In terms of quality, presentation and taste - 5 stars for sure!  I've never had such exceptional tempura.  All the cooked dishes were simply amazing.  Grade A fish selection was melt in your mouth goodness.  They also have real miso soup offered in white and red.  We tried one of each and they were equally delicious.  The omakase was filling and we certainly great value for the price.  Our total tab of 2 omakases and an order of hot sake ($15) came out to $200. 

We already plan to return to try the beef tasting course.  Next time, we'll opt to order sashimi and nigiri on the fly.  The market selection changes daily, so this will surely keep us coming back.  Also, will be happy to see Tomo-san and Atsushi-san!  Wako is a wonderful addition to the neighborhood!  I wish you continued success and hope Wako is here to stay for a long time.
author: Liv A.

description:
Wako has woken me up from my slumber of finding lackluster Japanese restaurants.
Sure my wallet took a $200 hit, but it was worth it.

Since I'm kind of a food snob, I went ahead and chose my own dishes. Like creating my own Lego creation, rather than settling for their Omakase.

Here's a rundown of what I had and my opinion, though I'm sure you know it was great since you've already seen the 5 stars.

negi-toro : Fresh and delicious

akadashi / red miso, sesame tofu, nameko, mitsuba: Tasted like a hearty broth, an acquired taste since it is red miso, but liked it nonetheless

goma dofu / house made sesame tofu: Great homemade dish

ankimo ponzu: Yummy with that delcious glaze

kaisen sunomono: Crunchy and refreshing

en chawanmushi: My favorite out of everything. Digging into the various layers was like finding edible treasure at every turn

kisetsu no kakiage: fresh but passable. I really wanted more of a shrimp tempura dish instead of a fried pancake thing.

All the sushi I bought was super fresh. I ordered one of each seasonal piece nigiri style. (See pic of the menu and of my sushi attached). Each piece was around $5-$8 and was as good as my other favorite Japanese restaurants.

The blueberry panna cotta was small, but had a good creamy texture, and a tart blueberry aftertaste. We enjoyed it immensely.

The service was great, and the teapots were cool. Steel, and each table had a different one.

Reservations strongly recommended, as we saw people getting turned away left and right.

Would I come back again?

Do fish need water?

Hell yeah!
author: Jack R.

description:
I came here a couple weeks ago without a reservation. Unfortunately they were all booked up, but one of the ladies there was nice enough to offer us a table if we could eat in an hour. Since we were there already, we thought, why not try it?! We were sat at a table. Since we only had an hour, I couldn't get the seven course omakase and settled for the four course. The roommate got the chirashi sushi. Each came with the following.

Four course ($43) - 2 small plates, 1 bincho-grill, 7 pcs nigiri and miso soup
Chirashi sushi ($36) - 1 small plate, assorted fish of the day on sushi rice, miso soup

I really enjoyed the 7 piece nigiri that came with my omakase. Each piece melted in my mouth!  And I loved that each piece has it's own sauce brushed on it! Sooo good! The small plates and bincho-grill were good as well, but I didn't love it as much as the nigiri.

The roommate wasn't really impressed with his omakase. He said the fish quality was average and the sushi rice wasn't very good. His family owns a sushi restaurant so he probably knows better than me. But he thought it wasn't worth the money. I didn't really agree with him, but we have very different tastes.

I also got a glass/cup of sake for $10. I told our server I like dry sakes and this one was perfect! I don't remember the name of the sake, but my receipt said IZUMI so I guess that's what it was called.

I really wish we had more time since I wanted to try so much more! Since this restaurant is so small, I think it would be smarter for them to not take reservations. That way they wouldn't have an empty table for over an hour waiting for a reserved party. I probably would have ordered A LOT of food if I had more time since I really wanted to try a bunch of things. But it was really nice of them to fit us in. A good 4 star experience!
author: Elena N.

description:
Wako 和香

Reservation
I called in a week before and managed a seat for 2 on a Friday night @ 7pm. Online reservations are available for tables only so I called in for sushi bar, reserved for omakase diners.

Ambiance
The restaurant is small but nice and cozy.  There's only 10 seating at the sushi bar but it was a very worthwhile experience.  I wouldn't do omakase any other way.  Atsushi-san was our main chef and he was very kind.  He told us interesting facts about each fish he chose for us and even showed us the certification for the wagyu beef (sorry calf!). Tomo-san was also very friendly and made the effort to say hello to make us feel very welcome though we were seated to the side.

Omakase
For omakase, there is the option between a 7 course meal (~$80) or the nigiri ($100) and we opted for the latter.  The nigiri omakase starts off with 4 piece appetizer, one of which was the oyster over monkfish liver, which was a very refreshing start to the meal. Then there was 12 piece nigiri with miso soup (choice between white or red miso) to finish.  Some standout nigiri were the wild yellowtail toro, ink squid, otoro, wagyu, and uni. 

1.   Wild yellowtail toro
2.   Barracuda
3.   Rosy sea bass
4.   Striped jack
5.   Ink squid
6.   Spanish blue fin otoro
7.   Wagyu beef
8.   Uni
9.   Golden eye snapper
10.  Mirugai
11.  Unagi 
12. Tamago

Sake - "Gold Blossom"
We picked up the Kinka (aka Tedorigawa Arabashiri Kinka Daiginjo Nama) to accentuate our dining experience and it was a solid choice. The Kinka is clean, smooth, fruity, and flavorful. 

Dessert
There were two flavors for dessert: (1) panna cotta and (2) chestnut mousse.  The panna cotta tasted like creamy ice cream and the chestnut mousse was flavorful. Slight preference for the chestnut mousse since it's quite a unique item.

Price
For nigiri omakase with sake, our two person bill came out to $250.

Thoughts?
Wako focuses more on the flavor from the fish and rice combined. Simply aromatic.
author: Yolanda C.

description:
Wako is the best sushi restaurant in San Francisco. Period. We had the $100 omakase and it was fantastic. It started out with a an appetizer plate and then came the chef's choice of nigiri. They were essentially all the best options on the menu--things that I hadn't tried before and the classics including salmon, tuna belly (which had gold flakes), yellowtail belly, and the most amazing uni I've ever had. Then came red miso soup, dessert and we also had tamago complimentary from the chef. I savored every bite.

The servers were all very attentive and my overall experience was great. This is truly a place for a very special night filled with amazing food. My advice would be to make sure to call in to get a reservation in advance. Clement St parking is insane, but we always find one if you are willing to a venture a few blocks.
author: Vivian H.

description: We swung here to eat dinner since Tekka was full already. Let me just say that it is not comparable to Tekka. It's not the same, so it wouldn't be fair. Wako is more of a small and chic place that serves uniquely created dishes by the chef. We did the omakase and it was about $130 per person. Each dish got better and by the end, it was a spectacular end. I will say that this place is not specifically sashimi driven, it is what the chef creates and you eat. Some places are specifically sashimi driven. I would recommend this place if you're taking someone out on a date to impress. I wouldn't come here over and over again. It's nice experience though.
author: Tony G.

description: Hands down the best sushi place of its caliber. When I first went here they didn't raise their price yet and they were fairly new but seeing how well they are doing now makes me very happy because I remember how the chef/owner mentioned how hard he had to work to start this place and it is still really stressful for him to run it. His craft for the cuisine is definitely at a master class. From day one, I knew he would blow up and seeing all the help reviews now, only shows his attentiveness to his art is paying off. Even though he raised his price I would still try to boast his place over any high end sushi places in the city. P.s. The special Alaskan salmon around April, when he serves it is the best.
author: Herb L.

description:
4.5 STARS 

Finding a solid, REAL Japanese restaurant in SF is like finding a good man in SF. Amidst the cockfest of douchebags and losers, there's a real gem...somewhere. If you look hard enough that is. That gem is Wako.

Quietly opening on May 27th, Wako took over the old Murasaki spot and is the 4th high-end sushi restaurant to open in SF after Akiko, Maruya, and Kusakabe. Wako's opening was not published anywhere and I happen to stumble upon it on Yelp after going through 100+ of sushi listings. My friend had mentioned that Clement doesn't need another sushi restaurant. I initially agreed with her but after thinking about it, Wako is one of the few authentic, Japanese owned and operated Japanese restaurant in the area (Okina is another). 

Hailing from Sanraku, Wako's owner and sushi chefs serve up traditional Japanese fare. On the menu are nigiri, maki rolls (no dragon or gross bukkake rolls), binsho-grilled items, and izakaya dishes. All nigiri is individually seasoned and sauced so no soy sauce or wasabi is provided. Beware that the nigiri is charge by the piece and not by the pair so your bill will quickly rack up if you order strictly nigiri. Expect to spend about a $80-$100 pp. 

They have an excellent sake and beer menu. Our waitress recommended a great junmai (I forgot the name but it was $10/glass) which I guzzled down. She also recommended the best beer I've ever had (and I don't usually like beer): http://bit.ly/1xOAq1R. It was pricey at $9 a bottle but I've never seen this banana beer before. It was smooth and light with a nice, sweet banana finish. Get this!

As suggested by the sushi chef, we decided to go with the smaller omakase so we can add additional a la carte items from the menu. 

Omakase Option #1: Two small plates, 1 binsho-grill, 7 piece nigiri & 1 miso soup for $43 or you can do the Omakase Option #2 that adds sashimi, tempura & dessert for $68.

OMAKASE OPTION #1 ($43)
*Braised Eggplant  & Housemade Sesame Tofu: http://bit.ly/1ubIk0t
*Gindara: Grilled Black Cod: http://bit.ly/TNYXoa
*Nigiri: Tai, Aji, Bonito, Canadian Salmon, Uni (Hokkaido), Otoro & Anago: http://bit.ly/1xOdM9W
*Miso Soup: http://bit.ly/1lq9n7i
*Complimentary Matcha Dusted Chocolate Truffles: http://bit.ly/1xOjSXE

The eggplant and tofu were great subtle openers. Loved the custardy texture of the tofu. As most of you know, I despise cooked fish but the generous portion of gindara was perfectly grilled and the flesh was super silky and moist.  

The best part of the omakase (as always) was the nigiri. The progression was on-point: from light to fatty fishes. The fish was pristinely fresh and each nigiri was individually seasoned and garnished with items that best complement the fish. Our favorite was the otoro; it's like sex in your mouth!

We had a choice of housemade miso or red miso for our last course. We received one of each to share. The red miso is a lot saltier so I liked the regular miso soup better. It was a bowl of comfort with velvety cubes of tofu.

The complimentary housemade matcha dusted chocolate truffles were like crack! They need to package and sell these babies!

A LA CARTE ITEMS:
*Tempura ($12): http://bit.ly/1jmvAz9
*Gindara Tu Nasu: Braised Miso Black Cod ($9): http://bit.ly/1s8taNT
*Chawanmushi: Steamed Egg Custard w/ Uni ($8): http://bit.ly/1iqJEr8
*Ankimo w/ Ponzu Gelee ($8): http://bit.ly/1pnYPcc
*Otoro ($8/piece): http://bit.ly/1hRfcMd
*Matcha Daifuku: Matcha Mochi w/ Red Bean Paste ($4.50): http://bit.ly/SCIQIX

Because no Japanese meal is complete without tempura in Mr. NSS' eyes, we had to get an order of tempura which was one of the best I've had. The batter was airy and super light. The gindara tu nasu was bowl of savory, umami goodness and would have been perfect with a bowl of steamed rice. I loved the silkiness of the chawanmushi but the uni was a bit too brown for my liking. 

Back to cold dishes, the ankimo was deliciously buttery. Not Ino-san status but still very good. I liked the nouvelle touch of the ponzu gelee. The second otoro piece was sexlicious as the first. This is a must order!

Do order dessert here as everything is housemade. The matcha daifuku was bomb! It had a fantastic chewy, carblicious mochi exterior with a delicate matcha flavor and red bean filling. Lolia S. would definitely approve. 

The staff is sweet, attentive, and friendly. Feel free to chat it up with the sushi chefs as they're super nice. 

Reservations are recommended as Wako only has 10 seats at the sushi bar, five 2-tops, and one 4-top. Do sit at the sushi bar for all the nigiri making action: http://bit.ly/1ljg5fR.

Parking in the area sucks so it's best to come on weeknights. 

Having previously lived in Inner Richmond, Wako is breath of fresh air to the plethora of pseudo Japanese restaurants in the area. *ahem Ichiraku ahem* Just be prepared for the sticker shock for the area. Well, I guess that's what the ramen budget is for. It's gonna be ramen bowls for daaaayyyyssss now... =/
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
let me skip to the end so you understand why i left a 2 star review. after a fantastic dinner here with terrific service, we paid the bill, left a 20% tip and made our way back to the car. 5 minutes later, we get a call from the restaurant saying something was "wrong with our bill" and they asked us to come back. luckily, we had not driven away yet so we walked back to the restaurant. 

turns out they gave us the wrong check - ours was actually $20 more. ONLY $20!?!?! that was less than 10% of our entire bill! i would understand if we still owed $50-$100, but to call us back AFTER we left and go through all this hassle.. and for what? for a measly $20 that could've come out of the tip since it was the staff's mistake for giving us the wrong check in the first place? the tip would've more than covered the $20 difference. 

i certainly did not expect this type of thing to happen from a $$$$ restaurant with the reputation that Wako has. the whole ordeal just left a really bitter taste in our mouths after what was originally a great omakase date night for two.

the only reason they don't get one star is because their omakase is really cheap considering you get a TON of good food for it. i'm sure all the other reviews give you a pretty good picture so won't go into details here. also a pretty large sake selection here. but man, that incident at the end really killed the whole experience for me.
author: Yiwen S.

description:
Our overall experience at Wako was a let down. For a four dollar sign restaurant, Wako suffers from a major identity crisis - it's tries to be fancy but lacks attention to detail. Its flaws are glaringly apparent and should not be compared to restaurants like ju-ni, and kusakabe. However, it could stand out if they choose to lower their prices and pretentiousness to the $$-$$$ range. 

Food: (exclusively omakase)
Nigiri - Decently tasty & fresh
Cooked food - less impressive

Ambiance/Decor:
A little too bright in the wrong places. I wouldn't have noticed the cheap walls and imperfections otherwise. 

If you go - don't sit at the sushi counter. Both the bf and I agree our experience would have been better at a regular table. We were surprised by the chef's experience levels. Somewhat stressful witnessing them make our food.
author: Nattie X.

description:
Excellent food and service. 
Been here twice within 3 months and the consistency is perfect.
author: Eric R.

description:
Fantastic restaurant and impeccable service. We had the 12 piece omakase and the chef would explain what we were eating and any additional questions we had about it. I would say I enjoyed probably 7 or 8 of the pieces out of 12, but as it is omakase, you may or may not necessarily like all types of seafood; it was always a matter of personal preference in my case. 

I felt the staff was very friendly and appreciative of us coming as they all said bye to us when we were finished and walking out. Even one that was not initially near us (perhaps in the back) made an effort to reopen the door, while we were already outside, to say thank you / goodbye. 

Definitely on my list of places I will visit again.
author: Drew R.

description: Great quality Omakase and Great service. The portion of the nigiri was a tad bit smaller than most places I go to.
author: Chantel H.

description:
What a neighborhood gem!  Be sure to make a reservation, a couple was turned away at opening.  Choose the sushi bar, you'll get all the perks and attention you need.  

Definitely go with the 7 course option for $68.  You get the 7 nigiri if you go with the 4 course also, but it's not the top tier stuff.  

LOVED:
-housemade tofu
-tempura fig
-aji
-aji fried bone
-salmon nigiri
-toro
-chawanmushi, perfect, crab pieces embedded throughout and mochi
-choco bites at the end

Would skip next time:
-uni
-crab

Requested, but not available:
-kohada
-chutoro

Add ons: gindara, beautifully buttery and smoky 

Drink: try the akitabare, smooth.  

Tea comes in a cast iron pot, really heavy, be careful.  If you use your fingers for the nigiri - no finger towels, use your napkin.

Improvement: timing of the courses, we had grilled items at the same time as nigiri and before I was even finished with the first course of tofu, tempura fig and veg, the sashimi was waiting for me.  Made me feel rushed and didn't feel like I was doing the food justice, as nigiri should be eaten immediately.  

Not only do you get the savory aspect for $68, you get dessert & little choco bites. 

Highly recommended, a bit below the other edomae choices that have sprouted up around town, and leans more on kaiseki, but high quality and supreme service.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Wako's an upscale Japanese Restaurant in the lower Richmond not far from Georgios on Clement Avenue.  The interior's tight with high ceilings.  The first impression was that it was new and intimate.  As I sat down, I immediately noticed how cold it felt inside: cold enough that I had to keep my jacket on whilst eating.  The 2nd thing I noticed was the loud sound acoustics inside.  It's not too loud that you cannot have a conversation but the sounds bounce around enough so that the surrounding conversations are distracting.

To make matters worst, the music which was loud instrumental drum beat music that I'd never heard of which kind of distracted the vibe of a place that's supposed to be an authentic Japanese restaurant.  I would've expected more peaceful sounds or softer, less invasive music.

Even with all those distractions, the quality of what was served seemed pretty decent.

For around $80, you can order a 7 course meal that comes with an appetizer, a sashimi dish, 8 pieces of sushi, a cooked dish, tempura, and miso soup.

Let's analyze the 7 course meal (which changes monthly):

Plate #1.  Fried fish ball (tasted like a tater tot: 3 stars); Fried calamari (not bad but the squid was stringy: 3.5 stars); Fish mixed with salad (3.5 stars); and white yam cubes and okra (excellent: 5 stars); a sort of Toro Tartar (4.5 stars)

Plate #2.  Four pieces of two types of sashimi: a smoked yellow tail (4.5 stars) and red snapper (4 stars)

Plate #3:  Cooked yellow tail with veggies and a sweet sauce (similar to teriyaki): 3.5 stars, the cooked meat seemed a little fishy.

Plate #4: 5 pieces of tempura: 2 were scallop cakes wrapped in shiso leaf (5 stars); green bean (4.5 stars) and bamboo shoot (4 stars) with an orange bell pepper

Plate #5:  sushi platter #1: ika sushi (5 stars); spanish mackeral (5 stars); red snapper (4 stars) and amberjack (4 stars); then sushi platter #2: toro (5 stars); salmon roe (5 stars); hotate (scallop) (4.5 stars); smoked wild salmon (4.5 stars);

Plate 6: I had the red miso soup (5 stars).

Plate 7: Dessert, a green tea sort of pudding with a black berry (4.5 stars).

All in all, for a 7 course meal, you get a lot of items.  Although I'd probably come here again, I cannot say I was "wow'ed" but did enjoy certain things a lot.

The service was good.  The atmosphere could be improved because of the temperature inside.  It was too cool at times and then at others too warm.  The circulation needs to be improved so that eating and socializing is the only focus while dining here.

The background music needs to be improved too.  The drum beat and noise of the music went right to my stomach.

Will give this place a try again but had higher expectations.  Still decent quality..
author: Tony U.

description:
Wanted to try this place for long time. 
It's indeed the best sushi bar I have been. 

Next time, I would like to order from La carte menu, hope its will be available.
author: Min L.

description:
As a horrible procrastinator, I don't show up to ANYTHING on time. Except for Sushi. We arrived 15 mins in advance of opening for our 5:30 old-people-time reservation to make sure we got to eat as soon as humanly possible. The parking Gods made it possible by giving us a space right across the street in this ordinarily parking-cluster-F area, where stalking is usually your best bet for success.

Atmosphere:
Minimalist, quiet, but not sterile. There is a scent infuser and mood lighting in the bathroom. 
I usually like to sit at the bar but you have to call to reserve that, online is for tables only.

Service:
Minimalist, quiet, but not sterile. Perfect pacing. Incredibly solid.

Food:
I'm an Omakase girl - $100 pre-tax & tip gets you
All the hot green tea you want
4 tasty amuse-bouche sized starters
12 pieces of high quality nigiri (no soy sauce or wasabi here people, this is legit - the Uni and Barracuda were the standouts of the night, the waygu was a little chewy and the the eel was a bit mealy)
Miso soup (red or white)
Tomago (theirs is different - if you like it spongy, you may find this pretty tasty)
2 solid little desserts (smooth basic panna cotta and tastier chestnut mousse)
Bomb-ass tiny chocolate truffle bites

Fullness-meter:
Full but not-thanksgiving-turkey-stuffed

Overall this is no Sushi-Ran in terms of how amazing the nigiri are, but it is truly legit, deserving of its Michelin star, and definitely worth showing up on time, heck - even early for.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
I kept building up this place in my head based on all the reviews. Over the summer I was in Tokyo and basically wanted to continue my high of quality sushi. When the date finally came to have dinner here I was more than excited. Stepped into a beautiful, cozy restaurant wrapped in wood. The decor in the place was completely inviting and intimate. The place can only sit about 30 people (you must make reservations and they book up pretty fast..). I really wanted to sit at the bar but it was completely booked even with calling 2 weeks in advance. 

We decided on the 7 course omakase which was comprised of  3 small bites, 1 piece of grilled fish, 7 piece nigiri, 3 small pieces of tempura, miso soup and dessert. 

Completely FRESH AND SIMPLE. Nothing too intricate or bold just simply delicious quality flavors that stayed true to their ingredients. I have to say the sushi nigiri pieces are VERY SMALL; even to Japanese standards. They were probably the smallest pieces of sushi I have ever had.. Even after the 7 courses we were still hungry so we ordered the kaisen chawanmushi - a small hot pot of jidori egg curd, snow crab and uni... AGAIN absolutely delicious but soooo small!! I was still soooo hungry. After dinner  I wanted to run to Genki for a crepe! 

Bottom line this place is OK. Pricey considering I left this place not overly full but definitely worth your while.
author: Caye Q.

description:
Ordered: Seven Course omakase dinners $82 (min. 2 orders)  small plates, sashimi,  warm dish, tempura, Chef's choice of nigiri (8 pcs.), miso soup, dessert

Second best sushi  I've ever had and best Omakase in SF! Celebrated a birthday and they were cute and brought our dessert with birthday sprinkles. Love it and will be back.

Make sure you make reservation ahead of time because there will be no walk-ins. If you're getting omakase, make sure you sit by the bar. Chef Tomo is awesome! The restaurant is small and cozy; the bar seats 10 and about 5 tables. Chef Tomo made our experience unforgettable by making sure each piece of sushi was perfect, attentive, and having a great sense of humor.

The fish is super fresh. Nigiri had the perfect amount of rice. Rice was perfect and prob best sushi rice I've tasted. This place is similar to authentic Japanese sushi where you don't need to dip it in soy sauce, it comes sauced and you just pick it up with you hand and put it in your mouth.

We ordered the seven course omskase with a couple extra nigiri and it was a lot of food. My favorites of the night were Filefish topped with foie gros and blue fin tuna in jalapeno soy marinade. 

We can't wait to come back and recommend everyone to give this place a try.
author: Joy L.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday and we all ordered the 7 course omakase. This is probably one of the first authentic sushi experiences I've had in San Francisco and I wasn't disappointed. Although we didn't get to sit at the bar, the service was great at the table and they were pretty on point with their timing to bring the food out to us. One of my favorites was their salmon roe, a tempura dish and of course their fatty tuna with gold flakes on top, ugh drooling just thinking about it already! The atmosphere felt really laid-back and overall great place to have a special occasion. Thanks Wako for a great meal!
author: Elisa S.

description:
It's taken me a while to make it to Wako because it's so hard to get to the Richmond area, but it was worth the trek.  We requested seats at the bar (by phone only) and the chef was very friendly and explained things just the right amount.  Definitely get sushi bar seats!

We were debating between the 7 course and 12 piece nigiri omakase. I went in thinking I only wanted sushi, but I'm glad we did the 7 course because their cooked foods blew other places out of the water.  The 12 piece nigiri option gives you some more luxurious items like anago, marinated maguro, wagyu, and uni.

Their sake prices are actually pretty reasonable and come in glasses, 250 ml, or 750 ml options. The pairing is $60/person, but we went for two 250 ml bottles, instead, which worked out well.

To start: small plates (I love the presentation of very carefully selected dishes).
- Blue fin tuna tartare with caviar: super smooth, good flavor
- BBQ eel with celery cucumber, tomato, mango: perfect for summer. The bbq eel had an a really good char on it
- Deep fried river fish and giant clam with edamame: the giant clam was really good, but the river fish was basically fish skin, which I didn't love as much
- Shigoku oyster with yuzu pineapple sauce: the sauce on top was really good and unique

Sashimi: you're first presented with a little dish with gold flakes and their house blend soy sauce, which is probably one of the best flavored soy sauces I've ever had.  The sashimi is on ice with seaweed, shredded daikon, edible flowers, a lemon, wasabi, and most importantly the fish.  We got 2 pieces of blue fin tuna (so fresh and so good) and 2 pieces of kampachi (I liked the yuzu on it).

Seasonal warm dish: Grilled swordfish in the center (super tender) and this almost gravy like mushroom truffle butter sauce that was very rich without being super heavy. It was a beautiful dish with different colors and textures - shimeji mushrooms, enoji mushrooms, okra, shiso leaf, edible flowers. This was a very impressive dish that I did not expect to come from a sushi place.

Seasonal tempura: I thought - how good could tempura be? Their batter (not panko) and selection of things they fried were really unique, and the green tea sea salt for dipping was awesome.  We had pike eel, brussels sprouts, a fig, and a cluster of corn kernels.  Probably some of the best tempura I've had (including in Japan).

Nigiri: (* = favorites)
1. *Kelp marinated halibut with shiso: the kelp marinade added so much flavor
2. Shiro ika: white squid - tender, but the texture is not my thing
3. Giant clam (from Washington) with rock salt and lemon: this is a hard one to come by  
4. Wild king salmon with yuzu and shiso: super smooth salmon
5. Aji with chives
6. *Ikura: house cured, wrapped in special seaweed from Kyushu - loved this
7. *Bonito: cherry smoked (with almost a bbq sauce flavor) with a garlic chip that's interesting for texture and flavor. I usually prefer my bonito a bit torched, but this was very interested
8. Chu toro: super smooth, melts in your mouth

Add ons: a la carte prices on the bill didn't perfectly match with the menu, but it all more or less evened out
- *Blue fin tuna in jalapeno soy marinade - slightly torched, great flavor
- Kohada (gizzard shad)
- Kampachi
- *Tamago: like dessert for me; I love this 
- We also got extras of the bonito and ikura

We finished with red or white miso soup (they gave us one of each). The red one was interesting and was very rich in flavor.

Dessert: they gave us one of each.  They did an impressive job with desserts since it's usually not the focus at a sushi restaurant.
- Coconut mango mousse cake with raspberry: a great fruit dessert
- Green tea and white sesame mousse cake: I love green tea and sesame, and I would have definitely paid for another one of this.  The cake was very light, and it had lots of beautiful layers.

The chef told us that they actually change the menu every month, which is a lot of work, but it definitely makes me want to go back more often!
author: Marilyn T.

description:
I'm actually surprised this place has a Michelin star. It was good but definitely not a mind blowing experience. Came here for my cousin's 23rd birthday. I hadn't even heard of this place until she mentioned it. We made reservations for the sushi bar (you have to call for this) at 8:30 on a Thursday and arrived to a packed restaurant. The dinner is long and we were the last ones to leave but never felt pressured to. 

You can only do the omakase at the sushi bar and we both opted for the $100 option. I also got a bottle of nigori and my cousin got some sochu on ice. We started with some cute tiny appetizers that took me back to Nishiki Market. Then came 12 pieces if nigiri you eat with your fingers. They give you this cute little finger wipe and a big serving of ginger to cleanse your palate between each piece. My favorite was the gold foiled toro that melted in my mouth. Gold foiled seafood is apparently a specialty of the city of Kanazawa, just south of the Noto Peninsula. Fun fact! You also get to pick between yellow or red miso so we got one of each and tried each others. I'm glad my cousin got the red one because I didn't like it and she loved it. Dinner ended with a piece of tamago (meh) and your choice between two desserts. I got the pan cotta and my cousin got the chestnut cake. Oh and you also have the option to order additional nigiri's after. 

I loved the sushi chefs and they were very nice. They spoke to my cousin about her time in Japan and recommended other sushi restaurants to try. I can't imagine having as good as an experience if we just sat in the regular table and ordered a la carte. I also added up the pieces of nigiri and it came out to be $98 so the $100 omakase is a pretty good deal considering. 

This has no bearing on my rating but service could have been more attentive from the waitresses. Its a small restaurant and I had to ask for my water to be refilled multiple times. The overhead lights here were also way too bright. Michelin star aside, I think I would still prefer my all time favorite Sushi Ran over Wako.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Truly a lovely Sushi restaurant. Unfortunately I went with people who did not appreciate the details of high quality sushi you'd expect from a Michelin rated sushi restaurant, however I enjoyed and relished in every bite.

Very lovely food and service.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Cute little Japanese restaurant. Friendly service. Make reservations. 

I just ordered some small plates and ngiri off the menu. The house-made tofu was ok. I had one at Raku in Vegas before, which I liked, but this wasn't the same/as good. The raw squid was NO BUENO though. It was like in this bitter sauce. The pieces of ngiri are a bit more expensive than what I'm used to in Seattle. $4-$5 sure, but I got some tuna belly, uni for $9 each! That's pretty hefty! The quality was pretty good, but not my favorite spot or anything. I ended up spending ~$70 w/ tax/tip.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Wako is the real deal if you are looking for Nigiri De Omakase, or trusting the Sushi Chef to serve you fresh creations of  traditional Japanese style sushi. The focus here is on exactly that. 

So if you are used to eating yada yada whatever rolls dripping in mayonnaise, thousand island dressing, and Sri Racha sauce, deep fried and covered with onions and other ingredients to mask the old, inferior, and chopped up bits of run-of-the-mill fish, don't come here. In fact stay away. Instead, check out your local Gaijin ("foreigner") owned/staffed Japanese-in-name-only Korean/Chinese restaurant for your oyster shooters and Gaijin Rolls.   

Wako is a smallish restaurant on the busy Clement street restaurant corridor in the Richmond district of SF. It is pretty new, opening in 2014. The owner/Head Sushi Chef is Japanese. In fact, most, if not all the front end staff, is Japanese. The seating is limited, and is focused on the Sushi bar. There are other small dishes, but mostly it is all about the sushi, not hot pot, sukiyaki, izakaya, ramen, kushiaki or any other Japanese food genre. 

We came here to try Omakase (Chef's choice) Nigiri (single sliced fish on a sushi rice ball).  We sat in front of Nakayama Tomo-san, the head sushi chef/owner. He was born in Shikouku, and got his Sushi experience in Kansai (western Japan) in Sakai-Shi (where the famous 16th century farmer-turned-Shogun, Hideyoshi came from, near KIX int'l airport). Here in the Bay Area, he worked at Sanraku before opening Wako. 

We were served a steady supply of various Nigiri, 14 to 20, I lost count. They were smaller in size than a traditional Japanese Nigiri from Jiro, but this has become popular in the US by people like Nobu in L.A. and other higher end sushi makers, to allow for greater variety for the diner, and perhaps a little more profit for the restaurant. 

We ate all of these Nigiri in a more traditional way, without wasabi mixed in small plate with soy sauce. Rather, we ate them exactly how Tomo-san served them, with a dab of wasabi under the fish, as is custom. He cut all of our fish and served us individually. 

We had a nice small 250 or 300 ml cold sake, (about $38), but I forgot which one. They have several to choose from. 

You should expect to pay about $100 per head for this type and quality of sushi, which is typical for real Japanese sushi establishments with good fish and rice.

I really enjoyed this restaurant and would like to return soon.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Our friends who are sushi connoisseurs recommended this place so we all went together on Saturday night. 

We sat at the sushi bar in the L corner, perfect for 4 people and I think the best seat in the house as we can see how the chef prepares each piece of sushi in the omakase.  

I debated whether to give it 4 or 5 stars as I rarely give 5 stars on the first visit.  But I have to.  Everything was the just perfect.  First the food.  We ordered the nigiri omakase which our friends recommended over the other one.  It was a work of culinary art and precision. My mouth was in heaven.  I asked my friend where the soy sauce was and he told me the wasabi, soy sauce and all the other flavors are already combined in the sushi piece so all I had to do was pick it up and eat it.  He was right.  Each sushi piece was an adventure with distinct taste.  I love each one.  I especially love
- starter course of monkfish liver, salad with Apple, even the fish cakes with lotus roots. 
 - the scallop which was lightly seared. It is a perfect balance to its natural sweetness
- the fresh water eel was the most moist eel I have ever had.  
- the Hokkaido uni was amazing in taste and texture. We ordered another round after the omakase. 
- the ink squid had a great crunch texture.  Never like squid before but loved it here. 
- snapper, halibut, toro, yellowtail all had its unique flavor.  We savored it all
- the wagyu beef nigiri was even tasty. 

We also ordered the following extras
- monkfish liver Loved it. 
- steamed egg dish- I forget the Japanese name.  This was divine with uni, fish and mushroom. 
- fried clams.  Yummy
- grilled glazed cod.  Tender and tasty

We finished with red and white miso soup. I loved the white one.  Hubby loved the red. Then finished with two desserts mix - I liked the lighter fruity one.  

We drank sake and hot tea throughout.  The sake I would recommend are the one that is gently fruity and the otter festival. 

Lastly I loved the setting, it is bright but not too bright, very homey and comfortable.  It was like eating culinary art without any pretense. 

We had 17 courses in all.  It was just over $800 for four people and worth every penny.  I look forward to coming back again soon ;-)
author: Lei H.

description:
I used to not like raw fish. However after watching Jiro Dreams of Sushi on Netflix my boyfriend had dreams of one day Sukiyabashi Jiro. Since that's not happening anytime soon we ended up looking for Michelin star omakase spots. After discovering omakase, I can say that my thoughts about raw fish have most definitely changed and now we've spent the last few special occasions finding different omakase spots. We went here for my boyfriend's birthday and it's definitely our favorite spot of all the places we've been to.

To start things off I placed a reservation a few weeks in advance. If you want to sit at the sushi bar they recommend you make an opentable reservation (to secure a reservation at the restaurant) but you must also call in to request the sushi bar. Luckily it was available for my reservation! Wako is on a cute little street near a residential area. Parking wasn't too bad on a Wednesday night. Our reservation was at 8pm and when we arrived we were greeted by a small restaurant nicely decorated with wood panels. The restaurant fits a very small amount of people but it creates an intimate feel.

If you sit at the sushi bar you are required to order their omakase. We went with the 12pc nigiri option which was a good choice since we still got a couple of hot dishes but the main focus was on the fresh fish. Some of the standouts include toro with caviar and gold flakes and tempura fig. The sushi chefs were very knowledgeable about the fish and would describe where each piece came from. Our items came from Japan, Turkey, and even locally from Santa Cruz! When presented with the wagyu beef towards the end of the meal we got to see the certificate of where it came from including the little cow's nose print, his name, and his parent's names (they showed me this after I ate it, thank goodness!).

Overall this was a great experience and well worth the price. It's less pretentious than some other omakase spots and the intimate yet casual feel allows you to really enjoy the experience. We've also been to Kusakabe and Sushi Yoshizumi. I would say Wako and Kuskabe are our favorites (Wako slightly more because we like the atmosphere more) and Sushi Yoshizumi was my least favorite.
author: Sarah C.

description: Recently went here with my SO at a friend's recommendation. Wait staff was friendly and patient. The chef Tomoharu was great to chat with and served up amazing food. Great atmosphere. Blue fin tuna belly was fantastic. The menu choices are 9- or 11-course Omakase ("chef's choice") but you are able to request additional nigiri/sashimi pieces at a la carte prices. If you sit at the sushi bar, the head chef makes your food, and you get a chance to converse with and get to know them.
author: Rockefeller B.

description:
The quality of the fish was pretty decent, the presentation of the food given the price, was just okay. 
I went once for a la carte when it was available (not available anymore). Also went for the 11-course menu as well. I have not been disappointed with anything I've been served here, and I felt the staff was very attentive and cordial. Do not expect to eat here without a reservation. 
Given the price however, I've had better overall experiences elsewhere.
author: Mima G.

description:
Wako wako wako flame! This is a cute and cozy restaurant in Inner Richmond that I had reservations for two on a Sunday night. We were ready for our omakase!

My friend and I got 8 piece omakase, and our standouts were the uni, wagyu beef, tuna belly, and snow crab. Sooo good.

The one we both really didn't like though-the clam. Could do without this one.

We ordered all four desserts for the night- black sesame mochi, matcha mochi, matcha mousse, and coconut mousse with banana. My favorite was the matcha mochi! Best mochi I've had outside of Japan. The black sesame mochi surprisingly had a whipped cream like center. 

Overall, a cute little Inner Richmond place that doesn't even make you feel like you're on Clement! If you want to sit at the sushi bar, you have to call in! I'll definitely be back for more omakase, hopefully next time at the bar :)
author: Katrina L.

description: Didn't know they have a Michelin star until after we left. It is well earned and the omikase offerings are each made with pride. Wonderful flavors , cozy setting and a masterful chef. Fish flown in from Japan is special.
author: Roger B.

description:
I had a good experience dining for the first time at this new spot. Well over $200 + $40 tip for two patrons, FYI. It's a quality restaurant. Small, focused on nicely flavored nigiri, no wasabi or soy. This isn't a place for diners who don't enjoy legit Japanese cuisine.

Note: We had more nigiri than pictured plus miso, another soup, and tempura.
author: Paulina F.

description:
My friend and I came here because of high ratings and how much people have been raving about this place. Buuuuut all hype was false unfortunately. 

For food, we ordered the 10 piece nigiri omakase and the kaisen chawanmushi to share. Food is mediocre at best. Average. Nothing stood out to my friend and I. Maybe just the seared scallop nigiri, but that's out of 10 pieces of nigiri and a small plate. 

As for service, we never got a refill on our tea. However, I noticed that the table next to us got an entire pot of tea while we just had a small cup. No one ever stopped by to ask us if we wanted a refill. Also, once the place got busy, we barely even saw our waitress unless they were giving us our food. Even then our food came out pretty fast.

Overall, our experience here was definitely lower than what we had expected. The quality of food is so-so and just average. We were hoping that Wako would prove us wrong, but instead, they proved us right that their food indeed is just average. I'm not saying Wako is bad, but there are definitely other sushi restaurants that serve better fish than here for the amount we paid here. 

Also, just to give you a glimpse of how much we spent, our total bill came out to be about $153 without tip -  $85 per person plus tip. Unfortunately, we won't be coming back.
author: Bonny C.

description:
Skimpy Sushi.
I am going back to Japan 2~3 times in a year, having sushi there quite often, so I think I have a title to make a comment to say this sushi is totally BS.

I am completely baffled by all the 4 star, 5 star reviews -- then again, Northern Cal has changed drastically.  No longer do you have people who actually know food, eating it -- just a bunch of rich nerds who look dress like they are homeless.

This place is gaijin central!  In fact, I was the only Japanese person in the entire 95% full restaurant.

This is not REAL JAPANESE Nigiri.
This is totally Bogus! You got to be kidding.
This is totally BS!
Well, Let me tell you what's traditional Nigiri should be look like.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=Za_FTqM88HAyAk6L7HbcNw

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=EJjWE1DqLG9r8HMFB74Cbg

That's why this is not traditional sushi, period!
The Pinky-sized Nigiri is so typical Americanized Sushi calls Su-Shit.
Don't get fooled by the Pseudo Japanese!
You'll get ripped off real good.
This kind pseudo sushi better stayed in place like Vegas.

I got a rip-off Sushi last night.
Who wants PINKY SIZE Nigiri?
Hipster Doofus, period.
OK, Just get over with. It's like "The Slanted Door" in Sushi version.
Weey over pricing, and you don't get much, but frustration.
It was PINKY SIZE Nigiri !

This is a thing, Can't Trust Yelp Reviews.
I had such a high-hope to get a real Traditional Japanese Omakase-Nigiri here.
I was looking for Jiro's class Sushi finally in SF!
But, I was wrong, totally wrong, disappointed, unsatisfied, very much.

The most rip-off Omakase in SF.
This is Not Traditional Japanese Sushi.
15 Kan, 15 single Nigiri Omakase, about $100.
The Neta and the Shari was twice smaller than authentic standard Nigiri.
And over sauce for such a tiny Neta. PINKY SIZE !
I was like, " Man, This isn't Japanese Sushi I'm eating, slicing fish like that small, must be very expensive fish from Japan, because Yen got lower."

Please see and check the size of Jiro's Nigiri.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R2L5IrkQTV0

Wako's Nigiri is about half size of Jiro's.
Wako's Nigiri is not even close to Jiro's.
I was hoping at least "Ino-Sushi" level, but not even close.

I am not asking the Sushi-maker to be like "Jiro", I don't think he can reach the level, but if you are real Sushi-Chef, I don't think he is, you need to have your master trained you taught you and train to be like your master.

I know that this is San Francisco, but I think we are ready for real Sushi.
But, not even close.
So, this Sushi-maker is great for "Rich-Americans". 
I think I am not rich and hip enough to come to a high class Sushi place like Wako.
I am a regular working class guy who is always hungry.
I felt like I should not be here because I am not sophisticated enough.
I don't belong here because I am not a rich American.
I don't even qualified to come here.
But, I can tell you this, the place is great for hip star-dufus who never had real Nigiri in Japan!

There are a few "Real" Japanese Sushi Bar better, a lot better than Wako in SF:
Ino at J-town
Koo on Irving
Kazu on Irving

Great lookin' decor and friendly service like any other "Asian" Sushi Bars.

So get this, Wako is American Sushi, Not even close to Traditional Japanese.
Domo, Daigo and Tataki level, You must know that they are Chinese-syshit, 
but you'll pay more here!
Who wants pinky size Nigiri? 
American Hipster, who else?
May be the Sushi-Maker is not Japanese, but he speaks.
It is very hard to believe if he trained in Japan.
What a shame!
The Sushi-Maker will rip you off really good. 
Well, you can find better "Asian" Sushi Bars in SF.

So that I do not recommend to anyone, simply because over pricing.
I had better,  I've experienced better.
I do not come back here again.
No, Thank you!
It's a shame, if the Sushi maker is Japanese making Nigiri like that.
Don't get fooled by Pseudo Japanese!
You'll be more than sorry getting the small rip off thing they think it is real sushi.
author: Nobu K.

description: This is my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco to date. I've been to Kusakabe, Ijji, ju-ni, Maruya, Omakase, Zushi Puzzle, Sushi Ran, Sushi Hashiri and Wako is still the best. Wako's sushi is not super innovative but it's done well and ultimately delicious. For true sushi lovers, sit at the sushi bar. Otherwise, amateurs sit at the tables.
author: Kai C.

description:
Service: A+ (they even opened the bathroom door for me)
Food: A- ((good and fresh, though everything was good...nothing really stood out as amazing...best of the night for me was the negi-toro, kanpachi & kinmedai)...some others were chu-toro, miyazaki beef, hokkaido uni & the tamago was delicious) also the smoked yellowtail belly was interesting.
Decor: A (clean and simple...always love the wood look)
Price: B (between fair to high...not too bad unless you eat and drink like me :) + a la carte nigiri prices are for 1 piece only)
Atmosphere: A (small, lively and engaging. Chefs are down to earth cool guys and fun to conversate with....huge +)


Notes: If you sit at sushi bar...You're required to order omakase. Omakase comes with small bites, a soup, 12 pc nigiri, tamago + desert. Option of $82 (less food) or $100 (which I went with). Nigiri a la carte prices are sold by 1 piece. Basic 300ml nigori sake $12, hot sake $17. 

Recommended. Wako dishes out some tasty stuff here but I personally dont know if I'll come back soon. While everything was pretty good... nothing really stood out and wow'd my taste buds (Don't mind me...I'm just being a sushi snob :) I just need to feel that umami type of way if I'm spending $300-400 (for 2) on a seating!
author: .I I.

description:
Came to this restaurant because of the high reviews. As we come in we are greeted by a very nice waitress. The decor is also pretty nice. 

We chose the omakase and expectations were high. Sad to say, the food was not up to the expectations. Many of the plates were pretty tasteless and very small portions. The nigiri was good, not amazing. 

Price of the nigiri per service is also quite ridiculous - check the menu. 

Sad to say don't think will be coming back unless they either (i) up the quality or (ii) lower the prices to the level of the quality.
author: Nuno S.

description: Service was good, place is clean and servers are attentive. A bit overpriced for $130, I had better sushi in Vancouver for less.
author: S S.

description:
With the lack of authentic, quality sushi restaurants in SF, I can see why Wako has high reviews.  Whenever someone raves about a sushi place in SF, they start with "my favorite roll..." & I stop listening.  Being a purist, sushi is nigiri or maki not California rolls (not authentic) with a combination of random stuff on it.  

We ordered items from both the sushi bar & the kitchen.  The cooked food from the kitchen rate 1-2 stars.  The sushi 3.5 stars.  Overall it was an overpriced dinner.

Kama - the waitress couldn't tell me if it would be Hamachi, basically any type of fish  kama (collar) is served at the same price.  Supposedly it was Hamachi kama that we got.  I've never seen a kama chopped into the 3 small pieces we were served,  It was overcooked, over salted & dry.  1 star.

Butterfish - meh, nothing memorable & def not misoyaki butterfish.  A little piece but at least it wasn't dry.  2 stars.

Tamago - was waaay too sweet!  Definitely wasn't trained on how to prepare it like at Jiro's.  1 star.

The hamachi yuzu miso  - yellowtail, yuzu, lily bulb, miso, celery, carrots $6 was the only great item we ate from the kitchen.

Sake maki, negi-hama maki, hamachi, hotate & saba nigiri were great.  Fresh fish but not great cuts.  Sushi rice was good & served at proper (room) temp.   They don't place soy sauce on the table & take it upon themselves to drizzle it on for you.  That annoys me - like a sushi Nazi who assumes all the customers are too stupid to know how to eat sushi.  I know how to eat sushi & don't drench it in soy sauce, in fact sometimes I'd rather not use soy sauce at all.  3.5 stars.

Service was good - dishes cleared promptly, water kept filled (despite the drought) & they checked on us regularly but not intrusive.  

Tables are close together so if there are loud people seated next to you it can be annoying - we know 1st hand.

TIP:  If you decide to try Wako, book a reservation.  This small place doesn't mark the tables as reserved but most are.  There were many walk-ins who were turned away while we were there.
author: Kim S.

description: My girlfriend and I each had the 9-course omakase at Wako.
