The courses included some small plates, chawanmushi, 4 pieces of sashimi, 8 pieces of nigiri, a cooked mackerel dish, soup, and dessert.  The highlights of the meal were the some of the nigiri (tuna belly, uni+salmon roe, barracuda) and the chawanmushi.  Aside from those standouts, the rest of the food was just plain good - comparable to other places that are half the price.  The service was very attentive, and we were pretty full by the end.  Wouldn't be my first choice among SF's highest-end restaurants, but tasty and a good experience nonetheless.
author: Simon L.

description:
Pretty amazing! It's small/cozy but very stylish and inviting. I like the wooden walls. The bathroom smells really nice! Friendly waitresses. Party of 4, ordered just about everything on the menu, so much so that the waitress kept saying "you sure you want more" =) What can I say, we were very hungry. 
Two orders of Omakase Nigiri plus extra orders of mirugai, uni, toro, salmon skin hand roll, etc., etc., But what we REALLY wanted more was ankimo and the best abalone tasting nigiri ever...sadly, they ran out of both. 
We finished our dinner with sweet tamago (very different from other places) and the misoshiru/akadashi miso soup...which were not as tasty as they looked but cleansed the palette. 
Since it's a bday celebration, we ordered four of the perfect/shareable desserts: mango mousse cake, raspberry tarte, and two of the mocha. It was very filling! 
$175 per person
author: Vee V.

description:
This is an upscale sushi restaurant. We had omakase, or chef selection which was served from the daily nigiri selection. Each bite is a gastronomical adventure, differing textures and just the right amount of rice. The nigiri selection was surprisingly broad from barracuda that was flash flamed to abalone that had the most amazing texture. I may have also had the best mackerel yet, which is always my favorite anyway.

The setting is intimate with only 10 seats at the bar, but it gives one a front row seat to the artistry that is perhaps the culinary peak of a chef's skill.
author: David A.

description:
*Small and cozy restaurant located in the heart of Richmond district in San Francisco
*Def make a reservation in advance as it was really busy even on a Tuesday night. 

I will say this from the get go: the food and service were impeccable. Every single plate that I received was an art.The fishes were fresh, buttery and practically melted in your mouth. The flow of all the courses made sense, all the ingredients complimented each other and there was not a single issue throughout the meal.

Some of us ordered the omakase dinner, which is a 7 courses menu for $76/each and you are trusting the chefs to present you the finest dishes of the restaurant. Although $76 is expensive, but in my opinion you can expect to pay $50 - $120 for an omakase experience anywhere else...

*First course - Small plates: (homemade tofu; seaweed + octopus; fish chips; tuna) - I can't remember the rest :(

The components on the dish are meant to be eaten individually and each on their own were amazing! The homemade tofu and seaweed/octopus in the short glass definitely stood out as they were really unique!

*Second course - Sashimi: Yellow Tail + Red Snapper
Fresh + Melt in your mouth.. *drool*

*Third course - Warm dish: Seabass; Okra; butter sauce
Seabass cooked perfectly with a crispy skin and light butter sauce! 

*Fourth course - Tempura: Eggplant; cauliflower; green bell pepper + matcha salt
The vegetable tempura was the best tempura I have ever had! They had a light crispy batter and not too oily. You can tell the tempura was fresh as they were hot and soft inside :). Although it was not needed, the matcha (green tea) salt really added a nice flavor to the dish

*Fifth course - Nigiri (8 pieces): 
All the nigiri was a hit at the table. Right amount of sauce and wasabi as they didn't overpower the freshness and flavor of the fishes. 

*Sixth course - Miso soup (choice of regular or red miso soup)
Definitely pick the red miso soup, it's got a pretty unique flavour in a good way and it was a nice palate cleanser

*Seventh course - Desserts
Both desserts had a texture of a pudding. Not too sweet and very refreshing, a nice way to end the meal :).
author: Anh T.

description:
Oh Wako!

Your Michelin star is well deserved.   We came here a month after you opened and just recently and my how you have found new heights.

The omakase course was spectacular.  Your selection of sake was great pairing.

You have put together quite the experience and we look forward to the next one.

I will have to get my mouth tested now cause it was just pleasently f@*!ked so good.
author: Spanky M.

description:
I had the pleasure of trying the omakase at Wako with some of my closest friends. According to my friend, Wako leans towards a more traditional taste in their nigiri sushi rather than a modern taste; where the flavors are not very powerful. If I go with his definition of traditional/ modern, then I currently prefer the more modernized taste.

From the nigiri selection, I really enjoyed scallop nigiri (unique), crab nigiri (a butter made from the crab brain to dress the top of the nigiri), makareel nigiri (my favorite fish as a nigiri) and uni nigiri (very fresh).

From the non-nigiri selection, I really enjoyed the sesame tofu, hamachi sashimi and corn tempura.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Managed to squeeze in a reservation at the sushi bar on the same day which was pretty unbelievable. Upon entering I was surprised that the restaurant was tiny! But I guess that is expected of omakase-style Japanese restaurants, they're never huge. My bestfriend and I sat in the corner of the sushi bar which was awesome because we got to see everything, the way the chef crafted our nigiri piece by piece - that honestly made the price tag worth it. We opted for the 7 course omakase however looking back, the people next to us who ordered the other omakase seemed to be getting better fish lol. I would recommend getting the more expensive omakase because it has a better selection of fish. Our omakase dinner was great but I felt like it wasn't as filling as Kusakabe's omakase plus we didn't get uni - I was disappointed. But i'll definitely be back to try the other omakase. 

The good: 
- friendly chefs
- fresh fish
- their red miso soup at the end is bomb! They even make it with sesame tofu
- sushi bar experience was awesome

The bad:
- isn't as worth it as Kusakabe ($95). For $70 I expected more variety of dishes. No uni in the omakase :( 
- restaurant is so tiny
author: Caitlin B.

description:
It's often difficult to write a review that differs from the majority. A lot of people have given Wako 5 full stars, but after dining there, I found that I couldn't justify a rating above 3 stars. I've been eating sushi since I was 6 years old and have experienced omakase meals in some of the some of the best Japanese restaurants around the world (Tokyo, New York, San Francisco, London, etc.) San Francisco has recently seen an explosion of high-end Japanese restaurants many of which only offer set menus ranging from $95 - $250 per person. When I saw that Wako's reviews were highly positive and their prices were less ($85 for base omakase), I anticipated a meal that was expertly prepared and good value. Unfortunately, very few of the dishes we received hit the mark. 

Included, please find an overview of our 7 courses. Although, please note that they skipped one of the courses (tempura) that is supposed to be included according to the menu, and we didn't realize it until afterward.

1. Starters: Toro Tartar, Okre with Daikon, & Fig Tempura. The fig was the standout but there was nothing special about the remaining appetizers (and the okre diakon could have been skipped entirely).

2. Sashimi: Incredibly poorly chosen items with terrible presentation (an unappetizing and tasteless piece of eel with small bones, an OK piece of clam, and 2 pieces of blue fin tuna). The quality of the fish was OK, but this certainly isn't the right combination to get a person's palate prepared properly and the whole dish looked like it had been thrown together.

3. Warm Dish: Whole cooked fish with a green vegetable sauce and a fried fish bone on top. This was the prettiest looking dish (photo attached), but after a few bites it was incredibly boring. The flavors just weren't present.

4. Tempura: We never received our tempura dish at all! There was nothing even mentioned, and since they took away our menus, I did not realize this until writing this review.

5. Nigiri: This is where the restaurant shines, and perhaps if I had only been eating Nigiri, I would have also praised this restaurant. I thought the selection could have been a little more intriguing, but the rice was great and the fish was fresh and expertly cut. Honestly, if we had only had this dish, I would have be able to provide at least a 4 start rating.

6. Miso Soup: We opted for the more pungent red miso. The dashi and flavor was excellent. My only complain was there was very little in the soup (only a couple tiny pieces of tofu and a small flake of fish). The broth was excellent but the distribution of the soup could use greater attention.

7. Desert: The deserts were nice. One featured Matcha and the other was sweeter. They were a pleasant way to end the meal.

All in all, we were disappointed with our meal, and in retrospect are surprised we missed an entire course. The way they served the nigiri (in 2 parts) made it seem like we were receiving all 7 courses, but in retrospect after re-reading the menu, I definitely recall the Tempura course being listed on the menu and missing from our meal. I think for this price point, there needs to be a little more focus on the presentation and the quality of the non-nigiri dishes.
author: Justin G.

description:
omakase: 5/5 
service 5/5

I came here a few years ago when they were new and then again when recently. The omakase is probably one of the best I've had. There are only two omakase choices on the menu for $90 or $130 (although when I went before it was only $70 for the lowest option, I guess thats what a michelin star does). I always opt for the bar seating right in front of the sushi chef because I wanna see everything made and you eat the food right after it is made. You can even watch the chef grate wasabi right in front of you (for those who don't know, wasabi at most sushi restaurants is dyed horseradish and never real). The service is friendly and servers are attentive. The fish there is extremely tasty and fresh. You may not get the same thing every time you go there because it depends on what is in season and what they can get in the markets. 

The Richmond district is not known for fancy food, because of that, this place is still not as popular because it is a ways off from the hub in downtown. Although now, there are some trendy bars. Hard to believe there is a place like this is 2 blocks away from my fav childhood cafe D&A; those two don't belong in the same neighborhood.
author: Cecile S.

description:
We got two seven-dish omakase and a few beers over the course of an hour or more. A great way to spend a romantic evening. The bar seemed lively, but the small tables for two were a bit too close for comfort. 

The food speaks for itself. Wonderful seasonal variety and a perfect blend of west and traditional sushi styles and hot plates. They hold themselves to the traditional standards while also having very strong foundations in American fusion.
author: Alexzandra E.

description: My second favorite omakase place in the city (favorite is Zushi puzzle... but that's a whole different price point). There are plenty of food and the price is pretty cheap... I think $80-120 for omakase. Good value for sure!
author: Betty T.

description:
This is one of those places where one would say "wow" upon entrance. Very clean, quiet and peaceful, yet always full of people. Very small restaurant but OMG!!! the freshness of the fish, the way it is presented and service are absolutely awesome. They sure know what they are doing. Sadly enough they are not open for lunch, I'd be here, spending money for sure. Reservations are a must. 
Food is really worth the drive, wait and money you pay for it. I've had omakase course before, in few places, and this one is easily the top 3 I've had in San Fran. I've seen 7 people being turned away, as they didn't have reservations, so I'm telling you they know what they are doing. Don't be fool, call ahead. Order blue fin tuna, it's a must. Also whatever they will have on their special menu, which I'm sure hanged daily. I will absolutely be back. This place is AWESOME!!!
author: Abe L.

description:
Deviated from my usual fav, kusakabe, to take my mom here for her birthday. 

Overall I really enjoyed the different preparations of the fish. We had the 12piece omakase and was very pleased with the food itself. 

I had to minus a star because the service was a bit off, and to be honest, quite awkward at times. One server came and asked for our dessert preferences. We told her what we'd like and five minutes later another server comes and asks for our dessert preferences again! I explained the other girl already took our order and the second server said "well she didn't get it can you just tell me again?" The tone was all off and it just felt awkward... The example I just shared was the third awkward interaction (I'll spare you and my keyboard the other details).

For a one Michelin star restaurant, it sure was unexpected.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Does this place need even need review #338? The other 5 star reviews pretty much sum up the experience. It's all true. The sushi and service are consistently excellent. I've been coming here for over a year now and have never been disappointed.
author: Mook S.

description:
Ordered the seven course omakase to sample everything and nothing disappointed! Very fresh and presented well.
Pretty small restaurant so call ahead and you can reserve a table. 
Very friendly staff and accommodating.
I will definitely return.
author: Kehaulani K.

description: This was a terrific birthday dinner locale. The Chef's selection and presentation was amazing. You almost feel bad devouring works of art on your plate... Almost. The service was equally as good. Recommended!
author: Felton L.

description:
We sat at the bar for the full omakase menu.  

The fish and seafood items were fresh, and the presentation was beautiful.  In particular, we enjoyed the kitchen items -- all well executed, delicious and bursting with umami!  Sitting at the bar allows you to talk with the chef, but it also puts a lot of pressure on you to say you like everything lol.  The experience is very personal and intimate, which we enjoyed.

The only thing about Wako is that they do serve more rice with their nigiri than I prefer, and the rice isn't as well seasoned as I like.  But I can live with that considering how wonderful the fish and execution is.

Overall, Wako deserves it's Michelin star, and we would certainly return again.
author: Gina T.

description: I had the omakase on my birthday in December. It was so pricey but so worth it. My tastebuds were going crazy- I loved every bite of sushi I had, Everything was so fresh! The floral/citron toppings they added on the sushi was a little off-putting but I liked it because it was new and different than other sushi toppings I've had. I would definitely go here again. Service was great, ambiance was nice (perfect for a bday dinner with my sig. other), and I really can't complain about anything. If you're thinking of treating someone here for an anniversary, Valentine's day, or bday, I'd highly recommend it. Don't forget to make your reservation in advance!
author: Julie H.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite sushi places in SF. Although $82 for a seven course omakase may seem pricy, it's a pretty good deal compared to many other omakase in town (*cough sushi hashiri cough*).
The food won't necessarily blow you away, but there's something nice about simple dishes that are fresh, well made and balanced.
All the fish in the sushi courses were so bright and fresh, and at the perfect size and temperature. The pieces are all pre-seasoned so no soy-sauce dipping needed! Just trust the chef!
Probably the weakest course for me was the desert - you get a little cake type thing in a cup - but hey, who goes to a sushi restaurant for the deserts!
Best of all is the atmosphere of the restaurant. The place is tiny, and only seats about 20 or so people, so it feels super intimate and cozy. The service was on point; attentive but not overbearing. It feels very modern without being pretentious.
All in all, if you're looking for a low key, quiet evening with some amazing food, Wako is the perfect place.
author: Cat M.

description:
Possibly the best omakase experience I've ever had! We were seated promptly at the bar and ordered the omakase nigiri for $100 each. Our chef was attentive, friendly and knowledgeable. We loved chatting with him about everything, from origins of fish to experiences in Japan to the Warriors! 

You get a tray of 4 small bites to start, all of which were just okay. The best was the fig tempura. 

Then comes 12 pieces of nigiri, broken up with a palate cleanser (seaweed based), a special soup served in a shell (outstanding) and fried fish tempura (super delicious). All the fish was incredible, plus the wagyu nigiri was phenomenal. We also added on 2 more pieces per person because everything was so good!

We then received their seafood tamago, which was too sweet and reminded me of lemon pound cake. 

Followed by red or white miso soup (we got one of each - I strongly preferred the white) and a green tea dessert and a passionfruit dessert. Both were good, but the green tea one was AMAZING.

Everything about this experience was perfect. The service was great, the ambiance was great, our chef was great and the food was amazing!
author: Amy Y.

description: I had the 11 course omakase. Decent sushi but I've had better sushi elsewhere for a similar price. I was surprised they earned Michelin rating. I was a bit underwhelmed with the service as well.
author: audrey Y.

description: One of the best, if not the best, sushi experiences I have had. Granted you probably won't be going here that often. I think it's a good introduction into Michelin level food and their prices. I would recommend trying Wako if you're even remotely interested in what good sushi is like.
author: Kenji H.

description:
Pretty happy I got to try this place when it opened because this spot is definitely rising to the top of my favorite sushi / Japanese joints in SF.

This location is seemingly harmless and far away from most places but make no mistake this spot gets busy. It is tiny inside, with a maybe 8 person sushi bar so you definitely need to make reservations if you want to come here and try it out. 

I highly suggest the sushi bar, but since it's so small you should only do the bar if you have 2 people. They can at most seat 4 to a table, so be aware of this.

The chef is very talented, I think and does a great omakase. Not only that but it is worth every penny! It's such a cheap omakase for the kind of food that you get served, and the sushi and nigiri are all expertly cut, freshly sourced and delicious. They have a great selection of sake and good selection of beer as well (of course Japanese-based ...), also great if you just want to continue your omakase with whatever the chef has to recommend after your official omakase ends.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Recently given Michelin 1 star and officially become one of the 5 Japanese restaurant that has Michelin star.

First timer: should definitely go for the omakase set dinner either the 9 course or the 12 course will be fine depends on how much you can eat.  This way you will got to taste all the fresh stuff.

Food: definitely fresh and good quality especially the fish.  They used bluefin tuna from Spain but the texture and favor is surprisingly good.  Uni is another must try.
5 star

Environment:  small but recently decor.  Bar seating is he best experience since you got to see the chef prepare your nigiri.
4 star

Service: service is not bad, but wish the waitress would spend little more time explain the dishes.
4 star

Price: you get what you pay for and general price will be around 100-150 with tip+tax without drink.  Don't get fool by the prize of an item.  Just because a nigiri is $5 per piece doesn't mean it is half as good as a $10 piece.  You got to try and see which one you like the most.  For example I really like the $6 yellowtail belly and not really into the $9 sea eel.
4.5 star


Overall 4.5 star.  A decent dinning experience.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Wow... Wako is amazing... That statement in itself is an understatement.

If you're into quality nigiri and prefer them more on the traditional end of the spectrum rather than on the fusion side, then look no further. Wako is where it's at. Make sure to make a reservation in advance for the bar, order omakase, and watch the chef churn out masterful nigiri sushi. 

Service from the staff is excellent and conversations with the sushi chef makes the experience cozy and intimate. The fish offered are fresh and my favorites include the otoro, the uni, the wagu beef, and the anago. Apparently, the anago is Wako's specialty and it's definitely a melt-in-your-mouth winner.

I thoroughly enjoyed Wako over other well-known NYC and DC sushi restaurants I've been too. Space is limited, so make sure to account for that.
author: Tunaidi A.

description:
You know how people describe really good sushi as "melt in your mouth"? I didn't quite understand that until I had the fatty tuna at Wako. It literally melted in my mouth because of how fatty that tuna was. And it was delicious!!

I came here on a Wednesday night around 8:00pm and although this place is pretty tiny (like a max 25 people capacity), we were seated right away. I couldn't decide on the multitude of different nigiri pieces so I opted for the chirashi bowl, which is under omakase. I'm usually not an uni eater because all the uni I've ever had was way too fishy, but the uni that came with my chirashi bowl was SWEET. Apparently fresh uni is sweet and refreshing! I savored that silky piece of deliciousness and made a mental note to order more on my next visit. 

All of the fish that came in my bowl was super super fresh! The food was so delicious that I even ordered dessert and got the sesame daifuku and a matcha daifuku. Although on the pricy side ($5 for a mochi about the size of a golf ball), they were both  chewy on the outside and creamy on the inside, none of that frozen stuff you might get at a meh sushi restaurant. 

Parking was a bit difficult even at 8pm on a Wednesday, but that's typical of Clement Street. Side street parking may be your best option if you don't see anything on the main street.
author: Virginia T.

description:
It's hard to have izakaya style dishes and excellent sushi but this place manages that beautifully - for a pretty price.

You must have reservations - I heard the hostess turn multiple parties away.

Best isakaya dishes are the tamago and fried giant clam.

Sushi variety changes daily, and for me, the sweet shrimp with fried heads was the run away delight!  Also good were uni and red snapper - each fish served already seasoned with wasabi, soy sauce, and other toppings.
author: Catherine S.

description:
Thoughtful service. Amazing sushi, albeit small portions. Ordered from a la carte menu which made omakase seem like a much better deal. However omakase is only available for parties of two or more.  Was able to walk in without a reservation around 9pm on a Thursday but they had run out of a few of the fish I wanted.

Liked this place better than akiko. Next on my list is kusakabe.
author: Chinthrilla M.

description:
Came here for dinner. We were going try the omakase, but opted out to choose a few small dishes to share. Upon walking in, you'll be warmly greeted by the staff. There are a few small tables with a very modern and open Chef's table. 

We ordered:

- soy-marinated raw squid
- monkfish liver pate in ponzu gelée
- black cod, eggplant, grated daikon 

and an assortment of nigiri.

I liked how the style of food was very similar to that of traditional Japanese cuisine--the simple, elegant, yet complex flavor profiles. The nigiri were melt in my mouth, but I can't say any one piece really impressed me. However, for the quality of fish outside of Japan, I definitely give it a good 4 stars.

Service is an impeccable 5 stars. I think if I were to come back, I'd go for the omakase.
author: Rachel C.

description: I was really disappointed with my experience the second time around.  We had a reservation and was never told our time was limited.  After ordering Omakase, we weren't allowed to order anything more because they wanted to seat the next party.  It really ruins the experience when you want to sit down and enjoy a nice meal (and no, we were not taking our sweet time).  They could have at least told us upfront that we had to be out by a certain time so we could have ordered what we wanted ahead of time.  For a Michelin star rated restaurant, they sure don't care about the customer experience.
author: Lanes S.

description:
Service was good, plating was decent, and the space is lovely. Unfortunately the food itself (we went on Friday night and ordered chef's omakase) left a lot to be desired. The fish lacked flavor, was texturally bad (tough to chew), and some were not fresh (smelled fishy!). The other dishes were unremarkable. Bottom line, at $80/person the food should not be mediocre. Based on the quality of food we had I would expect this meal to cost about $20/person. No clue how the restaurant got a Michelin star based on my experience there. 

Go to Kusakabe instead.
author: Adam W.

description: Really enjoyed dinner here. I am also a fan of Kasakube and would say the two are at par regarding the overall quality of food. Wako has a more thoughtful, innovative sushi menu, and their sake pairing is simply wonderful.
author: Cynthia L.

description: One of the best sushi experiences of my life.  All the dishes were perfectly executed with great attention to detail.  The experience rivaled any sushi I have had in Japan.
author: Loyd C.

description: I really wanted to like it but it was just so so for the $135. The dishes are very underwhelming in comparison to other places like kusakabe that charge less. The nigiri and Sashimi weren't bad but I'd say 3/12 were a bit fishy. Wasn't happy with any of the cooked dishes at all. Pretty surprised by the Michelin star.
author: Dee N.

description:
I am going to update my review.

Just went back last week. 16 dishes for $100 is a great value.

Unlike last time, where majority of dishes finished with hot chili tone.  This time the seasoning were just right.

I still have problem with the rice as its little flavorless for white fish.  However the temperature control was good and for heavy flavor fish, the rice compliment well.

I wish Yelp can have 4.5 star rating. It's still not as good as Kusakabe and Yoshizumi.  But the gap between Kusakabe and Wako was very close this time around.

Yoshizumi still the best.  But Wako is such a good value.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Dining at Wako Sushi is an experience in itself and was probably the closest I could get to the Jiro's and Sushi Dai's of Japan. The owner and sushi chef puts so much care into everything he does, and will go into great lengths to tell you about where each ingredient comes from. I went with the seven-course omakase, which was really the best way to get a good sampling of the menu and their fish specials.

The meal starts off with a small plate that comes with three components. The plate was probably one of the most beautifully composed plates I've seen, built around the theme of autumn. First is a housemade sesame tofu with a tiny dot of wasabi on top, and the texture was a lot creamier than most tofu. Next was a roasted eggplant slice made to look like a tree stump that was covered with a delicious sauce. Finally, a piece of kombucha squash was carved into the shape of a leaf and roasted just right. All of the flavors were simple and clean, but it was the perfect way to pique my appetite.

The next course was sashimi, which was served with a bit of lemon zest that really complemented the fish. The best piece was the king salmon, generously sliced and extremely fresh. To round out the appetizers, the tempura plate was the most substantial and further showed the creativity of the chefs. The matsutake mushroom and shishito pepper tempura were relatively standard, but the mackerel was first encrusted with rice cracker and then fried in tempura batter. It gave the tender fish an amazing crunch on the outside, adding both flavor and texture. 

The main grilled course was served in between the nigiri servings, and the day's special was a potato-crusted salmon with seasonal vegetables. The salmon was essentially marinated in a potato puree that really softened the fish, and then it was topped with chestnut, green bean, and carrot. The dish was somehow a complete dish all combined into one piece. 

The seven pieces of nigiri is really the most unique part of the omakase, with each piece served one at a time, with wasabi and soy sauce already carefully painted onto the nigiri in order to avoid any customer drowning their fish in soy sauce and wasting the flavor. The best piece was the toro, or the fatty tuna belly. It's the most buttery piece of fish, and I loved the rice to fish ratio. They're definitely not trying to fill you up on carbs, leaving you plenty of room to really enjoy the fish. Wako has also brought upon my appreciation for uni. I've never really had good uni before this meal, and the uni nigiri with the shiso leaf tucked in between the rice was perfect. The brine-y flavor wasn't overwhelming, but I still got a great flavor of the ocean. Another highlight was the crab nigiri, which was so tender. It was a simple bite, but the perfect way to highlight the crab. 

The meal is finished off with a housemade strawberry mousse, maintaining that light quality that connected the entire omakase. The fresh strawberry chunks made it refreshing, and the mousse itself wasn't at all heavy or creamy. They also serve a complimentary piece of chocolate that they also make themselves, finishing off with a bit of decadence that you didn't realize you wanted after an amazing meal. 

Wako Sushi is without a doubt one of my favorite Japanese spots in San Francisco, and I highly recommend it to anyone, sushi lover or not!
author: Ashley T.

description: This place deserves all the recognition they get! Service is great, waitresses are always available, kind, and you gain a one on one interaction with them as they explain the dishes to you. Sushi wise, they house cure some of their sushi. There shipments aren't from California, mainly from Spain and Japan.
author: Karissa K.

description:
Hello Wako! To me you are Maruya in the mission minus the big bill! 

I went here couple days ago and I had a late lunch around 3pm and went in around 6 so my friend and I decided to opt for the smaller course Omakaze. Before our official course meal started, we ordered a SEASONAL mushroom soup -- this mushroom grows in Japan (also seattle and canada apparently) only under pine trees and because they grow and are at optimal in taste during this time, Wako only offers this soup in Oct/Nov months. 

Their smaller Omakaze menu doesn't change, but they will change up their menu close to quarterly basis for their bigger Omakaze.

Courses:

#1: Tofu and salad
- Tofu was super soft (possibly home-made) but a bit bland and wasn't too special for me.

#2: Miso glazed sea bass
- Pretty good but it's not unique to Wako and there isn't anything phenomenally outstanding

#3: 7 Nigiri
- Beautifully made and very tasty! I have to say.. the rice is better at Maruya but the cut of the fish and how it is prepared is exceptional! I LOVED IT. My favorite was (and if you don't do omakaze try this at least) red snapper with cherry blossom leaf, salt and lemon. It melted in my mouth and I think I had a tear in my eye. ;) 

#4: Finished with red miso soup which was great and unique.

#5: mini home-made chocolate

I highly recommend it and it will not break your bank.
author: Sarah K.

description: Confused about the hype and the Michelin star.  Omakase was really disappointing.  For the price point, Kusakabe or Sushi Ran is much better.  Wouldn't recommend.
author: Christine A.

description: Another stellar SF sushi bar! We came here on Saturday evening and sat at the sushi bar. If you want the Omakase set, please be aware that you'll have to get a bar seating (which you can only get by calling them, OpenTable reservations are for table only). One thing that's kinda unique about this place: a bunch of pieces of nigiri that we had were lightly seared via blow-torch. It was a treat watching the chef blow-torch the fish. Also, can I just say, amazing knife work on all the fish. Overall, a 5/5 place for sushi, but make sure you reserve ahead of time. This place also has one of the best price for the quality/quantity of sushi you get. We will be coming back again very soon.
author: Sharon L.

description: Absolutely mouthwatering , intricate , intimate and unique sushi experience! Quiet clean ambience perfect for a special date night. Passionate chef and food that delivers on taste as well as presentation. So many memorable bites throughout the night , the best sushi I have ever tasted. Can't wait to go back!
author: May F.

description: Great place. Everything tasted exceptionally good and all the food was well presented. The service is good. The atmosphere/decor is nice too; it's a smallish restaurant. Really stands out as one of the better/authentic Japanese/sushi restaurants. Way too expensive for my liking, however. There are better (or very comparable) sushi restaurants for lower prices in SF. I will not be returning to pay these prices.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I've been on the quest to find a great omakase sushi bar and have been to 5 different places in the past 2 months.  Wako got such great reviews with a bunch of nom nom nom, appetizing photos. But my friend and I were disappointed from our Fri visit. I'm hoping it maybe because they were having an off day.

Below's our experience on the full course of omakase. We also ordered a few things a la carte and I thought a la carte has better value. The best dishes are probably the uni and otoro.

Ambiance - 4 stars. Nice, quaint, intimate.
Deco - 4 stars. Clean, minimalist, comfortable.
Presentation - 4 stars. Artistically appealing.
Flavor - 2 stars. Sushi rice was dry and lacked flavor. We also ordered the white salmon special; it was cooked tough, doesn't flake off and the glaze was burnt and no flavor. Some other fishes were also lacking flavor.
Selection - 3 stars. 
Service - 3.5 stars.
Quality - 3 stars

I might go back again. But it would be to try the normal sushi bar.
author: May W.

description:
I was very surprised to see all the 5 star reviews, hardly ever happens and definitely never in new restaurants as they are working out their kinks.   But it's a few blocks from my house so I wanted to support my hood.

My hubby and I went for a Friday date night. We were excited to try something new and creative and we're all about food adventure. 

Unfortunately the food just wasn't great, the dishes were a bit bland and the portions pretty small and since fish is light, we ordered many but still walked away hungry.

The miso black cod had tons of bones in it, which just shouldn't be served in a fillet and the portions small.

We had the monkfish liver pate, it was interesting but a bit dry and lacking in flavor. 

The hand rolls didn't have much fish.  The best part of the meal was the nigiri, however they were pricey at $5-9/piece.  

The service was very slow, didn't refill our drinks and the rolls took forever, we waited over 30 minutes, while the hot dishes came out fairly fast.  The waitress apologized for the bad service and said hoped we'd come back again.  In this situation they should have comped some of the food and given us something on the house while we waited. 

After dinner we went over to another place for dessert and drinks, and if it wasn't so late I would have shared an entree as well.  

The bill came to $130 with tip, given the great meals you can have in SF for that price, including great sushi, it just wasn't worth it and I'm not looking to come back again.
author: Inga W.

description:
Happy to see these kinds of sushi restaurants popping up over the city. 

I was skeptical but it was actually quite good for the bay area. 

I don't think I saw this on the menu, but we had the sushi omakase.  We basically had all the fish they had available that night.

My only gripe I would have to say is that the chef could be a tad heavy-handed on the wasabi and some items were a tad salty.  Oh and their fish selection seems limited. They had 18 kinds that night but were kinda basic. 

Tamago was on the house. Yay! It's the cakey wet kind.  (If you know which one I'm talking about.)  It had notes of coffee,  I thought. 

Other than that, the quality is decent and is fresh enough. 

The desert was good as well.  The matcha cream-filled daifuku mochi was delicious. The outside mochi is soft and the red bean is smooth and doesn't overpower the matcha.  It had the perfect balance of flavors.  It was $5.  The peach panna cotta was also good but small. But there hasn't been a panna cotta that I haven't enjoyed.  

The decor is minimalistic and they play elevator music which is pretty usual for these types of sushi bars.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Wako - A Japanese & California Cuisine
Tuesday, May 27th was it's first official opening day of business.
This place is a very Traditional Japanese Style environment.
From the moment you walk in....you are greeted and you get a hot towel to freshin up prior to eating.

The Chief is a friend of the previous chief that had passed away a few month ago, and has reopened with a newly remodeled restaurant.

The Sushi is very fresh and very tasty.  The Chief makes high recommendations, so if your not sure what to order....his advise is awesome!!

Here is what I had:

Blue Fin Tuna
Yellowtail
Chinook Salmon
Konnyaku to kikuna no kurumi miso - Yam Jelly, Chrysanthemum Leaves, Walnuts and Miso
Tekka Roll - Hon Maguro, Wasabi
Negi-Hama - Hamachi Scallions
Chief Surprise Handroll
Chocolates for desert

Loved the Blue Fin Tuna best of all!!  
The Chief has his own Wasabi mix so there is no need to mix the Wasabi and Soy Sauce.  Everything was very fresh and tasty.  Seaweed was nice and crunchy.....got to love the Handrolls when the seaweed is like so!!

Sushi is individually priced.

Highly recommended .... I'll be back for more!!
author: Alan L.

description: What a pleasant dining experience. I compared it with Sushi Yoshizumi and they are different but both very very good. Yoshizumi is more traditional omakase, while Wako emphasizes a lot on the presentation. Head chef/owner was very humble and nice and had just the right amount of conversation with customers. Service was attentive and spot on as a Michelin star restaurant. Highly recommend.
author: Pookie L.

description:
I never write reviews...  But, I certainly think Wako deserves my very first review!

While the whole town is hyping over the opening of Kusakabe, Mr. J and I decided to try this even newer, shy of a month old joint first.  I got home around 8:30 pm on Friday night after a long streak of working weeks and was telling Mr. J that we haven't had time to really enjoy a meal together.  So, maybe we should go somewhere nice for dinner.  Mr. J was laughing at me and said no good place would have an open reservation on a Friday night.  Well, I decided it doesn't hurt to try and gave Wako a call to see if their sushi bar is available at 9 pm.  I won't lie, but I was surprised when the lady over the phone told me that they are available.  And there, Mr. J and I rushed out the door.  On the drive over there, we kept thinking if we made the right decision and will we be disappointed at the end of the night.

When we walked into Wako, I immediately fell in love with its cozy and inviting environment.  After identifying ourselves, the server sat us down at the best seats in the house with the reserved sign.  There are 10 seats at the bar and we got the perfect front view of Tomo-san and Atsushi-san!  Wako offers four or seven course omakase option and Mr. J and I went for the seven course one and added a few a la carte items as well.  I won't go into too much detail of our dishes as I believe a picture is worth a thousand words.  But, there are a few things worth mentioning.

*** Rice - Mr. J and I are very particular and picky when it comes to the sushi rice.  We both agreed that the sushi rice at Wako is probably the best we've had in the bay area.

*** Size - Some might find their nigiri to be on the smaller side.  But, I find them to be the perfect size to be eaten with hands in one bite.

*** Rhythm - Tomo-san always asks if he may start preparing the next sushi.  And, every nigiri is prepared right before served.  I really hate to compare Wako to Maruya since Mr. J and I like them both.  But, we've seen fishes been sliced together beforehand at Maruya the last time we were there at the sushi bar.

*** Tamago - Not your typical tamago at the sushi restaurant here.  The type they served is Kasutera, the kind that look and taste like the Japanese Castella cake.  And, it's Mr. J's favorite!  Tomo-san asked if we had this kind of tamago before and wanted our opinion.  After I took a bite and he saw my big smile, he said no words are needed as he can see it in my smile.

*** Dessert - I cannot express enough the importance of a dessert at the end of every meal.  I don't care how good of a meal I had if their dessert is weak.  A great dessert = a perfecting ending to a meal.  Mmmm, I am still drooling over their house made matcha daifuku!

Tomo-san and Atsushi-san are both funny and interactive.  They totally made our night a happy one!  Mr. J and I were the last two to leave with two very full and happy tummies!  We'll be back soon!!
author: Kay Y.

description:
Excellent omakase, sushi restaurant! I live in LA and was lucky enough to try this gem while visiting. I've eaten at Sasabune, Matsuhisa, and Urasawa in LA and this place is right up there with these brand names in taste, creativity and quality, but without the price tag and stuffiness. $68 vs $100+ is a smoking deal! 

Food: 5 stars
7 course omakase
Every single dish down to the garnish was amazing! I was especially in love with the red snapper tempura with rice crackers. You can tell the food was made with heart. 

Atmosphere: 5 stars
Modern wood decor, beautifully designed. Check out the bathroom, you wouldn't want to leave! 

If I lived in San Francisco, this would be my go to sushi joint!
author: Shirley W.

description:
I brought my bestie here for her birthday and we both really enjoyed the experience! I've been dying to come here because I love omakase and I like that theirs has different preparation styles (apps, grilled, sashimi, etc). 

We got two drinks, the omakases, and a couple of nigiri, which totaled $270. It's a little pricey but worth the quality! The menu changes every couple of months so there's good reason to always come back :)
author: Bianca W.

description: A really lovely meal at the sushi counter. Omakase was beautifully done and offered great line up of various sashimi and nigiri pieces, along with tempura and other seasonal little dishes that both delight the eyes and the tastebuds. Goma tofu was delightful and loved the custard egg. Love to revisit again.
author: Stephanie L.

description: So I thought I'll try a new #sushi spot in #sf and it was ok. The food overall wasn't too bad, but you can definitely get much better with the sane atmosphere. Order: raw squid, a5 wagyu miso stew , fresh assorted crab and seaweed , and some nigiri !
author: Li S.

description:
I love this new Japanese restaurant in SF. Small, refined, super friendly staff. If one calls Roku Japanese fusion toward the western end of the spectrum, I would call this Californian Japanese toward the Japanese end of the spectrum.

Everything was done with taste, fabulous presentation, great balance of flavor, and ingenuity.

If you are here with someone, I would suggest to share a 4-course omakase. The nigiris are amazing - seasoned for you already and top quality for fish, rice, and presentation. I even like it better than the ones in Japan since the chef seasons it perfectly to save us Americans from putting too much soy sauce on them. 

If you want to miso soup, I would recommend the misoshiru (traditional miso soup) rather than akadashi (red miso). The second one is a bit more salty and the traditional one has more subtle flavors. 

Skip the rolls - a bit too soft for my taste and the pickles are quite strong. 

The starters for omakase were a great way to ease one into the more elaborate nigiris. The sesame tofu surprised me a bit with a nutty overtone and subtle sweetness. Probably one of the best uncooked version of tofu I have ever tasted. The vegetable dish was delicate and light. 

The peach Panna cotta was fabulous. Not too sweet and not too acidic. Beautifully presented. Just the right creamy/airy balance with quite a bit of depth in the flavor. 

The black cod and the tempura were solid.
author: Rebecca C.

description: It's really, really rare that Yelp leads me astray. Wako was one of those times. My team and I  journeyed out to Wako for really disappointing omakase: execution, creativity and service were all a miss. $76 is a great deal for Omakase in SF, but the 4.5 average at Wako is baffling.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Tuesday - Called at 5:20pm to make a reservation for Sunday at 6:30pm. Very accommodating over the phone. Please do make sure that you call during their reservation acceptance hrs. On Saturday, I had to call in to make a last minute change to add 2 more people to the party. Again, they made it happen and we sat at the sushi bar. 

Our pleasure and first time was given to Tomo-san who serves around the corner are of the sushi bar. Tomo-san started joking with us when he found out that one person was late. He said, "Is the person here? Looking for parking?" I said, "yes". He said, "oh no... Good luck!" hahaha! The friend ended up spending 15 mins looking for parking. They didn't rush us to order since our timeframe was blocked off specifically for us to enjoy the dinner. 

Our party for 4 did the 7 course omakase for $68/head. 
Seven Course 68 small plates (3), sashimi (4pcs.) bincho-grill (1), tempura (3), nigiri (7pcs.), miso soup, dessert.

The four piece sashimi included King Salmon and Hamachi. Honestly, nothing special for this plate.. King salmon wasn't buttery or creamy enough. Just wasn't a big wow factor for this. 

I'm going to skip the grill stuff and the tempura stuff. 

Right down to the nigiri, because this is what I like about the place. Best fish of the day is what's this is all about. No soy sauce beyond this point. Everything was lightly prepped without heavy taste. This is where you find out if the fish is fresh or not. My favorite of the nigiri was the Snow Crab. Very close to what I had in Hokkaido Japan. Then there was scallop which was lightly seared. Very juicy and almost melted in my mouth (like tofu, but it has a nice caramel scallop taste). Then it was the toro... and finishing the authentic Hokkaido Uni. You can actually see that the box had hokkaido sticker on it. Very sweet! 

We also had a drink with Tomo-san.. Be sure to order up the Banana Beer that they have. Nothing better than drinking up with the sushi chef and talking about food. Tomo said he loved izakaya's in San Mateo area.   

~Note~

We requested one of the omakase to have more seared and more cooked items since our friend wasn't a big raw fish eater. Tomo-san was nice and served up some specials for her. He made sure that each item was okay and that she liked what was served. 

Wish the server were more prompted on refilling tea. We had to ask for a pot since we kept asking for refills. 

If I were to do it again, I would do 4 course meal, use the $25 difference and order some different stuff on the menu. You might get more bang for the buck if your a nigiri person. 

Oh, don't miss out on the housemade dessert and the chocolate.
author: Eric Y.

description:
The food here deserves an A! The sushi is pricy and I don't mind paying for it as long as the service is also great. 

The customer service deserves a C. 

Went here for dinner with my brother tonight for a 11 course omakase tasting. The staff was very nice but when the restaurant started getting busy, the manager name June put the check on our table before us even getting our dessert. The part that was a turnoff is how they brought the check before us even getting our dessert. Which made us feel like we were being rushed versus giving us the opportunity to enjoy the whole dining experience. Especially considering how much money we were spending on dinner.
When we ignored them putting the check on our table, the manager June came to our table and said there was a 2 hour time limit to eat at the restaurant. So we needed to hurry up and finish our dessert. When I asked June where does it say that there was a 2 hour time limit. She responded that it was posted on the website. Later in the evening I went on the restaurants website and there was nothing posted to say there is a 2 hour time limit. So not only June was extremely rude she also lied. June is not a good quality manager who knows how to create lasting relationships with customers to make them want to come back. June belongs in the back washing dishes because she lacks people skills.
author: J C.

description:
I have been on a sushi cleanse for the past six months. For six tortuous months, I have watched my friends, strangers, television hosts eat, discuss, and enjoy sushi. Now, I cannot even remember why I gave up sushi, but I am so glad that Wako was my introduction back into the wonderful world of sushi.

For my return, I decided that reservations for the sushi bar and the seven course omakase were the way to go. Reservations were easy to get for an early weekday dinner but parking was a headache. If you cannot find parking on Clement, save your gas and drive one block down to Geary.

The chefs and waitresses at Wako are very attentive and friendly when the restaurant is slower, so I am glad that my experienced ended before the dinner rush. For my appetite the 7-course omakase was not enough and I needed to interrupt with 8 more pieces of nigiri before finishing off with dessert. I enjoyed the small plates, bincho-grill, and tempura, which were perfectly cooked or fried. The nigri was beautifully present and tasty to boot but the cuts were smaller than I expected. At least the chefs downsized the rice to create the right ratio. Wako is a great for a sushi date night, and reminiscent of Koo, but be prepared for the bill. Eating here is an expensive experience. 

What I recommend:
- omakase (changes every month according to the chefs)
- anago
- tamago (bready and sweet)
author: Andrew W.

description: The best meal I had for my birthday, hands down. The omakase set is about $100. We had a couple of additional nigiris, including the sweet shrimp with uni. If it's on the menu, be sure to order that. I loved all the fish and was thoroughly full by the end of the meal, although I have a smaller appetite than others. The omakase set includes hot dishes that came out beautifully prepared and dessert. Wako is cheaper than Omakase, Akiko's and Kusakube but the food is just as good. Reservations were easy to make a couple of weeks in advance. I would come here or Saru to get the bang for your buck.
author: Chi N.

description:
tip: don't dip the pre-sauced nigiri in the wasabi soy mixture.

Some imperfections, tempura not crispy. Skin on when requested but otherwise very unique selection of nigiri.  The stewed pear with mackerel was overcooked. Uni complements the egg really well.  

Giant clam nigiri had out of this world texture so that has to be the highlight of the night more so than the toro and uni cuz that's really standard omakase stuff.
author: Jacky K C.

description: I think they have an awesome concept but it's a bit modern vs traditional omakase. They basically turned the old tradition of having an authentic Japanese Chef preparing whatever they want into a fusion like multi course meal like a French restaurant. It gets alot of stars from me bec it is high end and they deliver well but it's short 5 star for lack of authenticity.
author: R M.

description:
It was competent. Not bad. But for the money, not amazing. If you think this is "the top of the mountain" then go camp out at Yume in Alameda and then tell me how they compare. Or compare to Kabuto--I'm sure I can get better fish for considerably less money at Kabuto. If you do compare, do an apples to apples comparison of exactly the same sushi orders. Heck, same day if you can swing it. I can feel the difference.

One piece of sushi I ate and then forgot immediately that I'd eaten it--no impression. It's not the point of sushi. At Kabuto, and Yume, the flavors are divine and they grab me. I could be totally distracted but I taste that fish and oh my god, there it is. At Wako there was a "je ne sais quois" missing. It didn't have the X factor. Don't get me wrong--it's not that Wako is bad; it's better than most of what's out there. I won't eat Sushi at 90% of the Japanese places in this town. It's just that at this level of restaurant I hold it to a higher standard. 

The gindara was fantastic, though. Also their tamago is unique and interesting. Service was good. And I really like how the interior is done. Nice atmosphere.
author: Paul K.

description: Wako is good. My brother-in-law and I went a few weeks ago and had an excellent meal. While it was a five-star meal, I'm not sure I'd return. There's no specific reason in particular, perhaps the cost? It was $425 for two (including tip). We did the 11-course menu, each ordered an extra wagyu piece, had 500ml of sake (two different 250ml selections) and left a $50 tip. The service was excellent. My only complaint was that the dessert wasn't as good as I had hoped for given the cost/caliber of the restaurant. Of course, you're there for the fish.
author: Brian J.

description:
Although the name sounds a tad awkward in English, Wako is definitely a place to go and go again. 
I know Tomo (the Chef) from his years with Sanraku. 
Here he truly delivers a top notch experience. 
I truly felt in a restaurant in Japan. 
Style, simple elegance, essential design in the food. 
He even remembered my name when greeted me. 
I took the most expensive Omakase menu because I trust him.  I got blown away. 
Take a look at the pictures and you will fully understand.
author: Bruno S.

description: The best omakase dinner In SF, seriously. This place is truly a hidden gem and the experience exceeded all of my expectations.
author: Amanda H.

description:
modern japanese, fresh sushi, and comfort.  Modern wooden interior with a bright and cozy feel. None of the boring dim lit jazz feeling that too many sushi places go for.

Uni chawanmushi is amazing, rich dashi broth with fish, shiitake, mochi and uni on top. This is a mid $$$$ range sushi place but it's magic bc the rice is so good and rightly proportioned for each piece of nigiri. I had the buttered snow carb and chutoro nigiri and a mentaiko temaki. Chu toro alone is underrated and should be looked into more. It's better IMO than otoro bc it is less greasy and maintains the tunas true flavor. Sitting at the bar allows you to see the care and preparation that goes into each piece of sushi. 

Everything on the menu besides sushi is also great and warming, making the whole selection and experience awesome. 

Parking is miserable, but I would struggle again to eat at wako.
author: Megan L.

description:
I went to this restaurant because I used to go to Murasaki for Toshi-san's sushi before it turned into Wako.
In terms of Wako, the service was okay, nothing especially good or bad. 
Food here was very mediocre.  The quality of the fish and the creativity of the dishes were the same as any other sushi restaurants with $$$ price range. I originally have zero belief in Michelin rating for Asian cuisine, so this place getting a Michelin star simply reinforced my belief.  
I know my expectations are high, because I am Japanese, but I've adjusted as I lived here over the years.  I am being fair with this review because I am comparing it to other local Japanese restaurants.
author: Tama H.

description: 12/20 2nd time coming here this time to do the omakase nigiri special. so we were able to try more nigiri rather than usual course meal. Id prefer this one over the course if u wanna try fresh nigiri fresh uni fresh slices from all over the world this is the one. The plates kept getting better and better ending in wagyu again omg that is the best thing here one must try uni for the daring and blue fin tuna belly oh my. definitely not ur california roll type of sushi place 10/10 still great quick service with very informative staff
author: Charles D.

description:
4.5 Stars

I went here with my friend the other day and we did 12piece Omakase. Food was obviously so good. Everything was great. I especially liked the Chawanmushi with Uni on top as well as Hamachi which was smoked with apple or something. The best. The desert was great, we each got different one.

The chefs and waitresses are excellent. This is a high-end Japanese place so I am not surprised. 

Omakase was $100/person with appetizers, soup and desert. For only getting 12 pieces, I think it is a bit overpriced considering the fact that each sushi pieces are a bit on the small size. 

Overall, It was great. I would definitely go back to this place if someone takes me there.
author: C M.

description:
This place is focus on omakase & Al la Carte nigiri with upgrades by Japanese sushi chef Their size & price was better than kusakabe..($$$$) and the nigiri were professional Japanese sushi from sushi rice to each fish nigiri..of how it's made.. Too bad they don't use red vinegar with More umami flavor for their sushi rice..  

I didn't enjoy the tai, cuz it's lacking flavor and taste. It's too boring..as i felt sushi chef were lacking passion..

Felt the chef don't have natural passion but trying a lot but they really have the potential become excellent.  

bluefin tuna w/jalapeño torched: A+
Uni:A  Fresh 
Tai: B- tasteless 
Barracuda: B+ very hard white fish 
Wagyu beef: A+ sweet ponzu w/momiji aroshi scallion garlic chip.. Delicious! 
Anago: A nice Anago sauce! 

Gindara w/nasu & okra dashi broth: A++ 
(Super delicious!)

Salmon Kama shioyaki: B not enough salt.. Tasteless.. But it was soft & fresh
author: Le Chef

description: A couple of days before going to the restaurant, I made a reservation and informed the person on the phone that we'd be celebrating my birthday. I went here with my family expecting a one-star Michelin experience; maybe my expectations were too high. I don't think the person on the phone wrote any notes down for the reservation because I certainly didn't get treated like it was my birthday. Pretty meh is all I'm going to say. Oh, and - ain't goin' back.
author: Eva G.

description:
Definitely one of the best sushi places in the bay area. 

$45 for the best omakase I've ever had?! Yes please! My boyfriend and I definitely put our trust into these sushi chefs, and we did not regret it! Each nigiri they hand out is perfectly crafted and just mmm mmm melts in your mouth. Every single piece tasted so different from the other but still managed to cause an extravaganza in your mouth.  I've never had a sushi experience like this before! The omakase also comes along with a soup and two small plates which also delight the taste buds in your mouth. The tea is also delightful along with your meal! 

And oh man! The silverware! From the teapot, to the plates, to the utensils, the silverware is so appealing to the eyes. The whole restaurant is nicely decorated, but the silverware just seals the deal. 

Also, the sushi chefs were absolutely charming! My boyfriend and I were 19 when we decided to come here. So we couldn't order any beer or sake. But! They still offered to cheers KAMPAI! with our tea cups and their alcoholic beverages. Made us feel very relaxed and engaged during our meal. They also answer all your questions enthusiastically and kindly if you have any while you sit at the sushi bar. Also, they're open to getting to know their customers which is always a plus!!! Waitress was nice too. They were all booked for the day, but she managed to slip us in for two seats at the sushi bar an hour later. 

Overall, this is the best sushi experience I've had thus far! I'm so glad my boyfriend and I decided to splurge on sushi during our visit to SF that day! Definitely would give it a ten stars if I could!
author: Kim N.

description:
Love their ambiance! Love their service!
And of course love their sushi~~~

Everything is so fresh and yummy.
Love dat we dont need to dip in soy sauce or wasabi...

All r very flavourful!

From halibut, mirugai, awabi, engawa, ink ika, shima aji, hokkaido uni, anago, hon maguro, A5 wagyu, cant remember all, hahahaha~

Plus my fav tedorigawa sake!
Wonderful experience, just like what I had in japan.

Definitely going back!!!

Mango mousse cheesecake and chocolate to end the meal!!!
author: mui chu C.

description: You know this place is legit when the sushi chef/owner reprimands you for not eating your sushi the moment he serves it onto your plate. "haven't you watched 'jiro dreams of sushi'?!" he asks us. I immediately pop each beautiful and delicious sushi in my mouth after our scolding to maximize the taste and experience of each bite. Wako is special because they have a very unique selection of fish and different preparations of fish to add a variety of flavors. I wasn't a fan of the sushi rice cuz it was a bit sticky but overall a wonderful experience for the sushi omakase. The service was great and they had a great sake selection. I can't wait to go back!
author: Christine H.

description:
If you eat here, try and sit at the bar for the full experience. I've been here twice now. The second time we sat at the bar which was a much better experience. The sushi was served piece by piece rather than all at once. 

I have to say that Japan has totally ruined me for sushi...so my spoiled ass thought wako was good but not GREAT. The ambience is superb with the wooden themed interior, though. This is probably the most authentic omakase you could do in SF right now. Their non-sushi dishes were wonderful. Really loved the matsutake soup, miso cod, and tempura with matcha salt. 

The course meal is definitely a good deal. Although we did sushi a la carte the last time we were here. Tell me who orders ALL of the specials of the night? We do...
author: Stine H.

description:
My experience with Wako is good.  Came here with 4 others and service is there.  We paid $150/pp with drinks.  Wako is good but not great comparing to few other places in san francisco.   I believe the reason is the quality of the fish.  They charge quite low for omakase and it was very fulfilling.    The size of their courses are huge comparing to others.   If we didnt spend that much on drinks, the bill will be around $80/pp even with a la carte added.   For the price,  this is one of the hest omakase theme sushi restaurant in sf.  My favorite is the homemade tofu...reminds me of the tofu I've had in kyoto.  

Will recommend for friends and will come back as well!
author: Wasabi L.

description:
Nice restaurant with a trendy atmosphere. Very helpful waitress. We had some sashimi and rolls as a starter. They were really excellent. The tuna was great, as was the cod. 
Not cheap, but had a great evening.
author: Garnett S.

description: Came on a special occasion and did the higher-priced omakase with my girlfriend and her sister. Sat at the sushi bar, ended up being likely the best meal I've ever had. Unreal quality, attention to detail, and taste.
author: Ben P.

description:
I guess you really gotta pay the price to get some good sushi in the city. This place is def worth the money :) we did the 12 piece omakase - oh lord. Top picks:
1. Spanish mackerel
2. Golden eye snapper
3. Bonito
4. King salmon
5. Striped jack
6. Blue fin tuna belly
7. Wagyyyyyuuuuu!! Ahhhh so good
8. If you're an uni lover you'll love. My fiancé is and he said its one of the bests he's had.

Savor every piece because once it's over you'll be wishing you're rewinding the night.
author: Jess T.

description:
As I am sure it is good, it is for me WAY TOO expensive! have to be part of the super elite to afford to eat there! (This has been the problem with San Francisco, these new upstart restaurants are way out of line and cater only to the wealthiest of residents in this city! The poorer classes do not count any longer as San Francisco has been from what I have heard a 'playground for the elite'! Such a nice city but ruined with this exclusive classism)!

There is another new restaurant opened on Balboa Street near 6 Avenue that is not receiving many customers as well, as they have also priced themselves out of the market beyond reach of the not-so-rich. as well (I predict that they will undoubtedly fold real soon).
author: Nikolaos P.

description:
No frills, no fancy bells and whistles. Quality fresh fish, prepped well, dressed well... that all ate well. It was the best meal I've had so far this year. 

To give you an idea on pricing I paid $500 after tax and tip for 21 pieces each for two (42pc total), chawanmushi, corkage on a sake, 250ml sake. Yeah it was $500, but not bad for the quality and that we almost hit 50 pieces. To give you more perspective on pricing, a single A5 Wagyu is $10 where it would be $15-20 elsewhere.

The chefs are funny and informative. As in this exchange...

"This is the Blue Fin Tuna marinated in jalapeño soy."

Chef, is that authentic style?

"No no, it is Latino style! In Japan we use different pepper."

I've already paid my first and last month's rent for Seat #3. See y'all there!
author: Al L.

description: Compared to other Michelin star restaurants, the food quality is fine but not outstanding. Where they come up really short is small quantity of food for $92 per person. I would expect twice as many pieces per person.
author: Hazem M.

description: Amazing food and service.  The sashimi was very fresh and near Tokyo restaurant levels.  The same meal in Tokyo would cost you 5x the prices here.  Loved it, and will return often.
author: Doug S.

description: We sat at the chef's counter and had the nigiri omakase. Each piece of nigiri was a whirl of flavours and textures. It was so perfect. The most pleasant Japanese meal I've had in San Francisco so far. (The chef is really nice too and the venue pretty cool with good music.)
author: Olivia M.

description: Had a lovely experience last night with the 11-course omakase. The food was delicious and the service was great in this cozy restaurant.
author: Ari R.

description:
Omakase. Plus more.  Order extra uni and hamachi and wagyu for dessert. Yes dessert.

This is not a casual sushi lets grab a couple of rolls kind of place. The food is exquisite. 

It does kind of raise the bar for all the other sushi restaurants I go to. 

Highly recommend the omakase. Sit at the sushi bar if you can.
author: Dani K.

description:
We enjoyed our dinner here.  It is a really beautiful little restaurant.  All their various dishes they use to plate the food were beautiful.  We did the $100 omakase nigiri menu.  The fish was not as prepped as much as at Kusakabe or Omakase but there were was some interesting flavors added to the fish.  We started with a small 4 appetizers plate that was good.  There was also miso soup in addition to the 12 pieces of nigiri.  And we ended with a small dessert that was tasty.

We also added an extra 3 pieces of nigiri.  All the fish was very fresh though not spectacular.  The service was perfect!

I guess the day of 2 pieces of nigiri of the same fish for a reasonable price is gone!  LOL  We notice all the upper tier of sushi restaurants only offer 1 piece for almost what we used to pay for 2 pieces not that long ago.  Is the quality that much better?  Not sure it is.
author: Kell M.

description:
One of the top Japanese restaurants on my list. If you haven't tried this place yet, you are missing out! 

Let's start off by saying how picky I am about Japanese food (really). The food and service at this cozy and sweet place is absolutely delightful. I've been here at least 4 times since they opened and this place is so impeccably consistent. The servers and sushi chefs, Atsushi-san and Tomo-san are always so polite and friendly. I've sat at the sushi bar a few times and ordered the omakase as well as at a table ordering a la carte. The kitchen dishes are very tasty and the sushi is so so so fresh every time. I personally enjoy the element of surprise of the omakase more and add more sushi if I am still hungry (because I eat a lot). I always make sure to end dinner with the uni. I'm drooling as we speak. Let's not forget the sake selection too because sake + Japanese food = a very happy me!
author: Soph T.

description: Back for another mindblowing experience and it was indeed a no fail! We had the nigiri Omakase and had the freshest selections. I can't rave enough about this place and I just hope it stays consistent. Make sure to call early to reserve a table as it stays booked even on a rainy Sunday! I'm definitely a regular and will keep coming back. I recommend starting with the first Omakase option on the menu and the nigiri Omakase for your 2nd time!
author: Pam V.

description:
Out of Wako, Kusakabe and Maruya, Wako is probably my favorite.  But that isn't saying much.  The sushi here, for someone who lived in Tokyo for 4 years, then lived in NYC for 8 years (and bemoaned how there were only two Tokyo-grade sushi joints in all of NYC), was inoffensive.  

Rice was properly flavored, though extremely delicately so.  What does it mean when flavor is so subtle it's almost indiscernible?

Fish was fine, though ultimately uninspiring.  Bland.  When fish is good, it tastes like life.  This was just okay.

Really, inoffensive is the word that comes to mind.  Where is the rich, nuanced flavor of good rice, balanced with sweetness and sourness and a rich oily piece of live aji on top?  

Actually, the kohada was pretty decent.  Thinking about the good pieces, you might be able to make a passable meal if you could just select the few items that are actually pretty good.  But I'm not sure it's worth the effort to figure out what all those pieces are.  That would mean sitting through dozens of rather mundane pieces of nigiri.
author: Jason C.

description:
Along with Yasuda in Tokyo and Arami in Chicago, the best sushi I've ever enjoyed. 

Went there for Christmas Eve with my wife. We were in an indulgent mood, and perhaps over-ordered by a dish or three. Each was better than the last. The barracuda nigiri was very memorable, as were the hand rolls. But the Wagyu nigiri was nothin short of remarkable. The most tender and delectable piece of meat I've tasted.

Will definitely return.
author: Isaac P.

description: So great to see a traditional Japanese restaurant in the neighborhood. It's beautifully decorated with a sleek design - though it's quite small so I would call ahead if you have a large party. My boyfriend really enjoys nigiri and completely devoured anything that was placed on his plate. This is a fresh fish place so if you're looking for rolls or chicken teriyaki - this may not be the place to go. Great service and atmosphere - will definitely be coming again.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Details, details, details!! Wako came highly recommended to us by a friend who lives in SF. Hubby and I ordered the omakase and it was an amazing experience from start to finish. I can't recall all the dishes, but the presentation was unique and beautiful. The nigiri was out of this world. The chef explained the origin of each piece and they all melted in your mouth. It was an intimate experience sitting at the chef's table and watching your meal unfold with such precision and passion. This is definitely a pricey choice, but a great way to celebrate a special occasion.
author: Tran T.

description: Of the 2 options available, my guest and I chose the 9 course dinner. There was an option to add a sake pairing which we also did for an additional $80 per person. We found the dishes to be prepared well, and we found them to be fresh, but I would say that they were lacking in both portion size and flavor. The sake was originally presented to us as 7 servings for a 9 course meal, but we then later found out that is was actually only 6 servings and that the server said 7 in error. The service team was very accommodating throughout the meal, but they were not very knowledgeable when asked questions regarding the fish, the preparation of each dish, or the sake. We enjoyed ourselves, but I would say that for the price, we found the overall experience to be overrated. We went and got burgers afterwards :)
author: Chris D.

description:
This has to be the best sushi in town. 
We sat at the bar and had the omakase nigiri. 

Highlights were the sea eel, fatty tuna, wagyu, house marinated ikura and Hokkaido uni. Basically it was all delicious. I would rate this better quality, value and less pretentious than Kusakabe which was my top pick before coming here. 

We had about 16pcs and came to about $125 per person. Super personable chef too!
author: P K.

description:
I love this place. It's our favorite special sushi spot in SF (say that 5 times fast!). Even if it weren't 3 blocks away from our house, we would still make the trek over to eat here. 
My fiancé has a birthday every single year, so I took him to Wako last night. We were seated at the bar (yay!), where we were served omakase: piece after piece of delicious fish arrived at the perfect time, made with such attention to detail. The fish was phenomenal- you don't need to dip it into that soy sauce/wasabi bog you always make (I know you do). Each piece is essentially crafted into a masterpiece of texture and flavor. I can't remember what we were served (there was some...lots of sake) but it was "close your eyes and have a moment" type sushi. Just trust me and eat here if you haven't already. Make a reservation, though. They fill up!

Bonus: the sushi chef lets me practice my Japanese on him! Then stumps me when he replies :-) I need to practice more.
author: Summer E.

description:
I was surprised to see all these 5 star reviews honestly, we opt-in for the omakase, for the price, the quality and taste of food was not up to par I think.

Nothing really was impressive. I was kind of disappointed. Will not go back.
author: Cheng C.

description: 2 major things: #1- It's SO BRIGHT in the restaurant and it ruins the ambiance when you're expecting a fine dining experience. #2- we ordered the 7 course tasting menu and sake pairing for a 9pm seating. Get this- they literally gave us the last 2 courses/2 sake tastings at the same time at 9:55 because the kitchen was closing at 10pm. Our server was really nice and you could tell she felt bad for rushing us through our $350 meal. Obviously the direction was higher than her and it was beyond her control but you shouldn't allow a 9pm seating if you plan on kicking people out by 10pm. It's just weird and something I've never experienced in a restaurant that is supposed to be upscale. The rushing totally ruined our experience and overshadows the food. We will never go back and I wish I could get the most expensive hour of my life back!
author: Sara Jo R.

description:
The sushi is excellent. The service is great. It is a small sushi restaurant of excellent service and quality.
It is also very expensive .
author: Natascha G.

description:
This is very close to a 5-star for me, but not quite there. 

Tomo, the sushi chef and owner, has endless patience answering our pestering questions about sushi, food, and life in general. Yes, if you go to Wako, sit at the sushi bar. Watching Tomo, a three-time U.S. Sushi MasterChef Champion, make your nigiri is a pleasure in itself. The ambiance is modern, clean (but not sterile), and comfortable. Great place to go on a fancy date.  

Now onto the food itself:  
Chirashi - Fresh but small slices. Has a dabble of uni included. I was disappointed that Tomo decided to use smoked salmon instead of fresh salmon though. For $36, I expected better.  

Best nigiri: yellowtail, scallop, mackerel, tuna, scallop (ask to keep scallop raw/un-grilled).  

Mediocre nigiri: chinook king salmon (too soft and mushy)  Drinks: Abbey Road sake (smooth, fruity, no aftertaste). 

The barley tea here is delightful too.  Desserts: House made black sesame daifuku (mochi) by one of the waitresses = amazeballs she also makes a killer panna cotta and green tea mochi.
author: Catherine C.

description: Excellent service and quality. Easily good value and of course delicious.
author: Alex C.

description: I absolutely love Wako, its a small cozy little restaurant and the staff certainly makes you feel at home.  The fish is always fresh and some of the appetizers are very good and very unique.  The Omakase for what I believe is around $75, is a very good deal, especially if you're willing to try new things.  But you certainly can't go wrong just ordering a la carte.  Reservations are highly recommended, since this place is small.
author: Darren W.

description:
Wow -- Nigiri Omakase, amazing, interesting, all good (though I'm not particularly fond of monkfish liver) -- Special Uni and Unagi at the end, good small plates, kept the shrimp tempura flowing for my 8 year old (who ate 1/2 my nigiri anyway). Really fresh fish, mostly brought in from Japan, but some local. amberjack, multiple kinds of tuna, Abalone, amazing small scallops. The Hamachi was smoked, which i usually don't care for, but still good. 

This is not your usual sushi place. No soyu to add tons of wasabi to and hide the lack of fresh fish ... very traditional Japanese, like what you'd get in a traditional hotel in Japan, including some items that we were not quite sure what they were ... 

Great service. After we left, they called to tell us we left them an extra $100 (two $100 bills stuck together) -- Could not believe it! Went back and got it, but left an extra tip ... Highly, highly recommended!!
author: Andrew C.

description:
Lovely, lovely little place and I hope people give it the special-occasion business it deserves. The prices are high, which is not to say you don't get excellent value. You do. But still, the prices are high. I would love to come here every week. That is not to be, alas.
We did the $82 set menu and everything was exquisite from the sashimi to the warm fish entree to the beautiful little mousse desserts and the tiny chocolates that came with the check. Pretty room, too. And the bathroom! Heated toilet seat, just like in Japan. A gem.
