author: Jennifer R.

description:
We came here because Wako provided the traditional Japanese Sushi experience we missed so much since we moved away from Japan. Wako is not the kind of restaurant that have fancy plating or over the top decoration/landscaping. No, these are not what traditional sushi is about. Instead, Wako excelled in two paradigms of excellent sushi making/service. First, they had absolutely excellent customer service: warm, welcoming, and very much down-to-earth-friendly. Second, although a small piece nigiri for $8-$13 may seem expensive, the actually quality of the cuts are quite excellent and definitely fresh. You will get to enjoy some of the freshest flavors across the globe. I will definitely be back for another round of "Omakase" when I'm back in San Francisco.

Cheers to Tomo and Goji ( I apologize if I have misspelled your names).
author: Nick Y.

description:
I'm going keep this one short, since there's not much more to say other than: Wako is the best sushi in SF. 

Incredibly fresh and authentic nigiri (you must do the Omakase here) -- delicious uni, barracuda, ankimo, halibut, and toro. The hot dishes were also all delicious. 

Love this place.
author: Roy C.

description:
A gem.  A diamond.   
Ordered the Omakase dinner for $76...
It was a seven course dinner.
Tsukidashi (with hint of new year delicacies including kazunoko), assorted sashimi with house made soy sauce, tempura, yaki-mono (baked oyster and scallops), assorted sushi, akadashi miso soup and finished with white wine mouse.
Presentation of food was exquisite.
Impressed with the ceramic ware used to serve each dish.

As an extra we ordered Satsuma Wagyu nigiri sushi for ten dollars each.
A melt in your mouth experience.

We enjoyed the nice selection of sake..

This restaurant just opened in July of 2014.  Wako is definitely a five star restaurant and to those who put three stars on review because portions are small and complain that his stomach did not get full doesn't really know how to appreciate thoughtfully presented and prepared essence of Japanese kaiseki cuisine.

I wish I lived nearby so that I can be a najimi kyaku.
author: Mark M.

description: One of the best Sushi restaurants in the city and it is my most favorite place to go! Quality of the Sushi and whole experience at the restaurant are amazing!
author: Kenji L.

description:
From all of your dining experiences if you were to enumerate on what makes for a phenomenal if not great dining experience what would you have list? First foremost company? The food, its freshness, its flavours, and how it is plated? The service and attention to detail? The authenticity to the cultural elements that has influenced the chef/the restaurant? Last but not least the ambiance and cleanliness of the venue?

Of all of the aformentioned the one area of Wako that needs improvement would be service. The food and the level of detail/attention the sushi chefs have dedicated to their craft hands down is worthwhile. However through out the entire dining experience the running joke was whether the staff were truly Japanese as we felt the level of politeness was a bit forced. I would've hoped for an inquiry of whether there were any dietary restrictions or allergies.  It would've been wonderful if when a member of the group got up to using the restroom he/she would return to it nicely folded. It would've been amazing if the empty bottles and glasses were collected as opposed to us having to place it on the side to make room. It would've been great if as our ginger was nearing depletion it would've been refilled. It would've been great if after we finished the main entrees of the Omakasee we would've been asked if there were any additional items we would like to order instead of rudely being forced to pay because they needed to prep for the seating of the next dining group. First time we've ever dined at an establishment that didn't want additional $$.

There is a difference between good and fantastic, and although service may not be important for some it is an important element that is a necessity when you have patrons, even moreso in an environment/market where there are many other fantastic alternatives for sushi.

Would've given 3.5/3.75 stars, but since those are lacking as was the service I'll stick to 3.
author: G. F.

description:
Very fresh and expertly prepared seafood.  Many of the fish at Wako were as good or better than Jiro or Mizutani in Tokyo, but the rice was definitely not up to the Tokyo standard.

Owner/chef is very friendly.  If you sit at the sushi bar, he will explain each fish to you as he serves them.

We had the Omakase meal which includes an A5 Wagu beef.  The beef is good but not great as I have had much better Wagu beef in Japan or in other San Francisco restaurants.
author: Eric T.

description: Teeny tiny restaurant. Teeny tiny portions. Fish was good but the lowest omakase obviously yielded the cheapest sushi and sashimi offerings. Waitress coughed all over us. Agree with other reviewers that the service could be greatly improved upon. Ju-ni had way more professional service, more reverential towards the fish (and the customer). Appreciate the substitution though when I said I couldn't eat egg.
author: Ina H.

description:
Wako is an exceptional restaurant. The service is extremely good and everything I had was excellent. I did the 7 course omakase and added on maybe another 5 items or so, and was very pleased with everything. It's not a cheap place, all said and done everything I had with tip and a little bit of sake was $175 but I left feeling full, but not stuffed.

Everything was really good, and I would definitely come back, but I can't say anything completely wowed me but even with that being said, overall I would say that Wako is one of the best, if not the best sushi restaurants in SF and I have been to a lot. 

Kusakabe vs Wako? That is a tough one. I think I would have to eat at both again to reach a final verdict, but I would happily eat at either again and can honestly say its really close and both are amazing.

Wako is quite small and reservations are very limited so book ahead.

Pro tip: ask for the bar, and if you book online, call ahead and ask if they can reserve the bar for you.
author: Brent F.

description: You HAVE to go to this place and you HAVE to sit at the sushi bar. No excuses! The sushi is really made with care and everything was so good. The biggest thing for me about Wako was the temperature of the sushi was just perfection.... and no extra soy sauce needed. At most of these things I like some pieces and not others but here I loved pretty much everything that was put in front of me. Cant wait to come here again and again and again!!
author: Eileen H.

description: We had the omakase (2 people), seven course. There was plenty of food. The sushi was very fresh and the food presentation was very nice. I was very happy that they offer fresh wasabi and not the wasabi paste out of a tube.
author: Melissa C.

description: Best sushi experience we've ever had. We had the tasting menu and all of it was just pure perfection. Our Waitress was very knowledgeable of the menu and all its ingredients.
author: Laura U.

description:
Made reservations ahead of time. The sushi here was fantastic and the place was very clean. 

We order the 7 course omakase and a few other pieces of nigiri to top off the tank.  The sushi was clean and fresh.  Enjoy each bite!  

Decor: 5
Food:5
Service: 5  

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami I would!
author: Kelson H.

description:
I'm a lifelong lover of sushi and have been to most of the highest rated sushi bars in Tokyo.  After 10+ meals here, I would rather eat at Wako than most of them. It is without a doubt the best sushi bar in Northern California.

Most sushi bars can get a fresh selection of fish from Tsukiji now days.  The topping is only a small part of the equation and a prerequisite to making good nigiri.  Tomo-san's rice, creative preparation, laser focused attention to detail and hospitality set him very far apart from the rest of the pack.  Not to mention that the decor and design of Wako look like a three star Michelin sushi bar that was transported straight from Ginza.

Simply incredible.  Go.
author: Will H.

description: You gotta be shiittin me was my retort to my Japanese wife long time Sushi loving globe trotting companion. We were served five micro plates consisting of egg, tofu, octopus, potato and wagyu jerky. No no no this is total shit, and we are not buying into your hype. Done no more and we left for greener pastures.
author: Bill K.

description: ever since Wako earned its Michelin star, the portion and the selections are a lot less than before.
author: Carol C.

description:
Worth every penny. I do Wako's omakase every few months, it is incredible value for the money. Great sake pairings, excellent service. Definitely my fav sushi experience in the city. Nothing more to say other than don't miss this if you like sushi and find yourself anywhere near by. 

Make sure to get reservations well in advance!
author: Jim S.

description:
Ordered a la care tonight and everything was delic! Pricey but delic.

- nigiri: salmon, saba, and anago
- giant fried clam (wouldn't call it giant but was good)
- salmon skin handroll
- sesame mochi for dessert yum!
- complimentary house made chocolate was so good

Next time will have to try omakase.
author: Gina R.

description: You should dine at Wako if you want a truly unique experience. However, if you are starving the portions are quite small and expensive. With that being said, you don't come here to get filled up, you come here to taste the freshest selections the chef has to offer. I had the omakase nigiri at the sushi bar and it was an evening to remember. One cannot explain the variety of tastes. You simply have to try. Highly recommend. It also has a Michelin star which is always cool:)
author: Paul G.

description:
Here are the reason why is just A-OK. 

service is great, so nothing to complain about.
Food taste great as well, very fresh and delicious.
value is where it had gone wrong. 
for its price for the omakase i expected a little more. sure it taste good, but portion is really too small....each pieces is smaller than most places. 

I had the omakase course set, after course is done, i ordered a few more and still not full!!! when i pay this much for food, yes it must taste great, which it is, but im not full!!!

If you want great sushi, try yume in alameda. each piece is bigger, and i would say it taste better too. Yume only seats 8 people so the chef is only making sushi for you, and at wako they are also making dishes for others in the dinning area. 

so will i go again? probably not, i would just keep going to yume.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Amazing sushi experience with a less crowded,  comfortable ambience .

I went  to Wako with a group of friends and we each order the 8 course set dinner.  I must say they lived up our expectations of what true japanese couisine should be.  Each of the course was a surprise and was meticulously crafted to perfection. The restaurant was  small but I didn't feel that I was packed into a small space.  The services was awesome.  I really enjoyed my dinning experience there and would go back.
author: Wil M.

description:
Dainty, tiny little overpriced portions.  Extremely limited selection of fish.

The fish itself is not bad, but there is much better around for more reasonable prices.  Other reviewers seem to love this place, maybe I am missing something??

Nahhhhhhhhhhhhhh.

Won't be back.
author: Albert R.

description:
If I had to compare this to Saru Sushi, I'd say this place is 100x better. I had the omakase (whichever was more expensive :] )

Rice: spot on, flavorful, definitely has seen a very careful process to make the rice.

FIsh: Does melt in your mouth count? You can definitely tell that there is quality in this fish. I'm a real big Uni fan and as far as I can tell, this one is suberb. I've been to one of the best sushi restauarants in LA so I know what is good fish or not. :D

Service: My girlfriend and I sat at the bar, and at first, it was sort intimidating and awkward becuase it was so quiet, however, the chefs made conversation with us and the experience became perfect. We got to know the chefs and a little bit of their daily lives. This is what sushi bars need to do in my opinion. We made reservations a little late, but they were nice enough to fit us in. 

Overall: If you don't want to spend a ton of money at Kusakabe, come here; it's 2nd best. Price is totally reasonable, hehe.
author: Alexander N.

description:
It's actually 4.5 stars but I'll round up.  The city lacks really good authentic Japanese cuisine, so Wako is a much needed addition to the restaurant scene here.  

Service, decor, and atmosphere feels exactly like some of the Japanese/new sushi places I've been to in Tokyo.  The night that we were there, about 90% of the patrons were Japanese.  If I had closed my eyes, I sort of could imagine that I was back in Japan again. 

Let's get down to the food.  We ordered the 7 course omakase, holy moly, it was a ton of food!  Wako's strong suite is definitely their cooked dishes.  The grilled fish, uni chawanmushi, ankimo, and tofu.  All were great, well except the ankimo was a bit overdone but the flavor was spot on.  Sushi was good, the technique's there but the quality was just OK.  He didn't have higher quality cuts of fish, and when asked about copper river salmon (it was in season), the chef said that it was an expensive fish.  It is an expensive fish, but other restaurants like Koo manages to serve it.  All of the sushi we had were prepared and seasoned nicely though, so the mediocre quality of the fish isn't as jarring versus if it was prepared the traditional sushi way.  This isn't to say that they have bad quality fish, their fish are leaps and bounds above places like elephant sushi and anami.  I would place it the same quality standard as Roka, which I am a fan of also.   Also in the beginning the sushi rice was really fresh, so it was a bit warm, which heightened the vinegar flavor.  The texture was great though, and after the first few pieces the taste improved dramatically as the rice cooled.  

The dessert was amazing!  I'm usually not a dessert girl but I could eat a whole bowl of the panna cotta that they served at the end.  I also want to go back to try their matcha mochi, it looked amazing!

We will definitely be back, order a bunch of hot plates and order a bit of sushi if in the mood.  I'm so happy to have a true authentic Japanese restaurant in the city and be able to do this, usually we're stuck with the options of only sushi or only hot plates.   If Wako improves their sushi, it might be my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city :)
author: Christina L.

description:
Very small place, but decor is nice and staff is friendly. I wanted to sit at the bar, but they only do 6pm, 630, and 8pm. I wanted 7pm so we had to sit at a table. You can get 7 course omakase with cooked food for $75 or all nigiri for MP. I got the 7 course and it was so yummy. A little bit of everything. The highlight was the 8 different nigiri you get. No soy sauce needed. Super fresh. Loved it all. The rice was super good. 

We also added a la carte items: ankimo, tomago, tuna roll, steam egg. All were very yummy and the price was decent. 

I haven't had good quality Japanese food in awhile and I am sure there are a lot better places out there, but I was very satisfied!
author: Karen H.

description:
Wako has a very reasonably priced omakase menu. The first course consists of a beautifully crafted seasonal vegetable dish, very light, very appetizing.  Almost like an amuse bouche.  Then the grill dish we had was a nicely chared pieced of salmon, with the right amount of fat.  It was almost as buttery and decadent as a piece of black cod.  The 7 pieces of nigiri followed were the highlights of the meal.  The fish super fresh.  The rice chewy and perfectedly cooked.  Each nigiri was nicely seasoned, with a hint of citrus or a pinch of wasabi.  The fish's distinctive flavors were not masked, but elevated.  What ended a wonderful meal was the matcha daifuku, pumped with a creamy filling similar to Beard Papa's famous cream puffs.  Not overly sweet, just the perfect little sweet note to end your meal. 

All for under $50 (excludes tax and tips.)  I think that's a steal.
author: Candice B.

description: The seven course omakase was a good value with the sushi and eight pieces of the best nigiri I've ever had. Really enjoyed the scallop and salmon.
author: Pearl L.

description: Had a good experience here, got the 7 courses omakase and everything was skillfully prepared with amazing details. The sashimi was fresh.
author: S T N.

description:
I have conflicting feelings on my experience at Wako. While the food is high quality I feel like the environment and service aren't up to par.

Wako is definitely a small restaurant. The center of the restaurant is a sushi bar. Table seating is relegated to about five. Even though the restaurant is very small it is easily a five dynamite stick experience. I've been to party sushi restaurants that are quieter. It's a strange dynamic when you're eating high quality food with the soundscape of a super bowl tailgate.

The food is broken down into grilled pates, appetizers, small plates, rolls, and nigiri. This isn't a cheap restaurant. Each piece of nigiri goes for $5. But the nigiri does melt in your mouth. The fish has a really high level of luscious fattiness to it. Two of our party, including me, opted for the pre fixe menu. They don't specifically state what you'll receive. It just says the amount of nigiri, small plates, etc. The prix fixe menu is a relatively good value, I think it'd be best to order exactly what you want and adjust as needed. While the food is good overall I feel like it's lacking a bit of that "oooh" factor. The one standout dish is the chawanmushi.

Service is questionable. Even though there seem to be many servers, the experience felt like an ordeal for both staff and customers. One of the difficulties stems from the number of plates. There are so many plates! For the nigiri they even combine customer's orders on one plate. Then the waiters have to discuss each and every piece to the customer. I feel like the waiters would have a much easier time if the restaurant weren't so cramped. We were never really checked up on, but it was mainly because they were so busy trying to bring us our plates and take away the ones we were finished with.
____
High caliber Japanese cuisine that you'll most likely forget about thirty minutes after leaving. Chaotic service and atmosphere. Is the food worth the hassle? I'm not sure but it's great on its own.
author: Michael H.

description:
Incredible! It's an experience.

I walked by this place and the decor was so clean and woodsy that I needed to come here. DO set a reservation because every single seat is taken! They fill up the place to maximum capacity!

Get the 7 course omakase. Everything was so fresh and perfect. Service was amazing. There is literally a set server for each table. She even told me what not to eat (there was an odd plant on the plate). She refilled my teapot probably 5x.

Oddly, they do not serve any soda...
author: Carleen W.

description:
Love.  Love.  Love.

This is not a Japanese restaurant you should go to if you want something cheap, don't appreciate/like raw fish, or only like untraditional rolls.

A and I went this past Saturday for dinner.  We called a couple of hours earlier to make reservations, although, technically, we didn't need to, because our table was the only one available when we walked in, so we probably would've gotten it anyway.

I have a feeling this place is going to be packed once the word gets out.  So shhh...keep it down.

We both got Omakase Option #1 ($43).  
- Small Plates (2) - Braised eggplant and housemade sesame tofu
- Bincho Grill (2) - Grilled Cod
- Nigiri (7) - Bonito, Snow Crab, Uni, Salmon, Otoro, Aji, Hamachi
- Miso Soup - option of red miso or housemade miso.  

Ala Carte
- Hamachi Yuzu Miso

Everything was high quality and so GOOD!  The highlight of our night was definitely the nigiri, with the otoro being our absolute favorite.  Everything is pre-seasoned so no soy sauce is needed.  In fact, there is no soy sauce on the tables, although I think they will give it to you if you request it.  We did not.

It's a little pricey, but you get what you pay for.  We will definitely be back!

$115. for two.  No drinks.
author: Kris L.

description:
I found my go-to sushi spot. 

Simple, traditional Japanese sushi. None of that Philly Roll nonsense. Rice. Fish. Simplicity. 

I only recommend this place for elite sushi eaters that understand the true Japanese tradition and acknowledge the rare art of sushi. Expect only the finest quality fish. One should never put a price on quality seafood. Raw fish is not meant to be cheap. 

I felt as if I was back in Japan. And I thank the sushi chefs for bringing sushi back.
author: Yunah R.

description:
Go here. Now. Before it becomes impossible to get in. 

After the Chronicle wrote this week that: "... we were a little late to the trend, [but] Japanese flavors are taking center stage in Bay Area restaurants" we decided to try one of the new, more authentic sushi restaurants that opened recently. 

We wandered into Wako not knowing what to expect, but with each bite and every attentive bit of service, the dreary mood from the wind storm outside faded away. They should rename this place "Transcendent Sushi." I'm not exaggerating. I will remember our dinner at Wako as my first true sushi experience and one of the best meals of my life. The fish was the highest quality, the preparations were impeccable, and the entire omakase menu was perfectly thought out. 

We were also thrilled to learn that the chefs / owner came from Sanruku. We recognized some of the recipes (like his luscious sesame tofu), but the food was at a whole other level. This is a joyful place, in a restrained and beautiful way, and I can not wait to go back. We're making our next reservation so that we have a return visit to look forward to.
author: Shoshana D.

description: Made a reservation yesterday. Got in today. After eating, made another reservation in 2 weeks! (YES that says a lot for me) Probably my first really authentic, traditional "sushi" experience. Got the omakase 7 course with extra appetizers and nigiri and of course lots of alcohol! I must say everything looked delicious and it tastes just as pretty as it looks! If you lahh dat uni, damn their Hokkaido uni... So fresh, so gooood! That sesame tofu... Gooodness, I can die and go to heaven. I lovee tofu in general and their tofu was seriously the tastiest I've ever had! Service was excellent and the atmosphere was comfy and homey! See you in 2 weeks! A suggestion - make reservations... I saw them turn away all walk-ins. Do it now or regret 5ever. :)
author: Betty P.

description: I was a little bit suspicious of all these rave reviews on Yelp, but I was totally wrong. This place is real. I don't usually drive to the city just for sushi, as there are other good sushi places in the peninsula too. I might change my habit now!
author: Makoto K.

description:
SF is so fortunate to have this amazing new restaurant. I ate here on Thursday night with my girlfriend; we have been having omakase at all of SF's best sushi restaurants and Tomo and Atsushi are setting a very high standard with Wako. We came here on their 3rd day and the food, service and atmosphere were all exceptional. 

As is our custom, we like to have omakase (chef's choice) to give the chefs the chance to put their best foot forward in their own personal shock and awe campaign. The Omakase began with a few special dishes then sashimi before being served edo-mae style sushi (preseasoned by the chef). All was of the highest quality and creativity. If you are looking for a fantastically authentic sushi experience, Wako is tough to beat in this town. 

Tomo is from Shikoku (smallest of Japan's four major islands) and was trained in Osaka, which is known for having some of the best cuisine in all of Japan. This training really shines through in the authenticity and quality of the dining experience at Wako. I expect it will soon be very difficult of get a seat at Wako.
author: John D.

description:
Omg! What a lovely and elegant spot I've found! I was even more happy that their sushi is fantastic! Perfect! Yummy yummy! The service is spot on.
Very good sushi spot and the best in the Richmond district.
author: Em C.

description:
Just a tiny little restaurant with no more than 5 tables and a few seats around the sushi bar, the menu at Wako includes few a la carte dishes (only a few appetizers and nigiri), with a pretty great sake menu. 
My Omakase was a mix of sushi, sashimi, hot dish, soup, salad, tempura, and dessert. The other option included only sushi. Both meals hovered around the same $80/person price point. The reason why the sushi-only Omakase was more expensive was for the Uni and Wagu beef additions, which were more exclusive and higher grade. I personally thought the mixed Omakase was fantastic. I'm a sashimi fan and being able to enjoy both sushi and sashimi made it worth it. As far as highlights, the tuna sashimi was some of the best tuna I've had in my life. The texture, freshness, and taste of the tuna was quite simply exquisite. For sushi highlights, I found both the Toro (fatty tuna), and squid (raw but lightly torched on the top) to be of special significance. The hot appetizer of the day, miso marinated black cod, was also fantastic.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Hands down, the best sushi I've had in SF. Tomo, who used to star at Sanraku, takes it to another level here. I am very picky about which nigiri I eat, but I had faith in Tomo's mastery and ended up enjoying fish I previously hated -- like ankimo (monkfish liver) and pretty much any white fish in the sea. 

It's expensive and you won't find any dragon rolls or any mayo-slathered Americanized stuff (which I actually found to be refreshing for a change), but you won't find better sushi in the City. Plus, Wakako U. (aka Wako) loves the name!

I used to complain that San Francisco was something of a second-rate sushi town. No more!
author: Brett W.

description: We sat at the bar and did the nigiri omakase menu.  We ordered a couple bottles of sake to go with and it was a near perfect experience.  The chef was super warm and friendly.  He explained each dish as it came out.  I can not wait to come back!!
author: ML ..

description:
Food quality and presentation is amazing! Went for the 7 course and it did not disappoint. 

The highlight is the nigiri which is basically a sampler of a whole bunch of different fish each one extremely impressive on their own, but each of the earlier courses were equally flavorful.

If you have a large appetite you may have to add something on top of the main meal. We added the grilled squid and the black cod miso which were both amazing. I cant describe the style in which this was prepared but it was absolutely delicious.

Prices are a little on the high side so be prepared to throw down some money but its definitely worth it. I'd say for 2 people about $200 but if you're not super heavy eaters I think that same amount of food could be good for 3 or 4 on a mother's day or something like that.

We got in early at 6:30 on a Thursday night but by the end of the meal they were turning away guests who didn't have a reservation. If you're coming in for a later dinner or on a more busy night make sure to reserve ahead of time.
author: Mike H.

description:
Best sushi place in SF. Amazing quality and delicious combinations. Beautiful presentation. Kind and attentive service. 

Definitely go for the 7 course omakase. A very special and memorable meal!
author: Monica C.

description:
had the omakase:

* nigiri/sashimi dishes are very high quality fish: 5 stars
* needs to ease up on the bitter flavors in the warm dish & appetizers: 2.5 stars
* tempura dish was soggy: 1 star
* 1) requested no wasabi on the nigiri. it came with wasabi. when i mentioned it to the waitress she did not offer to correct it. she merely shrugged her shoulders. 2) it is one thing to keep topping up our tea cup, but when you keep adding hot tea to cold tea, it does not help the tea. the above 2 points = very unprofessional service skills

would definitely go back for sushi/sashimi, but since it is becoming an omakase only menu a return visit is unlikely with its history of inconsistency.
author: Sam K.

description: Amazing! We had the omakase dinner and it was delicious. Every course and the way each dish was plated was absolutely beautiful. Great service and great dining experience.
author: Lisa C.

description: Best sushi place in SF, nice settings with extraordinary attention to details. We sat at the bar with Chef Tomo, and ordered the nigiri omakase 12 pieces, every piece is a true gem, with well balanced flavors.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Decided to come back here recently after having a 5/5 star experience the first time. All I can say was the food this time was okay (tuna was still very good and delicious), but that was about it and I felt $200 for myself and my date was totally not worth the amount of food I got this time for the 7 Omakase dinner because I still left hungry. Don't think I'll ever want to come back. Plus the Omakase 7 course use to be $76, and now they jacked it up to $82, when your portions are already small. Service is still good, but the experience was ruined after having an awesome time the first time.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
Hands down the best sushi in San Francisco-especially given the price. I've been to this place at least four times, and each time it does not disappoint. 

Food is great; service is always friendly. Thank god SF finally has an awesome omakase place!
author: Tim R.

description:
This was a delicious, memorable Japanese meal.  
The two of us shared about 8 dishes and appetizers off the non-sushi list, and each was delicious and a work of art. The best was the yellowtail dumplings, which were like fishballs in tofu soup.  

Nigiri was small and prices high, nothing stood out.  

Desserts were delicious, but a standard little mochi was $5.  

Dinner for two, no alcohol, was $150.  My friend and his girlfriend came and ate exclusively sashimi/sushi items (no hot dishes) and his bill was $300.  

This place is small so sound really travels...it got unbearably loud when a party of 6 drunk older women came in.
author: T Y.

description: Wanted to try this place because of the rave reviews and because I usually only go to kusakabe for my pricey sushi fix. There's two omakases to choose from, one with hot dishes and one with just nigiri (the latter being more expensive). I decided to try to first one. The hot dishes were good but nothing very special. The sushi is top quality and would definitely recommend. The chefs are very nice. Next time I come I will get the nigiri omakase!
author: Jessica Y.

description: No, this is not your typical teriyaki beef Japanese restaurant.  I called last minute and able to score a seat at the sushi bar.  The dinner was set and prepared by the sushi chef.   The  sushi was amazing and it was simply one of the best sushi meal in I had in SF.
author: Sfscubaman T.

description:
Food: 3 stars
Price: 2 stars
Service: 2 stars

Wako is a total disappointment. Quite the shame as the neighborhood needed an upscale sushi restaurant to fill the void left by the passing of Sasaki-san (See Murasaki, http://www.yelp.com/biz/murasaki-sushi-bar-san-francisco).

Wako is a total racket. The kind of people that dine here and rate it highly fall under one of two categories...either they are too rich to care or they simply don't know any better.

Case in point: Nobu K. For those of you who don't know this man, he is quite the infamous Yelper and an expert on Japanese food in SF. Whatever you may feel about his ranting reviews, he is rarely wrong and has the experience to back up his opinions. Therefore, it was quite the relief to find his Wako experience was identical to mine. Give it a read... http://www.yelp.com/biz/wako-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?hrid=3eoFpyL1jJqqfXjuD3Kv0g

Details
---------------------------------------------
We ordered two portions of uni at $10 a pop but what arrived was about a tablespoon of actual food. The smallest portion of uni I have ever seen in my life. Worse, the uni looked chopped up and was slopped upon a bed of daikon. Why would you do that to uni?

We also ordered the toro, which while of high quality, was also disturbingly small at around 1 1/2 inches long and 1/8 inch thick. Again, the smallest sashimi I have ever seen in my entire life. Shockingly so. Like the uni, the actual preparation of the fish was not so great. My two pieces of toro were totally different jagged shapes and one significantly thicker than the other. No garnishes, no special plating, nothing but a dollop of grated daikon and a single shiso leaf.

We ordered a bunch of other items and the only stand out was the Wagyu Beef Stew, which was pretty darn good. The Assorted Fish Collars was mediocre at best. Without the dipping sauce the fish was dry and bland.

I was also greatly displeased by the service. Once we informed our server that one of us was a vegetarian, you could tell we were not welcome and the service reflected that going forward. Didn't matter that we had ordered sake for the table and were ordering expensive fishes from the daily specials. When we asked what was available to order, we were shut down immediately. The server made it clear there was nothing he could eat, that even the seemingly veggie dishes contained some form of bonito. She made absolutely no attempts to suggest a course of action. Just to be clear, we weren't expecting too much and were cognizant of the kind of establishment we were in, it was the treatment and service that was a let down. FTR, I believe there are only two veggie items on the entire menu, a cucumber-sesame maki and an umeboshi maki. Everything else has been prepped before service so you won't be able to make edits.

The real travesty was the pacing. First, all of the non-veggie food arrived first. Meaning, the poor vegetarian sat there for 25 minutes as dish after dish was served to the meat eaters. How long does it take to make a cucumber-sesame maki exactly? Then they mixed serving the raw items with the cooked. That's just not right man! They know they screwed it up as we received one apology near the end when one of the appetizers was served so late, it arrived last, after all the main items.

TL;DR
---------------------------------------------
The prices and portion sizes at Wako are shameful. There are plenty of other restaurants to spend your money at that won't leave you feeling scammed. It was difficult to look down at my plate and realize that I was about to eat $50 worth of fish in a couple of bites. The photos on their website didn't look anything like what we received. It's totally possible that the quality of the fish surpasses other restaurants but who cares if you are receiving bad service and microscopic portions?

If you really must dine at Wako, just get the omakase. The dishes look more consistent and the small portion size makes sense for a 7-course meal. But honestly, do yourself a favor and go somewhere else.
author: Sam S.

description: One of the best sushi restaurant in SF. It's pricy(one order for 1pc nigiri), but totally worth it. The sushi are fresh, well cut and nice decorated, the small plates are delicious too...wait, actually everything is good here!!
author: Rex M.

description: Great friendly service! We had the 7 course omakase. Really fresh seafood with a good variety of different fish. With the price tag, this place will be a special treat for a special experience.
author: Olivia A.

description:
Clean and modern interior, really sharp. Service was excellent and each omakase course was swiftly brought out after the previous one was finished.

The fish itself was fresh, but I wasn't too wild about the extra wasabi seasoning on the nigiri.
author: Orien W.

description: Well deserving of their Michelin star! Everything was good and of high quality!!!
author: C J.

description:
14.09.18     First Visit of many



Sushi ---------------------  5 (freshness, different preparation)
Non Sushi ---------------  4 1/2 
Interior -------------------  5 The obvious and hidden details
Service ------------------- 5 Stars (I believe I gave only 2 other places this honor)


Note: I have never went to Japan ... 
                so I cannot truly compare it to some of their finest sushi places.
          however I had been to Kiss, Kabuto (old and new locations), etc

Service
   Exceptional
   3 very courteous professional female wait staff
   Almost like having a personal wait staff for your table
 

Had one of WAKO omakase dinner:
      Four Course   $43 
                             small plates (2), bincho-grill (1), nigiri (7pcs.), miso soup


Black Cod
    Marinated in miso


This is a place that is exceptional that is one of the top 2% in the Bay Area
Expect slightly higher price ... BUT you get
   Exceptional service
                      quality ingredients
                      presentation
                      taste

There are too much detail that I will add later:
   Interior ... layout, presentation, dishes, ...
   Yes ... sometimes I  am into detail ... 
              I would observe things like a detective ... I am curious person
              shape, size, placement, texture, blah, blah 
             I would take many pictures of a single subject in different angles for
                    a perfect picture
             This place and food kept me buzy w/o a smart phone (solo run)

I will not bore u with overkilled details
The nigiri did not come with a side of soy and wasabi.
The pieces were treated that u don't need to add anything

Simply ... I am saying it is a personal experience
               Open your mind ... like a child and let it soak in
               Observe the surrounding, table, service, etc

ROUGH DRAFT ...
More to come

ENJOY

Warning:  RESERVE ...

I regret posting this ... now it will be even harder to get in ... sigh ...
author: S.K. Y.

description: Easily one of the best Japanese restaurants I've ever been to. Authentic and intimate, the food is exquisite and well executed. Go for the prefix, well worth the $$.
author: Marianna L.

description:
Originally was planning to eat superstar, and they sent us to bstar. Thankfully they did as we passed this little gem on the way over. 

Just opened and this traditional Japanese restaurant is great!

My friends opted for the four course while I opted to get a few small plates and a roll. The yuzu hamachi was light with the right amount of citrus while the cod was amazing. The chanwanmushi was delicious and not overly salty like some places. I will say the roll was a little forgettable, but overall the traditional small plates were great.

Would definitely come here again.
author: Harrison T.

description: Authentic, quality and simply outstanding Japanese cuisine.  Love this place.  Great selection of raw and cooked...omakase is the best way to go if it's your first time.  Really one of the best in SF.
author: C L.

description: I woud give this place 3.5 stars.  I dont know what the hype is about. The fish was fresh but nothing really stood out.  The cooked stuff wasn't bad but again nothin memorable. I came here in search of other sushi places in san francisco, but always end up at the same place saru sushi.  This place would be good date pace and as a first time omakase style dinner.
author: Richard M.

description: Good experience. Wannabe Jiro! Severe rip off people! One amazingly small piece of Uni for $9? Uni from Russia , that wasn't even as good as Mendocino for that price. Two pieces be $18!? On Clement Street? The owner is making a huge profit margin!! Sushi is expensive, but you can't blatantly rip off your clients! It wasn't worth the price. And that's real talk!!
author: steve a.

description:
Yes, the food was good (not great), but the service is horrible.  Clearly, the restaurant wanted our table; and dinner was thrown at us with no regard for order.  We got a hot dish then sushi then a grilled fish then more sushi. Who serves this way?
The bill was almost $70 without wine (the price of the house wine was not on the menu; the server told us it was "about" $14 a glass). 
Yes, the decor is charming. The plates are lovely.  The food is innovative, but even the best food tastes rank with bad service. My spouse and and I have eaten in many top Japanese restaurants (in Japan and in other countries).  This place was the worst.
author: Allyn H.

description:
When I finally spend the time to write a yelp review, then the experience must have been mind blowing.   I eat alot of sushi, and this tops any sushi restaurant in the bay.

I was a fan of the sushi chef and owner, Tomo, when he worked over at Sanraku in the metreon building.  He is both a fantastic chef and food artist.  When I heard he left to open his own restaurant, I knew it was going to be great.

At Wako, I was a single diner, so they were able to fit me in at the sushi bar, but reservations are highly recommended as many people were turned away at the door.   It's fun to sit at the sushi bar because you can see these two chefs make their magic.    

Tomo would explain each course to me, and the waitresses would also tell me where the fish came from.  It was either locally caught, like the salmon and black cod, or it came from Japan.   They also said that they make the wasabi there, from fresh wasabi root.    Their were two Japanese women sitting next to me, and they were both telling me that this restaurant was very authentic.  I believe them.

I went with the 7 course meal.  Everything melted in my mouth.  EVERYTHING! 

So if you want to treat your mouth to something orgasmic, go to Wako.
author: Brian V.

description: Great spot.  The food was delicious and inventive.  We had the 7 course menu which was fantastic.  The waitstaff was attentive.  Not a huge spot - maybe 8 tables or so and perhaps a dozen spots at the sushi bar.  Perhaps the rain kept people away, because at 8 pm, there were spots at the sushi bar and a walk-in couple was able to get a recently vacated table.  Pretty casual - yoga pants and hoodies seemed to dominate the sushi bar.
author: Anthony D.

description: Yummy yummy yummy yummy yummy and fresh and delicious and I can't WAIT to go back!!! We had the sushi omakase and everything was top-notch, sitting at the bar with the owner serving us was a real treat.  He's fabulous- friendly and knowledgable and the restaurant is comfortable and the service lovely.    Only drawback is the parking on Clement street, of course.  Otherwise, it's really a great restaurant and I can't wait to go back!
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
Delicious, traditional Japanese dishes, wonderfully prepared and presented in a cozy but casual yet elegant setting. Excellent and friendly service. 

We got the 7-course omakase ($68) and enjoyed each course. Stand-outs were the house made sesame tofu and the tasty sashimi / nigiri. 

Make a reservation since the restaurant is small. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jing D.

description:
What a great sushi restaurant in the Richmond district! Yes, it is pricy but it well worth it. The sushi is very fresh and the presentation of the food is gorgeous (for those who appreciate art). 

We tried their set menu and was not disappointed. The handmade mochi is the best we've ever had! Had to order a second round of them because it was so tasty!
author: Ang P.

description: Nice interior and ambiance. Very authentic and traditional Japanese taste. Tamago was like sponge cake, and different but I liked it. Presentation was also very lovely. Staff was helpful too. A bit pricey but I would come back again.
author: Glo D.

description: Wasn't crazy about all the starters but omakase was amazing.
author: Xteethx B.

description: This Japanese restaurant is phenomenal! Doesn't matter what I say, everybody on this planet who remotely likes Japanese food must give this place a try. Nuff said.
author: ed k.

description: The best sushi restaurant in the bay area. Top quality foods and services. If you want traditional Japanese food, here is where you want to go. Better order the 7 course omakase if It's your first time there so you can trying everything. (Order 7 course because it comes with a dessert that 4 course doesn't come with) All there desserts are hand make. Basically you won't be able to have the same thing you had here from other places! Highly recommended!!!
author: Elaine P.

description:
This place is my new favorite for new school sushi!  I've been to all the good spots and used to work in a Japanese restaurant and I am very impressed with this place!

I'm coming back here next week for my birthday.
author: Carl L.

description: The restaurant decor is a mixture of woods and tiles, simple, cozy and  tastefully done. Chef Tomo and Atsushi put traditional Sushi into art form. Omakase is the way to go, you won't be disappointed.
author: Denny L.

description: A highly rated, Michelin starred Japanese restaurant... Hmm... that's perfect. My wife loves sushi, and I enjoy Japanese cuisine, so we've got to try the place. I went here recently with my wife for a late Valentine's dinner on a not so perfect day (man, it was raining a lot). I must say overall the food is not bad. We both went for the 9 omasake course. The highlight of them all were the different nigiri sushi pieces. They were all so good, and they included scallop and a variety of different fishes. However, I found them to be small. I guess that's normal for fine-dining = small dishes and high prices. I had to order a couple of extra nigiri because they're pretty yummy. We also had a bowl of sashimi, some eggy soup thingy, sweet mousse desserts, miso soup, and some other items I cannot remember what they're made of. The tuna sashimi was very good. I'd rank it as high as the nigiri. The other dishes were okay. And about the service, it was pretty good, but it depends. I like the person who was serving us. She was super friendly and always look happy. However, another lady there who helped to serve us was kind of stern and seemed a little rude. Anyhow, I definitely enjoyed it here more so than my wife, but I left this restaurant feeling unfulfilled and went to get McDonald's on the way home. 3.5 stars for me.
author: Con N.

description: Very authentic Japanese restaurant.   The place is very small so reservations are a great idea.  Service is a bit basic but the food is excellent especially sushi.
author: Andy M.

description: I went here with my girlfriend, and it was amazing! We had the 15 piece nigiri omakase. Each fish nigiri was fresh and tasty. The presentation is very beautiful! The abalone nigiri was a bit too hard for both of us, but everything else was spectacular. I would definitely come back some other time to try it, again.
author: Kevin Y.

description: It was a random choice to come here, but this was a clutch decision! I've heard a lot of good things about this place, but until I try it myself, I don't want to say its as good as people say. Soooo....IT IS AS GOOD AS PEOPLE SAY! haha. We ordered the Omakase (it was 7 courses) and it was very impressive and it was pretty cheap, I think it was around 80 each, not bad for very good omakase. I will be back!!!
author: Q W.

description: The ambiance is very nice and the wait staff are great.  The food is good, but not worth the price.  The sushi is good, but again, not worth the price.  This is a serviceable Japanese restaurant in a nice location in the Richmond, but the prices are higher than warranted by the quality of the fare.
author: Harry P.

description:
3.5 stars. The $76 7 course omakase is probably about 15-20% overpriced given the portions and the selection.

Course 1 - Hijiki seaweed, pike eel, deep fried scallop, minced toro filled cucumber and somen noodles - pike eel had torch taste and the cucumber overwhelmed the toro flavor. Seaweed and somen were standard and good.

Course 2 - Red snapper and yellowtail nigiri - very fresh and good.

Course 3 - Sweetfish wrapped tamago with a dipping sauce - very simple and a little too bland.

Course 4 - Fried soft shell crab with dashi - nicely fried with a thickened dashi broth sauce.

Course 5 - Mackerel, pike eel, snow crab, scallop, salmon, barracuda, toro, striped jack fish - nothing exceptional or really fresh. I would expect the same quality at another sushi place that is significantly cheaper. They served the pike eel which was already in the first course. Can I have some uni?

Course 6 - Red or white miso - good quality but is this a course?

Course 7 - Panna cotta - standard panna cotta with fruit toppings.

The ambiance is very simple and modern which adds to the experience.

I would not recommend the omakase for the price and selection. The presentation was very nice though. Maybe my expectations were too high from the Yelp ratings.
author: Amy H.

description:
I've been here 2x. The first time i had dinner here i thought the fish was fresh and the service was standard.  My girl and i ordered a bunch of nigiri and left with a bill over $200. The nigiri and sashimi pricing is per piece and is very expensive. 

I went here with my girl and a friend on friday. My girl wasnt that hungry and ordered a small plate,  hamachi yuzu miso, and an order of sashimi bluefin and yellow tail. My friend and i ordered omakase..he ordered nigiri and i ordered sashimi.  
My girl's small plate and sashimi came out quick which was ok but now she felt obligated to sit and wait for our food, which we figured would come out shortly after.  we waited for a while then decided to split her small plate which was AWFUL- there well five tiny cubes of yellow tail and some mixed vegetables.  The yellow tail was extremely fishy and the miso sauce tasted like mayo.  My friend told our waitress that the yellow tail was very fishy and she responded with "thank you for telling me".  
It had been roughly 20 min since they served my girls food and she was still waiting for our omakase to eat her sashimi.  40 MIN LATER we had had enough and asked our waitress what was taking so long.  She said that a lot of people ordered at one time and our food would be out soon.  Really?  What is this amateur hour?  These guys have been open for 6+ months and should have this dial in.  We told the waitress we have waited for over an hour and were going to leave. She said that our food was going to be coming out in 5min...one piece at a time.  We told her no thank you and walked out. 

Overpriced sushi and bad service.  I will not be going back. There are a million sushi spots in SF that i love, and i'd rather spend my money with them.. and so should you!
author: Ezra K.

description:
I am positively in love with this place. Its fish is as fresh as it comes, and the warm plates phenomenal. To top it all off, the service is warm and accommodating. Being here makes me want to visit Japan.

Recommendations: black cod, house made tofu, any sashimi, and the wagyu stew.
author: Mary C.

description: Finally Tokyo sushi in San Francisco. If you want the best fish prepared in a traditional way with a touch of creativity you have to eat here.  They have ally the traditional preparations but also super creative dishes like jalapeño soy marinated blue fin tuna.  Don't miss this place.
author: Alexander L.

description: Lovely food and very nice chefs. Extremely expensive given the ambience and neighborhood. Huge minus: the cold and unsmiling server who, after I spent $120 pet person, asked me to vacate my seat at the counter when tables were empty, as a reservation had come in. It's true I was a walk-in, but wow ... she could learn some diplomacy skills. Don't go here; San Francisco has great sushi restaurants that are far better and at least act welcoming toward their clientele.
author: Courtney W.

description: I ate here twice. The sushi was just okay but I refused to go back because of the nauseatingly strong fishy odor in the restaurant, so my partner, who is black, went back by himself. There were empty tables and empty seats at the bar and no line, but after making him stand there waiting for five minutes while the staff had a conference in the back, they told him the restaurant was "fully booked" for the evening. How humiliating. If you are black, come with a white escort, or better yet, don't give this establishment your business.
author: Sarita O.

description: The closest you will get to Japan in Northern California.  Amazing, quality, creativity and service--even better than Sushiran!
author: WestCounty T.

description: Beautiful place and ambience. Expensive but one of the best sushi places I've ever had. Sit at the bar.
author: Vincent N.

description:
Outstanding overall in taste, presentation, service and thoughtfulness behind the meal.

My hubby and I went here on a whim last night, after being so busy at work and not remembering to find a decent reso for our anniversary.

This has been book marked for quite sometime but due to the mixed reviews and higher price point, havent had a chance to take a leap of faith to go just yet....until last night!

We both opted for the four course omakase, consisting of other reviewer's similarly served items:

1) house made tofu with wasabi, dashi stock & seasonal vegetables with bamboo and chestnut-refreshing, a good starter, but best housemade tofu by far is still raku in las vegas. 
2) grilled black cod- fish cooked to perfection, one of the better cod's ive ever had, no bones like previous reviews, excellent and buttery!
3) nigiri- korea halibut, chinook salmon with yuzu gelee, bluefin tuna marinated in jalopeno so, pike mackeral, kani with crab butter, seared hokkaido scallop 
4) red miso soup with himeki mushrooms. Good shari (rice) to fish ratio, edomae style sushi where they paint on the sauce so you dont need soysauce. Everything was very fresh, and delicious favorites were the bluefin tuna marinated in jalopeno soy, so flavorful, and the tuna a very good quality grade tuna. Scallop was also high on the radar, considering normally I dont like scallop, this says a lot. The searing added a good texture to the normally mushy scallop...delish!


add ons to make our belly full!

A5 wagyu nigiri, x 2- $10 a pop, but totally worth it. Beef comes cooked (seared I think so eat it while its warm) buttery & so tender
$8 hokkaido uni chawanmushi, - almost as good as aki-san at sushi sho in el cerrito! except this one was highighted due to the hokkaido uni included inside! so precious and yummy
$8 ankimo - the best ankimo weve ever had. Most ankimos have the gritty taste in the middle, but this one was SUPER smooth, velvety like foie. OMG!
fried mackeral fish bone - on the house, one of our favs
$3 tamago- so good, get it last for dessert, not a traditional tamago but has hints and notes of vanilla or coffee, almost like cake!
$5 matcha daifuku- house made mochi with redbean and matcha inside. heavenly
blueberry panna cotta $5 - good, not mind blowing, mild tasting like most japo sweets
grilled hokke- $8 this grilled fish was such a pleasant surprise. Its a grilled fish filet with bones, grilled over charcoal. You can tell the care the cook used to grill this fish to perfection, its normally a "dry cured" fish and they grill it so it comes hot, but it was the most moist and delicately seasoned fish. Comes with a side of yam. so delicious and healthy.



Hubby is generally a hater of small foods, and was pleasantly surprised at the japo chefs behind the counter. ( I thought they were chinese owned) 

He said overall the quality and presentation was great, and tomosan- the main chef you can tell he cares a lot about his restaurant, the customer experience and thought is put behind each and every bite and it shows.

$180 out the door with 1 small asahi beer. experience, priceless! 
not necessarily a normal day type of meal since it is pricey but for those days you want to splurge....

for those haters who gave it 1 or 2 starts and complained, sorry yall but you dont know what good traditional japanese food is supposed to be about. 
go eat your jive ass rolls elsewhere in the marina =)
author: Petri Y.

description: This place, like most restaurants on Clement Street, is terribly overrated. I had the very expensive Omakase and everything about it was just mediocre. They use way too much sugar (or is it HFCS?), the fish was not very fresh, and the dishes frankly were ordinary. I'm not inspired to go back again.
author: Eater S.

description: I enjoyed the omakase here.  In fact, I find the warm dishes pretty tastefully executed.  If I had to compare it to my Kusakabe experience, Wako gets the win for warm dishes.   However, the nigiri was only okay.  Kusakabe excels in that realm but you are paying significantly more for it.  I like that Wako doesn't enforce the omakase mandate so that allows for more flexibility.  Overall, I enjoy Wako because it's friendlier on my wallet.
author: Dorothy L.

description: Simply delightful! We had a reservation at 8 and they took us in at 7. Sat on the bar and had our omakase. The fish is definitely fresh.
author: Danny L.

description: Found Tomo!  He opened his own restaurant - So exciting!  I will eat sushi here more than anywhere else - perfect balance of taste, environment and price.  Excellent fish and shari. Shari was so good, very impressed.  We get the go all out omakase where you end up eating almost every available fish, either as sashimi or sushi.  We loved it all.  And, and, in addition to passing the rice test with flying colors, they pass the tamago test too - the tamago is exquisite, tastes like castella (Japanese cake.)
author: Wakako U.

description: Wagyu beef nigiri, yum! Just melted in your mouth. This resto is definitely worth for the price!
author: Lisa P.

description:
As good as sushi gets in SF. If someone takes you here, they're a keeper. 

From the food, to the decor, and ambience: this place embodies the modern Japanese aesthetic: relaxed yet intensely focused and elegantly simple. They do it well here. Can be pricey depending on what and how much you order, but worth it.
author: Jeff K.

description: Disappointed. 7 Omakase Sushi course was mediocre with mediocre fish selection. Also I could not believe they served farmed salmon in the Nimono dish from the kitchen. So much of "caring" about freshness and where their fish is coming from.  Sorry to compare but can't help it at the same time... Kusakabe is far better choice for your luxurious Sushi experience.
author: Miki M.

description:
7 course Omakase is a must try if it's your first time. 

Everything was on point and delicious! 

Parking is hard to find. You need to park maybe 2 blocks away.
author: Brian S.

description: Wow this sushi is good. Like insanely good. Incredibly fresh and very Japanese. Do not come here if you are looking for California sushi. But if it is authentic Japanese style sushi seek, this is as good as it gets. I used to live in NYC which arguably has the best sushi outside if japan and I can say this place rivals nyc sushi without a doubt. I've also been to japan and can say this sushi spot can easily hold a candle to sushi in japan. I've eaten at at least 15 different sushi spots in SF including koo sushi, o'toro, sushi zone, sushi ran, ichi sushi, zushi puzzle , saru sushi, eiji, daigo sushi.. I could keep going. Wako is in a league of its own.
author: Joey B.

description:
seriously though.. on a serious note.. if yelp was to let us rate a 10 star for one place and only one place.. itll be this place right here.
came here for the boyfriend's birthday and ohh my gosh.. let me tell you it is sooo worth it.
this place is very tiny. its half the size of my room... lol jkjk
make sure to sit at the bar if you choose to get the 7 course dinner
for a small girl, i have a very big appetite and this place not only made me fulfullingly full but i enjoyed my experience here. like really enjoyed it.
i have NEVER ever went to a sushi restaurant and experienced the freshness of seafood like this place. 
for a lil less than$200 for 2 people. i wouldnt mind doing this every month if they were closer to me
the sushi chefs are such sweethearts! they really made me experience incredible. thanks for everything
author: Holly V.

description:
We came excited - a new restaurant with solid 5 star reviews. The higher expectations made for a harder fall. 

Service was very slow. We waited 30 mins for our last rolls (after asking about them too). The food was creative/interesting but just not great. Wrap it all up in a high price tag. 

I'll come back in a year or two. Let them work out their kinks. Too much good food all around.
author: Oren W.

description:
WOW! What a great dinner!

Hands down one of the best sushi experiences in the city!

Sit at the sushi bar and have the chef tasting menu. It will run you $75 to $100 a person but it is totally worth it! It will not disappoint. 

They hold the service to the same standards as the sushi... 5 stars!!!
author: Lauren S.

description: We have been to this wonderful place on two different occasions. Each time we have had the Omakase. We have had the opportunity to try nearly every item on the Sushi side of the menu. The fish from Japan combined with an outstanding execution of the Sushi by the Chefs made for an excellent experience. We are looking forward to our next visit.
author: don k.

description: Wako is delicious, their omakase was the bomb! I just wish they weren't so crowded already.
author: Tatyana K.

description: Best sushi restaurant in San Francisco by far. Fresh sashimi and fish. The mochi and mousse is to die for. Will definitely come back soon.
author: Ronny B.

description: We had the $68 omakase in additional to seven other nigiri per person in order to get full. Presentation was very pretty, but the palate was too bland for my taste.
author: Eve C.

description:
Notice: the positive reviews of Wako are long. The poor reviews are short. 

I will counter this by making a positive review short:

I have eaten at pretty much every high end to cult favorite sushi place up and down the west coast and a fair number in Tokyo. 

We had the Omakase (plus as few a la carte items) and on a dollar for dollar basis Wako holds it own - and its only been open for a bit more than a week. Is it on the level of Saito or Urasawa? No. But it's coming in at a third or a quarter of the price, and you don't need to speak Japanese or wait a month for a reservation.

I do not doubt that in a year this will be a destination restaurant.
author: r g.

description: Came here for dinner with my girlfriend and a friend from out of town.  Been lived in Japan and eaten many Omakaze before, I would say this restaurant is of high standard in both services and food quality.  We ordered the 7 course omakaze for $76 each.  Out of them I thought the sashimi was fresh, the king crab tempura was tasty, and the main course nigiri sushi were exceptional!  The only thing I would say is that the red miso soup was a little too salty.  I preferred the white miso soup that my girlfriend ordered over the red miso soup.
author: Johnston C.

description: Yet again an amazing meal. Such a beautiful, clean, and welcoming environment. You guys have a concept and do it so very well!!!! Thank you for another delicious meal. So so so good. Go, eat here.
author: Kamilla H.

description: Great neighborhood for a authentic, delicious sushi restaurant.  We were able to get seated for 2 adults and 2 kids at 6pm on a Saturday evening.  It's not a huge restaurant so we were really lucky.  We ordered 1 omakase and shared several small dishes.  They were really receptive to the 2 young kids.  The sushi was super fresh and very delicious.  I'd definitely frequent this neighborhood gem.
author: Meredith K.

description: Amazing!! The whole experience was amazing...The food was beautiful, delicate, fresh and tasty! The drinks and service were spot on. It's a reservation type of place as it's very small. I can't wait to go back and participate in the chefs tasting menu.
author: PK R.

description: My new top sushi place in the city!  This place is spot-on with everything, from the decor to the dishware to the food itself.  Treat yourself to one of the course meals, and enjoy!
author: Corey C.

description: These guys are awesome, previously from Sanraku - Atsushi and Tomoharu are an amazing team.  We left our selection up to Tomo-San and all of the sushi and cooked dished were wonderful.  My favorite was a jalapeño-Mexican inspired tuna sushi. Go there soon before it becomes impossible to get a reservation.
author: Michael C.

description: Very authentic.  Servers were friendly and helpful.  Nice to see a sushi restaurant that rivals those in LA and NYC in terms of quality.  We both had omakase.  It's not cheap, but I came away happy.
author: Raymond C.

description: Best.sushi.ever!  Both my fiancé and I tried the Omakase and it was so great to have the wide variety of sushi, tasty grilled fish (with the perfect crisp crust), and amazing tofu appetizers.  If you're looking for a traditional Japanese restaurant, this is it.  I don't eat raw fish that often but did tonight and it was amazing- better than I have had at any other sushi restaurant in SF!!!  They even lightly flavor each piece of sushi so you don't need soy sauce for dipping and can better taste the natural fish flavors.  I will be coming back here again soon!
author: Mindy R.

description: I realized that EDOMAE is a new trend in SF!  In Japan, Edomae is a kind of niche style which chef usually put the sweet sauce on sushi. The sauce here was a bit more salty so I do not have to put additional soy source at all. This style is good fit with Omakase because I do not have to worry about what kind of sauce I should put on to each sushi. Anyway I am so happy to have Edomae in SF!!!
author: Ted H.

description: Hands down - the best sushi I've had in San Francisco.  The Omakase was fantastic. Will definitely come back and recommend this place to everyone.
author: Theresa N.

description:
Nakamura-san, thank you for serving the best Edomae sushi in San Francisco.  I knew from the moment my husband and I sat down at the sushi bar, that ordering off menu and just asking for your sushi/sashimi omakase was the way to go.  The freshness of your ingredients, your amazing rice, and your subtle flavors -- all I can say is thank you.

Order what you will, but do yourself the pleasure of sitting back and putting your trust in the sushi master.  The man is an artist, and the sushi is worth every penny.
author: Hannah H.

description: Enjoy some expertly cut fish and delectable small plates. Koji-marinated grilled King Salmon was suburb- as were all the mounds of perfectly temped rice with slivers of flesh atop. No other cuisine pays such great attention to details, so just let Atsushi and Tomo take care of you. They will.
author: Anthony R.

description:
I hate the typical Yelp review that starts, "I've never had sushi before, but this is the best restaurant!"  I've eaten a crapload of sushi, both in the Bay Area and in SoCal, but I have to admit that I haven't eaten at any of the other newish high-end places in San Francisco.  My partner lived in Japan for six years, and I may have picked up some of her fussiness about Japanese food, but I'm really just enthusiastic without being deeply knowledgable.

That said, this place seems like the real deal, with very traditional menu, and delicious fish with awesome texture.  Service was prompt and reasonably friendly.  It was certainly the best sushi I've had in San Francisco.  (Although now that I've read a few more of these reviews, I may be checking out the competition!)

Koshihikari Echigo beer is ubiquitous in the Southland, but a bit tougher to find up in the Bay Area, so I was happy to see it here.
author: Kevin L.

description: The place looked like it was the real thing. Portions are small and the nigiri rice seemed overcooked - a bit like unsweetened rice pudding underneath a morcel of fish. Even the sake that was recommended wasn't great. Decor was nice.  But think pay more for the "Japanese-Iness" of the place. Form over substance.
author: Tess A.

description:
this is my new favorite sushi restaurant in the city.
amazing service, ambience, food, presentation.
my new spot.

[heart]
author: Ivan C.

description: I would love to give this restaurant more stars! It just recently opened, but I have been here twice already. Both of the times, they went above and beyond my expectations. My family and I got the 7 course meal for the two times we were here. I believe it was $68 for a 7 course meal, but let me tell you, IT WAS WELL WORTH IT! Dish #1 was a three part appetizer: sesame tofu, mushroom medley, and okra and shishito pepper tempura. #2 maguro and seared hamachi sashimi #3 kyoto style grilled belt fish #4 hirame tempura #5 seven different nigiri sushi #6 miso soup #7 dessert. We also got chawanmushi in addition. It was the best chawanmushi I've ever had in the bay area. It was $8 and it had all sorts of things in it which included a fat piece of uni, white fish tasted like tai fish (not sure), snow crab, and it was just a whole lot of YUMMM. Not only does the food taste good, I love their presentation. It makes the meal enjoyable through the palate as well as the eyes. I know this place will never disappoint. If you are thinking about trying it out, you should do it soon because it just opened and it's already super busy. Weekends are pretty much reservations only because of their limited seating.
author: Saki S.

description: Words cannot express how delicious our meal was; simply put, I felt like the crevices of my taste buds were being delicately caressed with love and excitement. Will be back sooner than later.
author: Bink A.

description: If you have every seen "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" and wanted to experience it... this is the place.   Recently we went with dear friends who own their own restaurant and had heard good things about this place.  All four of us sat at the bar and had an incredible evening. The service, environment and food far exceeded our expectations.  Each piece of sushi was presented upon preparation and was not only a visual pleasure but an incredible tantalizing delight.
author: Sean S.

description: Every dish we had was delicious. The food was fresh, the flavors were on point, and the ambiance was inviting. Don't skip dessert because it is amazing.
author: Jo D.

description: Fantastic Japanese food.  The ingredients are outstanding in their taste and freshness and the atmosphere is a perfect mix of relaxed and elegant.  The omakase is very well priced and amazingly good.  Service was also very friendly.  I loved that place!
author: Bruno S.

description: We were so happy with our decision to try out Wako last night. My son did the ordering as he was most familiar with traditional Japanese food. Everything was so fresh, beautifully arranged & tasty. I experienced Chawanmushi (savory Japanese custard) for the first time. It was the most delightful dish, I will probably order it every time now! The new decor is lovely. Service was excellent. Hard to believe it's only been open two weeks.
author: Mary D.

description:
Excellent traditional sushi bar, with small menu of beautiful small plates and rolls.

Nigiri averaged out to about $5 per piece, so it's marginally pricier than competitor sushi places in the neighborhood. Fish was fresh and included some local selections (I believe the uni and salmon were both local), as well as some fish imported from around the world. The Norwegian mackerel was among the highlights.

I will definitely be back.
author: andrew m.

description: food is soso！ service is ok！ food quality and the price is not match totally unreasonable！ that is what i think！ no second time！
author: Horace L.

description: Good service and good value (Omakase). I had high expectations from reading the reviews here and must say I was slightly disappointed. Most of the dishes were pretty good but nothing stellar.
author: Johnson B.

description: Been there more than 5 times already .tomo さん is one of the best sushi chef in the Bay Area .never get disappointed .not even once .always enjoy the service and food there.always make a reservation before you go
author: Butterfaylc C.

description: Excellent.   This is one of the best Japanese restaurants I've ever been too.  The sushi melts in your mouth and every cooked dish tantalizes the taste bids.
author: Mike L.

description: Neither my husband nor I can think of anything we didn't like.  It's a pretty traditional, small sushi place.  Not much else to say than that.  It's definitely pricey, but what good sushi place isn't?
author: Nicole D H.

description: The best sushi I've ever eaten, and I eat a lot  of sushi! A lovely place to eat and very friendly staff. So pleased we happened across it. Will definitely revisit.
author: Chloë A.

description: Wonderful REAL Japanese food, beautifully presented. We enjoyed the omakase and ordered a few extras but turned out to be a little too much food. Everything was delicious. A cozy and authentic ambiance and great service. I definitely recommend Wako.
author: Cheryl M.

description: Made reservations a week in advance for 5 people at 630p. Got here at that time and we were seated near the door where it's a 4 seat table...wtf? We were not sitting comfortable. We asked to move to a roomier spot and they refused. Fine. Whatever...ordered the 7 course omakase for $68....omg...so not worth it!  The first 3 small tiny little plates tasted good but the portion size so small!  Nigiri's were okay sized, rice was good but again not worth 7 nigiri, 3 small plates, 1 grill, tempura, miso soup, and tiny ass dessert. Ordered one of their rolls where you can choose up to 7 items- good but way too small.  Sushi Sam is still by far the best!!  At least their salad order is a good portion size to share. We ordered some kind of a salad here and it was the size of my palm! Waste of time and money. Oh and forgot to mention- They charge you for wasabi if you ask for extra the 2nd time!!! Just cuz it's fresh doesn't mean you should charge $3 for so little wasabi!! Each order of raw fish should come with some sort of wasabi, correct? But only 2 of our many orders came with wasabi. We had to ask for more and when we did, they told us that it's $3 for extra....
author: Alyce l.

description: After going to Sasakisan for so many years I had to try Wako. There's definitely no comparison to Sasakisan.  The sushi was average and limited on the menu. Unfortunately nothing special about this place except it was expensive for what you get. Don't think I will be back.
author: Mary L.

description: Had the 15 course nigiri omakase. Absolutely incredible from start to finish. I've been fortunate enough to have eaten recently at Sushi Nakazawa (arguably by some accounts the best sushi restaurant in the country), and this place is just as good, if not better. This is real sushi, no super california dragon 49er cable car rolls, so if you're not into raw fish this is probably not the place to go. If you want the best of the best sushi in SF, this is the place to go. So happy to have a new place like this in the Richmond District.
author: Luis M.

description: very fresh fish, excellent value for the omakase
author: Judy H.

description: food deserves the michelin star, service and atmosphere is very unpretentious.  love this place
author: Jesse L.

description: Went to Waka Restaurant on Thursday night with a friend. The inside is so traditional Japanese style that I got the feeling that I was in Japan. The waitresses were very cordial and polite and the Sushi Chef was fun to chat with. Of course the reason I went there was because of the food. The presentation is absolutely beautiful and too good to eat. The fish is very very fresh and the other customers commented on this is what they were impressed with. Japanese restaurants run by other nationalities other than Japanese is fearful if you are looking for Sashimi or Nigiri. I have gone to other restaurants such as Sanraku Metreon and I would say that the price is quite reasonable for the quality you get. I will definitely go back again and recommended this restaurant to many others especially the caucasians and other nationalities who really know the true Japanese cuisine like in Japan.
author: Frederick K.

description: sushi like this I can eat everyday, little pricey but hey it's worth every penny. wow 5 stars!!
author: Christina W.

description: I had a wonderful and memorable dinner at Wako on a Saturday night. It's a small restaurant stuck into a crowded part of Clement Street, so find it and make a reservation. You won't want to miss this. We enjoyed fresh butterfish and sweetfish nigiri sushi, plus several other items from the menu, which changes daily depending on what fish they can get as fresh as they can. Among other things, we had the roasted seafood and vegetables, which were served in an abalone shell. I brought my girlfriend there for her birthday dinner, and while we were not late for our reservation, we didn't have time to go home and dress appropriately for our dinner. I was dressed in long shorts and felt embarrassed to go into such a classy restaurant, but the waitpersons could not have been more gracious and accommodating to us. Thank them  for such a wonderful and memorable dinner. We enjoyed every taste and dish we had, but especially enjoyed the black cod with eggplant, and loved the grilled fish collar, which is sometimes butterfish but happened to be salmon that night. What an elegant, gracious, lovely meal.
author: Susan R.
